corporate_registry.wiki_content:
===General Company Information (incl. ownership)===

The primary resource for accessing corporate records in Croatia is the [https://sudreg.pravosudje.hr/registar/f?p=150:1 Court Register] (''pub''), maintained by the Croatian Ministry of Justice. The register provides details on all registered companies, including their ownership, legal status, and historical filings. 

* **Searching the Register**:
  * Enter the company name or registration number ("MBS") in the search field.
  * For individual searches, enter the personal name.

* **Search Results**:
  * The search results include the company's registration number, date of incorporation, legal form, and status.
  * Ownership information may be available, but for full details, including shareholders, you may need to download the company's statute or other filings.
  
* **Obtaining Documents**:
  * The registry allows downloading official documents such as the company's statute, shareholder lists, and other filings. Some documents might require a fee.

===Chamber of Commerce Company Registry===

[http://www1.biznet.hr/HgkWeb/do/language?lang=en_GB Chamber of Commerce Registry] (''pub'')

The Chamber of Commerce website has a limited search of company information by number and by name. Results will show a graphical representation of basic information about the company, financial indicators and business analysis.

===Croatian Export Directory===

[https://www.hgk.hr/usluge/baza-uvoznika-i-izvoznika Croatian Export Directory] (''pub'')

This Croatian government portal provides information on relevant regulations and laws in the fields of investment and economics. You can search by name, primary activity, customs tariff (type of product), type of services. Information available for download includes contact information, primary business activities, size, ownership structure, and share capital. Additionally, you can search through a database of import and export companies.

===European Commission E-Justice===

[https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?CROATIA&member=1 European Commission Business Registry] (''pub'')

This is the European Commission overview of the Croatian business registry, which includes links to the registry, a description of how to search and what can be found as well as the legislation behind it.

===The Zagreb Stock Exchange===

[http://www.zse.hr/default.aspx?id=26484 Zagreb Stock Exchange] (''pub'')

This is the official website of The Zagreb Stock Exchange where you can get the information about all listed bonds, shares, issuers and their reports, data distribution and list of members.

[https://digitalnakomora.hr/home Official Croatian corporate registry (Digitalna Komora)] (''pub'', ''reg'')

[https://rsv.fina.hr/RSV-OnLineUnos-web/login Register of Beneficial Owners] (''pub'', ''reg'')

[https://www.fina.hr/rgfi Registry of Financial Statements] (''pub'')

[https://nesolventnost.pravosudje.hr/ Insolvency Register] (''pub'')

===Directorship Information===

The Court Register also includes information on company directors and authorized representatives. Details typically include their full names and sometimes their positions within the company. Historical directorships can also be accessed through the same register.

litigation.wiki_content:
Croatia has several public resources for litigation records, although privacy concerns may limit the availability of certain details.

* **Croatian Court Register**:
  * [https://sudreg.pravosudje.hr/registar/f?p=150:1 Court Register]: Also provides access to basic litigation records for companies. It is useful to check for any ongoing or past legal proceedings involving a company.

* **Other Databases**:
  * Croatia lacks a centralized public database for litigation records that provide full case details. However, basic case information may sometimes be found in the Court Register, or through specific courts' websites by searching their decisions.

[https://sljeme.usud.hr/usud/praksaw.nsf/fSearchNew.xsp Constitutional Court Decision Search] (''pub'')

The Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia has online its records for decisions made since 2000. You can search by signature, case number, or a year and date. The search returns results containing all of the terms supplied, not just one.

[https://sudskapraksa.csp.vsrh.hr/search Supreme Court case law portal] (''pub'')

[https://sudreg.pravosudje.hr/registar/f?p=150:1 Croatian Commercial Courts Register] (''pub'')

This is the official website of the Croatian government court register of legal entities. This register allows you to search by name or keyword. You can either search all Croatian commercial courts or specify a particular county. Search results provides company profiles as well as status updates on proceedings before the courts.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
To access the official registry, follow these steps:

* Go to [https://www.companies.gov.cy/en/21-eservices/esearch-in-business-entity-s-registry here] (where you can read a general description of what the registry contains and how it works).
* Click on "e-search."
* Enter the company's name or registration number in the relevant field and click "Go."
* Click on the company's name.
* On this page, you can see the company's name, registration number, legal form, establishment date, directors, secretaries, and address.
* If you want other information (see below for details) and are prepared to pay €10 for it, click on "Study File" at the top of the webpage, then log in (create a free account if you don't already have one).
* Next, enter the company name or registration number again and click "search."
* Choose the company and click "More details."
* Tick the box next to "Study File," click submit, and follow the steps to pay €10.
* On the following screen, click "eSearch Basket" to see a list of documents you've bought. Note that you might need to log in again at this stage, using the "Login" button at the top right of the page.
* Download the document from the basket and be sure to keep it somewhere safe because it won't be available to download again indefinitely.

This €10 extract should include (at least for limited companies):
* Full shareholder list.
* Name, address, and citizenship of directors, secretaries, and shareholders.
* History of any changes to name, address, directors, secretaries, shareholders, and share capital.

There's also a third-party database at [https://i-cyprus.com/ i-Cyprus] (priv). I definitely wouldn't buy anything from it, as it seems to be more expensive than the official site, but it is useful because you can search it by directors' names, something the official site doesn't allow. Note that the names of people who aren't Cypriot or Greek citizens are usually written in Latin.


And here is some crap pasted here by AI:

[https://eforms.eservices.cyprus.gov.cy/MCIT/RCOR/OrganisationFileSearch Ministry of Energy, Commerce, Industry and Tourism company filings portal] (pub, paid, reg)

The official register for all companies operating within Cyprus. This register includes detailed information about companies, such as their legal status, ownership structure, management, and financial data.

[https://efiling.drcor.mcit.gov.cy/DrcorPublic/SearchForm.aspx?sc=0&lang=EN&cultureInfo=en-AU Department of Registrar of Companies and Official Receiver] (pub, reg)

Free basic information about companies is available without a login. Paid information, including shareholding, is available for a fee, and the documents can be downloaded in English, Greek, or Turkish.

[https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?CYPRUS&member=1 European Commission E-Justice overview of Cyprus business registry] (pub)

[http://cylaw.org/ Cyprus Bar Association legal database] (pub)

A free online directory of all decisions (first instance and appellate) of the Cypriot High Court (the Appellate Administrative and Supreme Court) since 1997. Users can conduct full-text searches using the Sino search engine developed by AustLII.

Required for all subjects. Conduct an internal site search and look through recent judgments. The full text of recent judgments of the Supreme Court and other courts of the Republic is only available in Greek.

Required for all subjects. Conduct an internal search on the official website.

Required for all subjects. Conduct an internal search on the official website.

Subscription service that has Cyprus legislative and judicial service. All recent cases are available only in Greek. The only texts currently in English are older cases released in 1883 - 1989.

Access to the Cyprus section on WorldLII, providing access to various legal resources, including legislative and judicial decisions.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://or.justice.cz/ias/ui/rejstrik-$firma Commercial Register (entity)] / [https://or.justice.cz/ias/ui/rejstrik-$osoba (individual)] (''pub'') The Commercial Register is Czechia's official portal of all companies and other legally registered entities, including sole traders, associations and public institutions. The Register is administered by the Ministry of Justice. Search by subject name [Název subjektu] or identification number [Identifikační číslo; IČO]. Searches may be narrowed using additional details such as the street [Ulice], municipality [Obec] or court where the company is registered. To get results including '''inactive/deleted companies''', make sure to set the 'Vyhledávat údaje' dropdown menu on the right hand side to 'Platné i neplatné'. On the results page, for the full listing with historical data click 'Úplný výpis'. This provides registration date, file number, address, officers, and shareholding. On the results page you can also click documents collection ['Sbírka listin']. From the list of documents, you can click into each one, and open the PDF link at the bottom. The collection of documents contain public documents relating to individual entities (e.g. the company's charter, resolutions of the general meeting, annual reports, financial statements, etc.). The notarial deed [notářský zápis], equivalent to articles of incorporation, may have key information. Amongst the list of documents you should also find the Financial Statements [účetní závěrka]. The most recent financial statement may have more up-to-date information than the complete listing. The Register provides dates of birth and registered addresses of all officers and shareholders. *[https://wwwinfo.mfcr.cz/ares/ares_es.html Access to Registers of Economic Subjects ("ARES")] (''pub'') *[https://www.rzp.cz/portal/cs/ Licensed Trades Portal] - available in [https://www.rzp.cz/portal/en English] (''pub'') ===Ownership=== *generally available :-reverse: in some cases only In Czechia, not all companies are required to disclose their shareholders – for joint stock companies with more than one shareholder, the shareholders are not disclosed in the commercial register (though they may of course be the founding shareholders, which must be disclosed in filings). In these cases, information on the shareholders can only be accessed through the central securities depository by certain authorized persons, such as law enforcement, tax administration, public bodies. Sole shareholders are disclosed. [https://or.justice.cz/ias/ui/rejstrik-$osoba Reverse ownership search] - To get results including inactive/deleted companies, make sure to set the 'Vyhledávat údaje' dropdown menu on the right hand side to 'Platné i neplatné'. [https://esm.justice.cz/ias/issm/rejstrik-$sm UBO Register] Information on who meets the criteria of a beneficial owner: {- https://esm.justice.cz/ias/issm/napoveda#zmenyNew ]
Research Guide
'''Ultimate Beneficial Ownership''' The register of real owners (hereinafter also "the register") is an information system of the public administration, it is kept in electronic form by the relevant courts. The information system is centrally administered by the Ministry of Justice. The register of beneficial owners is not a public register in the sense of Act No. 304/2013 Coll., although from a technical point of view it is operated on the same information system platform. The records are partially accessible to the public, free of charge on the Internet. Part of the data is accessible to anyone for free on the Internet (https://esm.justice.cz/), without registration. The public is allowed access to data on the name, state of residence, year and month of birth and citizenship of the beneficial owner of the legal entity and the nature of the beneficial owner's position and the size of the beneficial owner's share, if the share establishes his status. The data that are the result of an automatic census and are therefore already available in the public register are also public. In the case of registered real owners of legal arrangements, the records are generally not public. Anyone can search the register by entering an identification number or the name of a certain legal entity. Anyone can also obtain a partial electronic statement directly from the website or a confirmation that no data is kept in the records of the subject.
===Directorship=== * available :- reverse: yes [https://or.justice.cz/ias/ui/rejstrik-$osoba Reverse directorship search] - To get results including inactive/deleted companies, make sure to set the 'Vyhledávat údaje' dropdown menu on the right hand side to 'Platné i neplatné'. ===Company Types===
''Details''
'''Limited Liability Company (s.r.o.)''' One of the most common types of companies in the Czech Republic is the limited liability company. Such types of Czech companies must be formed with a minimum investment of CZK 1. A minimum of one stockholder and one director are essential for forming a limited liability company in the Czech Republic. The stockholders may be either natural persons or corporations. An SRO’s stockholders assume limited responsibility for the organization, meaning they are not personally liable for the various monetary loans or liabilities of the corporation. '''Limited Partnership (k.s.)''' In a limited partnership, the general partners are fully responsible for the monetary debts and responsibilities associated with the firm. The general partner is in charge of running the business in such types of companies in the Czech Republic. Limited partners have restricted liability and as such, they are only responsible for the value of funds they have contributed to the partnership, as specified in the articles of association of the firm. '''General Partnership (v.o.s.)''' A General Partnership is one of the types of business in the Czech Republic where two or more individuals jointly control and run the business that is operating under a single trade name. Partners in such businesses split their earnings and expenses equally. Every member is entirely accountable for the financial commitments and responsibilities of the partnership company. As such, each of the members in such types of Czech companies is equally and jointly liable for the monetary obligations and responsibilities of the firm. There isn’t any basic investment requirement for forming such types of companies in the Czech Republic. '''Joint Stock Company (a.s.)''' A JSC’s stockholders have restricted responsibility, which implies that if the business accrues difficulties or obligations, their finances are not in danger. As such, the stockholders of an AS are only financially responsible for their investment’s value. Such types of companies in the Czech Republic must have CZK 2,000,000 as the required capital in order to be formed. This sort of corporation may be established by at least one stakeholder. The statutory authority for corporations with multiple shareholders is the board of directors, which must have at least 3 persons. A supervisory board of a minimum of 3 people is also required to be established by the joint stock corporation. The three people on the supervisory boards cannot also serve as directors of the corporation in the case of an AS firm. '''Cooperative (Družstvo)''' A cooperative, known as a “družstvo,” is a business that is held and operated by the individuals who consume its commodities and services. The cooperative’s main commercial objective is the societal or economical well-being of its participants, who are not individually accountable for the debts as well as liabilities of the enterprise. There isn’t any capital necessity for establishing a cooperative, however, it must possess adequate funds to operate. Such types of companies in the Czech Republic must consist of three individuals as a minimum before they may be founded. '''Sole Proprietorship''' Such types of business in the Czech Republic are controlled and managed by a sole person and can be established quickly and easily. In this kind of company entity, a single person operates their own firm on a self-employed basis. According to the Trade License Act, an individual can officially begin their business as a sole proprietor after they turn 18 years old. There isn’t any legal distinction between the company’s financial resources and those of the proprietor in these types of Czech businesses. As such, the firm proprietor is entirely and solely accountable for all financial debts and responsibilities of the firms. '''Branch Office''' A branch office in the Czech Republic is an addition to an international business that conducts business in the nation. A branch office in the Czech Republic isn’t regarded as a separate legal organization, thus, the parent firm must authorize all of its business-related decisions. Also, in such types of Czech companies, the parent firm is responsible for the duties and actions of its branch. The Czech legislation governs its formation and inclusion in the Czech commercial registry. International corporations who want to maintain a presence in the Czech Republic without establishing a distinct legal organization might consider opening a branch office there. It enables the parent business to keep oversight of the Branch office’s activities. '''Representative Office''' A representative office can be established in the Czech Republic by international corporations. A representative office is only permitted to carry out market research or advertise the products and services of its holding organization. Such types of business in the Czech Republic are not permitted to go on trade or enter into agreements.

litigation.wiki_content:
Germany has very stringent privacy laws; court records are typically anonymised, meaning the names of all parties (individuals and companies) are redacted. Nonetheless, it's quick to run checks in the available databases.

The first step is to go to [https://justiz.de/onlinedienste/rechtsprechung/index.php]. From here, click **"Bund"** to go to the search portal for federal courts, or click the name of one of Germany's 16 states (Länder) for that state's portal. On the resulting page, you usually need to click **"Entscheidungssuche"** (decision search) to open the search screen, then choose **"Volltextsuche"** (full‑text search) if multiple search types are available, and select the court(s) you want (there's usually an option for all courts). Key national courts include:

* [https://www.bundesgerichtshof.de Federal Court of Justice (Bundesgerichtshof; BGH)] – highest civil and criminal court; publishes decisions.
* [https://www.bundesverwaltungsgericht.de Federal Administrative Court (Bundesverwaltungsgericht; BVerwG)] – hears administrative cases.
* [https://www.bundesarbeitsgericht.de Federal Labour Court (Bundesarbeitsgericht)] – hears employment disputes.
* [https://www.bundessozialgericht.de Federal Social Court (Bundessozialgericht)] – social insurance cases.
* [https://www.bundesfinanzhof.de Federal Fiscal Court (Bundesfinanzhof)] – tax and customs disputes.
* [https://www.bverfg.de Federal Constitutional Court (Bundesverfassungsgericht)] – constitutional matters (case search via site).
* [https://www.bundeskartellamt.de/SiteGlobals/Forms/Suche/Entscheidungssuche_Formular.html?nn=3591512&docId=3589936 German Competition Authority – decisions] database.

Other useful resources include:

* [https://neu.insolvenzbekanntmachungen.de/ap/index.jsf Insolvency announcements] – federal site for insolvency notices.
* [https://www.bundesanzeiger.de Bundesanzeiger] – federal gazette; publishes insolvency and bankruptcy announcements.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
===General Company Information (incl. ownership)===

The first site to check for German companies is [https://companyhouse.de]. Sastre has an account on this site, and logging in makes some small improvements to what you can see. This website's layout is easily navigable, so it's good to check for a general overview. However, it's not 100 % reliable—especially for historical information (including establishment date)—so any information to be cited in a report should ideally be verified at [https://www.unternehmensregister.de] (see below). Moreover, companyhouse.de tries to charge extra for certain information, such as shareholder details, which can be obtained for free from unternehmensregister.de. **Never buy any filings from companyhouse.de**, because the same documents can all be obtained for free from unternehmensregister.de.

[https://www.unternehmensregister.de] is very tedious to use, but it has lots of great information, all for free. Here's a step‑by‑step guide to using it for general corporate information (including ownership):

* In the "Schnellsuche" field on the homepage, enter the name of the company you want.
* In the results page, scroll to find the right company and click on **"Registerinformationen des Registergerichts"** next to its name. Note that sometimes the company you want doesn't appear at the top of the results, even if you entered the exact name, so be careful not to accidentally choose the wrong company.
* On the following page, click **"Registerinformationen anzeigen."**
* On the next page, click **"AD"** for a summary of the company's current details ("AD" stands for *aktueller Abdruck*, i.e. "current extract"). For companies with names ending in "KG," this will include ownership information. For other companies, it won't.
* Instead of "AD," you can also click on **"DK"** in order to access specific filings. In the "DK" page, you'll see a "tree" of options with drop‑down lists:
  * **"Dokumente zur Registernummer"** contains all documents filed while the company has been registered in its current location. If the company has ever been registered in other towns/districts, there will be options for **"übernommene Dokumente"** from previous district courts, i.e. filings submitted while at the old locations.
  * The most commonly needed documents from the "DK" view are **shareholder lists** (only available for GmbH companies). A new list is entered whenever there's a change to the shareholder structure. Click on **"Liste der Gesellschafter"** and then choose the document with the most recent date to see the current owners (if there are any without dates, choose those too, in case they're the most recent). The actual document should be self‑explanatory and clearly dated. By downloading all the lists (including from **"übernommene Dokumente,"** where relevant), you can see the full ownership history.
  * From the "DK" view you can also access the company's past and current statutes or articles of association under **"Gesellschaftsvertrag / Satzung / Statut,"** as well as other corporate filings that aren't so commonly needed.
* Whether getting a current registry extract ("AD") or specific individual filings ("DK"), unternehmensregister.de works by adding the documents to your **"Dokumentenkorb"** ("document basket"). Where given the option, it's best to choose PDF or TIF format rather than ZIP. Add something to the basket by clicking on **"In den Dokumentenkorb legen."** To actually download the document, you then have to click through several pages: **"Dokumentenkorb ansehen,"** then **"Zur Freischaltung,"** then **"Jetzt freischalten,"** then **"Zum Dokumentenkorb,"** then finally click on the download icon next to each document in your basket.

For cross‑checks, you can also consult the **Common Register Portal** of the German Federal States (Handelsregister), which aggregates data from individual state registries. The European Commission's e‑Justice portal provides an English‑language overview of the German business register and links to the official register.

===Searching for an Individual's Affiliations===

If you want to identify an individual's corporate affiliations, you can search [https://companyhouse.de] by individuals' names (at least if you're logged in with Sastre's account). Individuals' pages on companyhouse.de list all past and current affiliations as a director (**Geschäftsführer**) or **Prokurist** (authorised signatory), as well as their date of birth and (most recent) place of residence. Ownership relationships aren't usually listed (though occasionally they are, especially for KG companies). The date of birth listed on companyhouse.de is reliable, but the dates of affiliations are very unreliable, so affiliations should ideally be confirmed on unternehmensregister.de as outlined above if you're going to mention them in a report. There's no simple way to search for companies that a person owns; the best approach is to use unternehmensregister.de to check the ownership of any companies where the subject is a director or where you have other reasons to suspect a connection.

===Company Finances===

Official annual financial statements (called *Jahresabschlüsse*) are available from both [https://companyhouse.de] and [https://www.unternehmensregister.de]. In terms of the statements' contents, both websites are equally reliable—if one website doesn't have a particular year, check the other. On companyhouse.de, go to the **"Jahresabschlüsse"** tab on a company's page and choose the statement you want to see. If you're logged into Sastre's account, they should be free to view. On unternehmensregister.de, search a company's name in the **"Schnellsuche"** field. On the results page, for companies that have statements available, each statement is listed beneath the company name (e.g., **"Jahresabschluss zum Geschäftsjahr vom 01.01.2010 bis zum 31.12.2010"** for the 2010 report). For older documents or those filed with state registers, you might need to use the **Common Register Portal** or state‑specific archives.

===Miscellaneous Notes===

* Ownership information isn't usually available for AG companies, unless they publish it themselves on their website or in their annual reports.
* There's no good way to search for a given company's subsidiaries or shareholdings, but these are sometimes listed in *Jahresabschlüsse*.
* **Geschäftsführer** is best translated as "director" and **Prokurist** as "authorised signatory."
* Regardless of which websites you use to access German corporate records, it's best to cite them as "German corporate records" or similar in your footnotes. Don't link directly to companyhouse.de, which is a third‑party aggregator.

===Additional Corporate Registry Resources===

* [https://id.occrp.org/databases/#germany OCCRP ID Database for Germany] (''pub'')
* [https://www.handelsregister.de/rp_web/mask.do?Typ=e Common Register Portal of the] German Federal States (''pub'')
* [https://www.firmen-in-berlin.com/sites/fitber/welcome.aspx Companies in Berlin - Business] Database of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) Berlin (''pub'')
* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?GERMANY&member=1 European Commission e‑Justice Overview of] German business registers (''pub'')
* [https://www.deutsche-boerse-cash-market.com/dbcm-de/instrumente-statistiken/statistiken/gelistete-unternehmen Frankfurt Stock Exchange listed companies] (''pub'')
* [http://www.dihk.de/ihk-finder IHK‑Finder - German Chamber of] Commerce directory (''pub'')
* [https://www.unternehmensregister.de/ureg/?submitaction=language&language=en The German Company Registry (Unternehmensregister)] (''pub'')
* [https://www.bundesanzeiger.de/ebanzwww/wexsservlet Bundesanzeiger - German Federal Gazette] (''pub'')
* [https://www.companyhouse.de/ Companyhouse - third-party corporate registry] service (''paid'')
* [https://www.transparenzregister.de/treg/de/start?1 Transparency Register (UBO register)] (''pub'', ''reg'') – the official register of beneficial owners; access requires registration.

litigation.wiki_content:
[https://domstol.fe1.tangora.com/New-S%C3%B8geside.31488.aspx Supreme Court]

The Supreme Court publishes decisions online, allowing search by date, topic and keyword. However, all personal and company names are anonymised.

In Denmark, only the Supreme Court publishes judgements online; while a database of case law exists, it is not publicly available. However, a March 2020 article stated that ""The Court Administration is currently preparing public access to court decisions in all civil cases and expects it to be accessible in 2021."" (https://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Denmark1.html)"

[https://www.karnovgroup.dk/loesninger/ugeskrift-for-retsvaesen Karnov Group]	

Selected case law is published in a weekly journal, collated online by private company Karnov Group and accessible only through a subscription service, which offers all Supreme Court decisions and "principal judgments and decisions of the High Courts and the Maritime and Commercial Court"

[Denmark Supreme Court - Greenland	"http://www.supremecourt.dk/supremecourt/Pages/default.aspx]

[http://domstol.fe1.tangora.com/New-S%C3%B8geside.31488.aspx Supreme Court Database]

Supreme Court Database includes searches from May 2008 onwards. The Supreme Court is the court of final instance in all civil and criminal cases in Denmark, as well as for other jurisdictions in the Kingdom of Denmark, including Greenland. Searching this site can identify case lists that include case parties and case description. Note that these lists are only available for 1 month previous to the current date. Lists are available for at least 6 months in the future.
Denmark Supreme Court	"Step 1: Search the [http://domstol.fe1.tangora.com/New-S%C3%B8geside.31488.aspx Supreme Court Database] of cases from 2009 onwards 

Step 2: Search the actual [http://www.domstol.dk/om/otherlanguages/english/thedanishjudicialsystem/thesupremecourt/Pages/default.asp Supreme Court website] 

The site does not appear to have a comprehensive case search function. Conduct an internal and site search in Danish and English.
This is Denmark's highest court for all civil and criminal matters. The Supreme Court reviews Judgments and orders delivered by the High Court of Eastern Denmark, the High Court of Western Denmark and the Copenhagen Maritime and Commercial Court.​This website will contain limited but important case detais, such as identifying the plaintiff and defendant and a limited description of the case/nature of suit."

[http://domstol.fe1.tangora.com/page13990.aspx?doshow13990=1&filterfromcontrol139901=&filtertocontrol139901=&filtercontrol139902_1=0&filtercontrol139902_2=0&filtercontrol139902_3=0&filtercontrol139902_4=0&filtercontrol139902_5=0&searchword13990=gmbh Danish Maritime and Commercial Court]

The site has a keyword search to allow you to search party. You can also receive judgement texts.​ The court oversees lawsuits related to commercial and maritime law.

[http://ec.europa.eu/competition/elojade/isef/index.cfm EU Competition Commission]	

Conduct internal case search using the provided fields as well as a site search. This is a anti-trust, competition, cartel commission for the EU.
Law Gazette	https://www.lovtidende.dk/	N/A	"The official Gazette of Denmark publishes info on Danish laws in general. Searching the various publications on the site, using the internal search fields, could yield information on your subject if the relevant law/announcement applies to them.
Also conduct site search in Danish and English.

[https://domsdatabasen.dk/ Courts Agency database of civil and selected criminal judgements]

Denmark has a civil law system with a judicial review of legislative acts. Additionally it accepts compulsory International Court of Justice jurisdiction with reservations. The highest Danish court is the Supreme Court, consisting out of 18 judges and the court president. The Danish supreme courts accepts cases from the Maritime and Commercial Court and the High Court (Court of Appeals). In turn, the High Court accepts cases from the county courts. Furthermore, the Danish Constitution provides for the Court of Impeachment of the Realm (Rigsretten) to hear cases brought against ministers concerning their administration. In addition, the Special Court of Final Appeal (Den særlige Klageret) deals with cases concerning disciplinary sanctions against judges and petitions for retrial of criminal cases under Article 86 of the Administration of Justice Act.

Court Structure:

- Supreme Court

- High Court

- Maritime and Commercial Court

- Special Court of Indictment and Revision

- Land Registration Court

- Greenland Courts

- Faroe Island Courts

- County Court

The Egyptian International Trade Point is an online directory and database run by the Ministry ofTrade & Industry. Search for the company name in either English or Arabic to return information on traded products and company details. 

[www.ClarifiedBy.com ClarifiedBy.com / Diligencia Company Name Search - Arabic / Farsi]

ClarifiedBy.com is the leading online source of company information for the Middle East & NorthAfrica, brought to you by Diligencia. Our company and individual profiles are based solely on official sources of information in the region, are available in both Arabic / Farsi and English, and have been curated by our team of analysts to ensure the information is accessible and easy to navigate. Trusted by consultancies, banks, and corporates, our mission is to provide clients with a clear view of the facts and a solid foundation for their decision-making. Where you see the ClarifiedBy asterisk, a universal sign used to point readers to an explanation of detail or a source, you can be assured that the information provided is reliable and accurate. 

[www.ClarifiedBy.com ClarifiedBy.com / Diligencia Company Name Search - English]	

ClarifiedBy.com is the leading online source of company information for the Middle East & NorthAfrica, brought to you by Diligencia. Our company and individual profiles are based solely on official sources of information in the region, are available in both Arabic / Farsi and English, and have been curated by our team of analysts to ensure the information is accessible and easy to navigate. Trusted by consultancies, banks, and corporates, our mission is to provide clients with a clear view of the facts and a solid foundation for their decision-making. Where you see the ClarifiedBy asterisk, a universal sign used to point readers to an explanation of detail or a source, you can be assured that the information provided is reliable and accurate. 

[http://www.egx.com.eg/English/ListedStocks.aspx The Egyptian Exchange]

Information on listed stocks, bonds, mutual funds and ETFs.

We need to engage a third-party provider in Egypt to obtain the most up-to-date available corporate filings. There are currently 2-3 options for providers. They will get you corporate incorporation info; directors; and ownership. The only exception is for Law 8 companies, for which ownership is not required to be disclosed to third-parties.	

The primary sources of corporate information in Egypt are: the Ministry of Trade and Investment (MTI) and the General Authority on Investment and Free Zones (GAFI).
	
There are also third-party corporate databases that can be searched to obtain aggregated information on companies in Egypt. One of them is an online specialised MENA database for which we have a subscription. The other is Mubasher Web Site, an aggregator of data about publicly traded MENA companies. The data comes from the respective MENA stock exchanges where the company is listed. This is searchable in English and Arabic. It will disclose known owners, directors, and subsidiaries, and basic corporate incorporation information.	
The state organisation Misr for Clearing, Settlement and Central Depository, which is the clearing house for Egyptian securities, sometimes provides profiles of Egyptian companies, but the website and the information is by no means wholly reliable. The website is not always functional and the information is sometimes outdated. A "site: search" is the best means to see if there is any information on the company in question.	

Finally, we have a subscription to a MENA corporate database through which you can also search for information on Egypt based companies on their archive at no additional cost. The report on the company from the archive is not always timestamped so it is not always evident when the company information was last updated.	

Directorships	

Directorship searches can be conducted through a MENA corporate database for which we have a subscription, by searching their online archive. Alternatively, you may engage the third-party provider of the MENA corporate database subscription to run a new check on the person's corporate interests to ensure you have the most up-to-date information. The report supplied will disclose directorships and shareholdings; percentage of shares will not be disclosed.	

Nexis Power Search - ClarifiedBy Extension

Begin research with searches of the ClarifiedBy extension of Nexis Power Search. In addition to determining if a subject has a ClarifiedBy profile, it can provide additional useful information even if the subject doesn't have a profile, such as Arabic or English spelling, affiliations, and other identifiers

Conduct an internal and site search in both Arabic and English.

This website could provide additional and useful information on your company subject.

[https://www.amcham.org.eg/ American Chamber of Commerce in Egypt]

COMPANIES AND DIRECTOR SUBJECTS 

Conduct a search of the Member Database (companies and individuals) and conduct a site search

litigation.wiki_content:
Egypt Court System  

Overview of the Egyptian Court System 

Supreme Constitutional Court 

The Supreme Constitutional Court is the highest judicial power. It alone undertakes the judicial control in respect of the constitutionality of the laws and regulations, and shall undertake the interpretation of the legislative texts in the manner prescribed by law. In addition, the court is empowered to settle competence disputes between the judicial and the administrative courts. 

Court of Cassation (Maḥkamet El Naqḍ) 

The Court of Cassation includes consideration of challenges brought to it by either party or by the public prosecution office. It also includes examining lawsuits related to judges' actions. In such a case, the court undertakes its role as a court of merit, rather than a court of law. It also has the power to give rulings on requests of reparations for all violated verdicts. The court issues annual collections on approved judicial principles under the title "Rulings and Principles of The Court of Cassation". 

Court of Appeal 

Courts of Appeal, some which are called Higher Courts of Appeal, have the competence to consider rulings by the courts of first instance falling under its jurisdiction, should these rulings be liable for appeal. According to the Egyptian judiciary law, there are seven courts of appeal in Egypt; in Cairo, Alexandria, Tanta, Mansoura, Ismailia, Beni Swaif and Assuit. 

Court of First Instance 

These courts of first instance have the competence to consider lawsuits filed before them as may fall under their jurisdictions, and their rulings can be subject to appeal. 

Courts of Limited Jurisdiction 

These courts have the competence to issue rulings on lawsuits of limited importance, falling under their geographical and term jurisdictions; their rulings can also be subject to appeal. 

Family Court 

Family courts provide a specialized judiciary tool that would take cognizance of such cases in an atmosphere different from that of other lawsuits. This aims to secure psychological peace for children who may be involved, especially in such cases of tutelage, divorce, alimony, custody, etc. The ultimate objective of this court is to negotiate an amicable settlement of family problems through specialized guidance bureaus. 

[https://www.cc.gov.eg/civil_appeals_services Egyptian Court of Cassation] 

The website has Arabic search for Civil and Criminal appeal cases by case number.  
 
[https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/search/ Global Legal Monitor - Egypt] 

[http://www.worldlii.org/catalog/2669.html WorldLII] 

A third-party must be engaged to manually search courts in Egypt to obtain copies of litigation records or summaries of the litigation. The cost is £950 per governorate per subject. Turnaround is 10-12 working days.  

There is no reliable online searchable database for litigation records in Egypt.  

My suggested approach is - assuming there is a HUMINT component to the case - running enquiries and seeing if litigation emerges, and then deciding on whether to engage the third party provider for the court checks.

As of July 2025, this website offered 5 free basic company reports in return for a free sign-up. Even if paid for, the basic report was EUR 6, compared to EUR 9 with the official registry (which is harder to sign up for, see below). Einforma's reports offer all background information on a company (including directors and owners, with a reverse search available but also paid for), alongside basic financial overviews (full annual reports are available for EUR 11.50) and filings (summary free, full version EUR 4). * [https://www.rmc.es Company registry for Spain with] administrator search capability (''pub'', ''paid'', ''reg'')

As of July 2025, it was no longer possible to purchase company information through this website without a log-in as previously. This makes the official source the [https://sede.registradores.org/sede/sede-corpme-web/home?lang=en ''Registradores de Espana''] site listed above. While the official source in Spain, this website requires sign-up either through a Spanish e-gov profile, or via application including provision of an ID document scan. Pascal completed this in July 2025, but found that the next step in signing up is an up-front payment for site credit of EUR 150. Without having seen a ''Registradores'' report, Einforma (above) seems like a better value proposition, since reports are a bit cheaper and information seems better laid out.

* [https://sede.registradores.org/site/mercantil?lang=en_EN Spanish Business Register by Association] of Registrars (''pub'')

* [https://boe.es/buscar/ State Agency for the State] Official Journal with corporate filings (''pub'')

litigation.wiki_content:
Searches of litigation records from the Spanish Supreme Court (Tribunal Supremo de Justicia), the Audiencia Nacional (a special criminal/administrative law court based in Madrid) and manual searches of the regional supreme courts of Spain's autonomous regions and cities[1] (Tribunales Superiores de Justicia y Unipersonales) identified no references to ***.
 
These are: Andalucía; Aragón; Principado de Asturias; Baleares; Canarias; Cantabria; Castilla-La Mancha; Castilla y León; Cataluña; Extremadura; Galicia; La Rioja; Comunidad de Madrid; Región de Murcia, Comunidad Foral de Navarra; País Vasco; Comunidad Valenciana; Ceuta and Melilla.

Spain follows a civil law legal system, derived from Roman law, which relies on comprehensive legal codes rather than case law. Unlike common law systems, judicial decisions do not have a binding precedent, but they may still influence future rulings. Legal outcomes and the interpretation of codes rely heavily on strict adherence to statutory law and legal scholarship. Searchable legal databases in Spain include multiple resources that encompass various levels of courts and tribunals. These databases provide access to judicial decisions, although the focus is primarily on statutory law.

'''[http://www.poderjudicial.es Consejo General del Poder Judicial]''' This body supervises the judiciary and maintains records of judicial decisions made across Spain. It plays a crucial role in the judiciary's administration and provides significant transparency in judicial proceedings. Search Tip: Use the site's internal search bar to find judgments and related records. Searchable by keyword (company name), but the only other search tools relate to court data. Searchable by keyword only. Searchable by keyword only.

'''[https://www.cnmc.es Comisión Nacional de los Mercados y la Competencia]''' This commission deals with cases related to market regulation and competition law in Spain. Their database includes rulings and sanctions related to competitive practices. Search Tip: For litigation related to market competition, utilize the search functionality within the website.

'''[https://www.boe.es BOE (Boletín Oficial del Estado)]''' The official state gazette publishes all legislative, regulatory, and legal announcements, including court judgments. It serves as an essential resource for understanding statutory law and regulatory updates. Search Tip: Use keyword searches relevant to the case or statutes you are interested in.

* [http://www.poderjudicial.es/search/indexAN.jsp Portal for judicial information in] Spain (''pub'')

* [https://www.poderjudicial.es/search/indexAN.jsp National high courts and provincial] courts case law database (''pub'')

litigation.wiki_content:
'''[https://www.finlex.fi/fi/oikeus/ Finlex]''' (''pub'')

The Finlex database provides details on cases of the follow courts:

-- '''Supreme Court''' 

Contents:
Decisions published in the yearbook of the Supreme Court as complete text of decisions since the beginning of 1980, as well as indexes of decisions of the Supreme Court from 1926-1979.

Search methods:
folder search: you can search for a legal case from annual folders (according to the year of publication of the legal case)
direct search: you can search directly with the legal case number above the annual folders, e.g. KKO:2004:21
keyword search: you can search from the alphabetical list of keywords, e.g. with the term Free trial
application forms: quick search and advanced search

-- '''Supreme Administrative Court'''

Contents:
Summaries of decisions of the Supreme Administrative Court since 1944 and complete texts of decisions published in the yearbook since 1999. Short solution notes from 1946.

Quick search
Search from legal case text, e.g. home peace* and basic law* . *. Broad search, e.g. problem areas* or landfill* . Search by law, e.g. Section 191 of the Land Use and Construction Act . Search with a term in quotation marks, e.g. "children's interest" . Search by yearbook number, e.g. KHO:2002:23 ; solutions issued in 1987-1996, e.g. KKO:1983-II-50 . Decisions issued before 1987, e.g. KHO:1984-A-II-85 or KHO:1985-B-II-520 . Search word as Break character *.

Solutions without a yearbook number are searched for by selecting advanced search and then search by volume number.

Advanced Search
Search with reference information
Examples of diary numbers: 3316/3/02 , 2023/3/97 .
The date of issue is given in the form DD.MM.YYYY (e.g. 1.1.2003 ) or YYYY (e.g. 2003 ).
Subject word, e.g. car tax
Diary number, e.g.: 3316/3/02
Date of issue, e.g.: 7.7.2004
Volume, e.g.: 1653
Summary, e.g. severe disability*
Date of issue, e.g. 1.9.2004-30.11.2004 . Limitation to years e.g. 2002-2003 .

Search from text
In the text search, you can search simultaneously with e.g. a search word and a phrase. Search words are separated from each other with a space, the word break character *. The without words condition cannot be used alone, but must be combined with other search conditions.

With all words (and condition), e.g. parking fee* value added tax*
With any of the words (or condition), e.g. beach master plan* summer outfit*
With an exact phrase, e.g. good manners
Without words (no condition), e.g. nature preserve*

''The Supreme Administrative Court - other decisions''

Contents:
In the Other decisions group, individual decisions assessed as having social, regional or other general interest are published, which have not been published as yearbook reports or short decision reports based on the legal significance of the decision. There are other decisions from October 2013.

Quick search
The quick search on the legal practice page does not apply to other decisions. If you want the search to also focus on other decisions, perform the search as a refined search by also selecting other decisions in the search selection.

-- '''Court of Appeal'''

Contents:
The rights of appeal database contains legal cases of the rights of appeal since 1964. The legal case report contains a summary of the decision, legal force information and references to regulations, legal cases and literature. There are currently about 2,100 abbreviated judgments of Courts of Appeal, since June 2004 there are also long texts of judgments.

Quick search
The search targets the legal case text. Search from the text, e.g. children* and meeting* . Search with case number, e.g. I-SHO:2004:2 . *. Search by law, e.g. YSL § 2 . Search word as Break character *.

Advanced Search
The date of issue is given in the form DD.MM.YYYY (e.g. 1.1.2003 ) or YYYY (e.g. 2003 ).
Issue year, e.g. 2004
Court of Appeal, e.g. Turku Court of Appeal
Diary number, e.g.: H 04/760
Decision number (volume), e.g. 966
Subject word, e.g. violation of domestic peace
Case number, e.g. VaaHO:2003:5
Date of issue, e.g.: 01.06.2004 - 31.10. .2004 . Limitation to years e.g. 2002-2003.

-- '''Administrative right solutions'''

Contents:
Since 1979, the administrative law database contains decision summaries of administrative law and previous county law decisions, which briefly explain the legal issue, the facts, the decisions of the lower courts and the decision of the administrative law. There are also references to KHO's decisions and literature. The database also contains water court decisions from 1988-1998. There are currently around 2,100 administrative rights decision abbreviations.

Quick search
The search focuses on the legal case text. Search from the text, e.g. election* and sananvap* . Search by legal section, e.g. Act on the Publicity of Authorities' Activities Section 11 . Search word as Break character *.

Advanced Search
The date of issue is given in the form DD.MM.YYYY (e.g. 1.1.2003 ) or YYYY (e.g. 2003 ).
Year of issue, e.g. 2004
Court, e.g. Administrative Court of Turku
Diary number, e.g.: 02163/03/5300
Decision number (volume), e.g.: 03/0837/2
Subject word, e.g. environmental permit
Date of issue, e.g.: 01.06.2004 - 31.10.2004 . Limitation to years e.g. 2002-2003 .

Search from text
In the text search, you can search simultaneously with e.g. a search word and a phrase. Search words are separated from each other with a space, the word break character *. The without words condition cannot be used alone, but must be combined with other search conditions.

With all words (and-condition), e.g. environment* troublemakers*
With any of the words (or-condition), e.g. mental health* psychiatrist*
With an exact phrase, e.g. precautionary principle
Without words (non-condition), e.g. capital income*

-- '''Market Court''' 

- All Market Court decisions since 1979.

Contents:
Market law decisions and statements are stored in the market law database. The solutions concern three sets of cases: 1) Market law matters, 2) Anti-competitive matters 3) Matters concerning public procurement. The database also includes the entire ruling practice of the market court that preceded market law from 1979-2002.

Quick search
Search from solution text, e.g. language school* and hankin* . Search with solution number, e.g. MAO:118/03 . Search by keyword, e.g. product imitation . Limiting the search to antitrust issues, e.g. /KR and market position* . Limiting the search to market law matters, e.g. (/M1 or /M2 or M3) and imitation* . Limitation of the search to procurement matters, e.g. /JH and tender value* . Search word as Break character *.

-- '''Labour Court''' 

- All Labour Court decisions since 1970. New solutions are saved in the database at least once a month. 
Search methods:
1) folder search: you can search for a legal case from annual folders (according to the year of publication of the legal case)
2) direct search: you can search directly with the legal case number above the annual folders, e.g. TT:2003-13
3) keyword search: you can search from the alphabetical list of keywords, e.g. with the word Sickness pay
4) application forms: quick search and advanced search

* [https://www.finlex.fi/en/oikeus/foki/ Finlex - Case Law Search] across multiple courts (''pub'')

* [https://oikeus.fi/ Judiciary website]  (''pub'')

* [http://www.korkeinoikeus.fi/en Finland Supreme Court website]  (''pub'')

* [https://ec.europa.eu/competition/elojade/isef/index.cfm European Competition Commission case search]  (''pub'')

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
Various sources of corporate records are available in France. The sections below describe official sources first, but please note that the last source is the best "one-stop shop" for French entities.

===National Enterprise Register===

'''[https://data.inpi.fr/ Data INPI]'''

From 2023, France's National Enterprise Register has become accessible through the National Institute of Industrial Property website. The search engine supports search by company name, number (SIREN) and other characteristics. A search by director name (click "advanced search" from the homepage, and enter director name in "Representatives" below) exists on the site, but as of November 2024 was not working. Company pages on the Enterprise Register give basic information, including those listed below. Directors, other principals (e.g. secretaries, auditors) and UBOs (where disclosed as required) are identified, with the DOBs of directors and UBOs given.

*name
*corporate ID
*activity
*entity type
*share capital
*wholly-owned (Y/N)
*branch registrations
*date of registration with its current commercial court. 

Note: the company's date of ''registration'' may not be its date of ''incorporation'' - look for a date of activity commencement, or historical filings, to check. 

A second tab of the company's registry page ("Associated Documents") shows PDFs of original corporate filings, which are an invaluable source of more detailed information than the basic summary (for example, a company statute might contain a full ownership breakdown, as well as biographical details about directors/shareholders). This tab can be viewed free of charge, but you need to log in (make a free account or ask Pascal for his login details). However, the filing display function is temperamental.

===Commercial Court Registry Database===

'''[https://www.infogreffe.fr/ Infogreffe]'''

The older corporate database, maintained by the Commercial Court Registries. Compared to the National Enterprise Register, Infogreffe only offers corporate filings for a fee. However, it does offer the KBIS Extract product (for a fee), which as of July 2023, provided company directors' full DOBs and addresses (compared to the National Register, which gives only mm/yyyy and municipality of residence). Additionally, Infogreffe provides a useful directorship search (current and historical) which may be searched by name and DOB. You can also simply click on one company's director to access a list of all their directorships (not possible on National Register).

Various company details are available for free, including those listed below. A UBO declaration may be downloaded for free. Directors and other principals are listed.

*address
*trade name
*legal form
*last year's turnover (where declared)
*activity
*branch registrations
*date of registration at current Commercial Court. 
Note: the company's date of registration may not be its date of ''incorporation'' - look at historical filings (Acts and Statutes section on the company's registry page) to check. 

Further detailed documents may be obtained for a fee. The most useful of these are the KBIS current extract ("KBIS"), individual filings ("Acts and Statutes") and annual accounts. Please note that individual historical filings are likely to be available elsewhere for free (see above and below). Less useful are documents on the company's debt status (expensive), bankruptcy status (available elsewhere for free), and legal position (frequently not available).

===Commercial Gazette Records===

'''[https://www.bodacc.fr/pages/annonces-commerciales/?sort=dateparution BODACC]'''

The Official Bulletin of Civil and Commercial Announcements (BODACC) is part of France's Official Journal, and regularly publishes announcements which companies are required to make on changes made - though these are very brief. It may be searched by company name or ID (SIREN), and also by keyword, which can identify directors.

===Free Corporate Filings===

'''[https://entreprises.lefigaro.fr/ Le Figaro Entreprises]'''

This database provides basic identity data on companies and, if available, a table presenting details from their most recent accounts, which may also be downloaded. Further down the company page, a list of the company's corporate announcements as published in BODACC is given (usually not further back than approximately 2008, however, so do check BODACC too). Beyond the corporate announcements, the database lists the company's corporate filings and makes them available for free download. These are the same filings available from Infogreffe for a fee, and from the National Enterprise Register (sometimes).

Unlike the other French corporate records sources, Le Figaro Entreprises is also receptive to Google site searches, which can help identify directors alongside the other methods above.

A further, but rarely-seen, key advantage of Le Figaro Entreprises is that it sources official announcements on companies from the ''infolegale'' service (subscription otherwise required), which collects data on companies from a variety of sources - not just the BODACC and the company's own filings. These announcements can include useful information - for example information on fines applied to companies (see the October 2024 announcement in '''[https://entreprises.lefigaro.fr/lm-wind-power-blades-france-50/entreprise-797671195 this]''' example). Le Figaro Entreprises is therefore the best one-stop shop for French entities.

===Associations and Foundations===

'''[https://www.journal-officiel.gouv.fr/pages/associations-recherche/?sort=cronosort&disjunctive.source Official Journal]'''

The Official Journal publishes announcements by associations and foundations (charities).

===Note on identifying ownership===

This is complex in France. Always check a public company's accounts first to save time.

French companies declare changes in ownership in individual filings to the corporate registries. These filings are available through the '''National Enterprise Register''' (purportedly), '''Infogreffe''' (for a fee) and '''Figaro Entreprises''' (overall best option). Scrolling down the list of filings, look for ones described as a change to share capital. Typically, these will consist of notes on a company shareholder meeting detailing the change, and then updated company statutes. If you are (very) lucky, the meeting notes will give an ownership breakdown. However, it is more likely that the change in share capital (and new/departing owners) will be described, but without a description of the status quo pre-change. You will need to work backwards (and often, forwards from the founding statutes) to identify this. If your subject is described as having a sole shareholder, immediately move on to checking the sole shareholder's filings to identify ownership.

===Directorships===

All of the official corporate records sources listed above may be searched for an individual's ''current'' directorships, as described below. However, third-party aggregator '''[https://www.societe.com/ Société]''' is a good source of information on historic directorships. Limited information on companies is available on the website without a subscription, however, so it is best used only to identify corporate affiliations.

*'''[https://www.infogreffe.fr/ Infogreffe]''' - search by name, surname and mm/yyyy of birth through the Advanced Search
*'''[https://data.inpi.fr/ Data INPI]''' - search by name, surname through the Advanced Search
*'''[https://www.bodacc.fr/pages/annonces-commerciales/?sort=dateparution BODACC]''' - search director's "[surname, name]" as a keyword
*'''[https://entreprises.lefigaro.fr/ Le Figaro Entreprises]''' - No internal search, but director names may be searched by external site search (search director's "[surname, name]"), which should also identify historic directorships.
*'''[https://www.sirene.fr/sirene/public/recherche Sirene]''' - Provides a surname/name search for directors and sole partnerships.

Note that while a register of disqualified directors (''Fichier National des Interdits de Gérer'') exists in France, maintained by the National Council of Commercial Court Clerks, it is not publicly accessible [https://www.cngtc.fr/fr/fnig.html source].

===Additional Corporate Resources===

* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?FRANCE&member=1 European Commission's overview of publicly] available business information in France (''pub'')
* [http://www.societe.com/ Societe - Third-party company information] website
* [http://www.journal-officiel.gouv.fr/balo Bulletin of Obligatory Legal Announcements] (''pub'')

litigation.wiki_content:
French litigation records are not systematically published, and names of individual parties are widely anonymised. Criminal cases are least publicised of all, but cases of public interest may be covered in the press.

The courts in France are divided into two parts - the judicial courts (those dealing with criminal and civil laws), and the administrative courts. Public law is applied in the administrative courts (''tribunaux administratifs''). Labour law is applied at labour courts known as ''conseils des prud'hommes''. The highest of the judiciary courts is the ''Cour de cassation'' (Supreme Court of Appeals). There are 36 courts of appeal, 161 ''tribunaux de grande instance'', and 307 ''tribunaux d'instance'' (the lowest level). At the top of the administrative courts rests the ''Conseil d'Etat'' (Council of State), with 8 courts of appeal (''cours administratives d'appel'') and 42 ''tribunaux administratifs''. 

'''Disclaimer Text'''

''Litigation records in France include civil, administrative, commercial, labour, and criminal litigation filings for the civil and administrative supreme courts (Cour de Cassation and Conseil d'Etat), the 36 local courts of appeal (Cours d'Appel and Cours d'Appel Administrative), the constitutional court (Conseil Constitutionnel), the competition court (Autorité de la Concurrence), the labour courts (Conseil des Prud'hommes), local civil and administrative high courts. Not all litigation records are available in France and names of individuals are almost systematically anonymized.''

===Civil Litigation===

'''[https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/ Legifrance]'''

France's central legal database contains selected judicial judgements alongside laws and government acts. Search by subject name, although individual parties to cases will be anonymised into initials. It is possible to narrow down using ''expression exacte'' and add name variations with ''associer une autre expression'' to help narrow down results.

'''[https://juricaf.org/recherche/+/facet_pays:France Juricaf]'''

Juricaf is a database of French judgements (and worldwide Francophone Supreme Court judgements) maintained by the Ministry of Justice. For France, it mainly publishes appeal cases from the Court of Cassation, Administrative Court of Appeal and regional courts of appeal, alongside Constitutional Court and State Council administrative judgements, and scattered first-instance judgements. Individual party names are anonymised as initials.

'''[https://www.courdecassation.fr/acces-rapide-judilibre Court of Cassation]'''

France's supreme court of appeal maintains a database of anonymised appeals judgements. The website supports a Google site search, which is useful for a more precise name search.

====Private Databases====

Alongside the official sources listed above, private, paid databases are likely to have additional judgements, if budget permits. The best are:

*'''[https://www.doctrine.fr/ Doctrine]'''
*'''[https://juripredis.com/ Juri'Predis]'''
*'''[https://www.lexbase.fr/rechercher-une-jurisprudence Lexbase]'''

===Administrative Litigation===

'''[https://www.conseil-etat.fr/decisions-de-justice/jurisprudence/rechercher-une-decision-arianeweb Council of State]'''

France's supreme administrative court maintains a database of its own selected judgements and selected appeals judgements. When searching this database for any name, untick the spell check option (''correction orthographique'') as this is quite zealous. The operators ET (and), OU (or) and SAUF (except) are available, and * may be inserted as wild characters.

===Criminal Record Check===

Criminal record checks on individuals in France may only be requested by the request's subject. If one has been provided for a project, verify it using the '''[https://casier-judiciaire.justice.gouv.fr/mai-web-b3-presentation/pages/validationB3Neant/accueil.xhtml?nocid=true Criminal Records]''' site.

===Insolvency & Debt===

Corporate insolvencies are indicated by the official corporate records databases:

*'''[https://www.infogreffe.fr/ Infogreffe]'''
*'''[https://data.inpi.fr/ Data INPI]'''

Individual insolvencies may be checked for using the Official Journal's '''[https://compte.bodacc.fr/pages/annonces-retablissement-personnel/ database]''' of Personal Recoveries. Make sure to select a region of residence for the subject, which is mandatory (it is possible to search all insolvencies by region, but not nationwide).

===Additional Litigation Resources===

* [http://www.juricaf.org Database of case law in] French across French speaking world (''pub'')
* [https://www.courdecassation.fr/service_ligne_commander_arrets_12007.html Online service to order judgements] by the Court of Cassation (''pub'', ''reg'', ''paid'')
* [http://www.autoritedelaconcurrence.fr/user/index.php French Competition Authority decisions database] (''pub'')
* [https://www.lexbase.fr/login Paid database for judgements by] French courts (''paid'', ''reg'')

litigation.wiki_content:
===Disclaimer=== We searched litigation records in the UK, including reported and unreported cases heard by the High Court, the Court of Appeal—covering civil and criminal litigation—and the Supreme Court. We note that not all litigation records are made publicly available or are accessible online and therefore these searches should not be considered comprehensive. Further, criminal records are not a matter of public record in the UK. We found no records for cases of which *** has been party to. ===Legal System=== The UK, with the exception of Scotland, has a common law legal system. Judges look to past, relevant precedential decisions and apply their principals to the legal questions before them. If a similar dispute has been resolved in the past, the court is usually bound to follow the reasoning used in the prior decision. Written opinions for precedent-setting decisions are published online as they are of significance and interest to the general public and legal practitioners alike. Case briefs mainly serve to show how a legal decision was arrived at, which requires, to some extent, recounting the circumstances of the underlying dispute. Personal data may be published in judgments, the GDPR notwithstanding. Court records for cases that are neither precedent-setting nor of public importance are not publicly available. The most comprehensive, online UK case law databases are maintained by the UK Judiciary website, the Scottish Courts & Tribunals website, and the British and Irish Legal Information Institute. These databases include decisions from all UK courts and specialty tribunals. The databases search allow for all courts to be searched at once, making knowledge of the subject's address history unessential. corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://find-and-update.company-information.service.gov.uk Companies House] (''pub'') Companies House is the United Kingdom's registrar of companies and is an executive agency and trading fund of Her Majesty's Government, falling under the remit of the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy. All forms of companies (as permitted by the United Kingdom Companies Act) are incorporated and registered with Companies House and file specific details as required by legislation. Use the search bar to search by company name, number or officer/PSC name. The search results will be organised by tab. To refine your results to companies, click the relevant tab. If searching for disqualified directors, search for their name and then click the 'Disqualifications' tab. Once you click on a company name, you will be brought through to its Overview page. Again, click on the relevant tab to access filings (Filing History), info on officers and PSCs (People), and current and former charges (Charges). In the Filing History tab, you can refind the filings by category by clicking on the relevant box at the top – for example, you can view Accounts, filings relating to officers, etc. NOTE: it's always a good idea to review the filing history in full as well because sometimes the filtered version does not pick up on relevant documents (e.g. filings that were resubmitted due to an error in the original). Company records are retained by Companies House for 20 years after a company is dissolved and stricken off.In response to privacy concerns, and to comply with the GDPR, Companies House will now remove company records from the free online database six years after they are dissolved. Companies House will include registrations, annual reports and other corporate filings, directors, and significant shareholders (25% or more). Companies are also required register incorporation details (including previous names), charges/ mortgages, and insolvency information, and file annual reports (full accounts) and annual confirmation statements (replaced annual return forms in June 2016). For full date of birth, including the day, look for documents submitted before 2016. For '''archived company details and reports''', use [https://data.occrp.org/ OCCRP Aleph] (''civ'') and/or one of the following services: *https://companycheck.co.uk (''priv'') *https://www.duedil.com (''priv'') *https://www.endole.co.uk (''priv'') [https://register-of-charities.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-search Charity Register] (''pub'') You can find out what it does, where it operates, its trustees, and info on income and assets. Additionally, OpenCorporates has composed a comprehensive charity register for the UK that includes over 375,000 registered charities. Around a quarter of the Northern Ireland charities have been linked to UK companies registered at Companies House. The remainder are unincorporated associations, and we are exploring ways to help expose this data for search. ===Ownership=== *generally available :-reverse: in random cases only, on [https://data.occrp.org/ OCCRP Aleph] (''civ'') Information on [https://www.gov.uk/guidance/people-with-significant-control-pscs People with significant control]
Research Guide
'''Ultimate Beneficial Ownership''' Beneficial ownership can be found on Companies House by following the chain of ownership or simply looking at the Persons with Significant Control (PSC). PSCs meet one of the following guidelines: the individual directly or indirectly owns over 25 percent of the company's shares or voting rights, or has the right to appoint or remove the majority of the board of directors. '''Publicly Traded''' You can find ownership information and corporate filings on the LSE and the Companies House websites for publicly traded companies. Public companies must have at least two directors and one secretary registered on Companies House. '''Privately Held''' Companies House will often have shareholder information. Ownership/subsidiaries can also sometimes be found in accounts. In the Filing History section, you will find a list of documents. If there are numerous documents, you can narrow your search by keywords namely Capital, Shares, Annual Return, Confirmation Statement, and Incorporation. You can also narrow your search by selecting the boxes that have these keywords in the Filter by Category subsection. If there are only a few documents, please search all of them. If a company has numerous shareholders and you are unsure on how to report this, first contact your CM to notify him/her that the company's ownership structure is complicated. Secondly, please reach out to more experienced peers or your Performance Manager for assistance. '''Nonprofit''' The Charity Commission in the UK keeps records of Charities in the UK. This website will have corporate filings that sometimes include trustee information.
===Directorship=== * available :- reverse: yes ===Company Types===
''Details''
'''Private Company Limited by Shares''' This is the most common company type. They usually have 'Limited' or 'Ltd' at the end of the company name. The amount for which shareholders are liable in the event that the company is wound up is limited to the face value of their share in the business. (In contrast, a sole trader is liable for all of the company's debts and can have their personal assets seized.) The company cannot sell shares to the general public (like a PLC can). '''Public Limited Company (PLC)''' This type can sell shares to the general public. It must have share capital of GBP 50,000 or more, of which at least 25% must have been paid up before the company can begin trading. Not all PLCs are listed on a stock exchange. The liability of the company is limited to the value of its reserves. '''Private Company Limited by Guarantee''' This type limits the liability of its guarantors to a pre-agreed amount that they have to pay if the company is wound up. Non-profits are often set up like this. There is no share capital or shareholders in this company. Its members/owners are the guarantors. '''Private Unlimited Company''' There is no cap to the amount that its members are required to pay if the company is wound up, so they tend to be used for companies where insolvency is a very low risk. They are not required by law to submit annual accounts to Companies House. This makes unlimited companies attractive to businesses that wish to maintain a level of secrecy about their financial status. '''Limited liability partnership (LLP)''' An LLP is owned by its members who have certain responsibilities, including acting in accordance with the partnership agreement. Its members (partners) are only liable for the amount of money they invest, plus any personal guarantees. There's no restriction on the maximum number of partners allowed but there must be at least two members on incorporation, either individuals or limited companies. They are solely for profit-making businesses. '''Limited partnership (LP)''' This is a business association of one or more 'general partners' alongside one or more 'limited partners'. It is the general partner who is personally liable for the partnership's debts and other obligations. Where there is more than one general partner, they are jointly liable for the partnership's debts. Liability is potentially unlimited, so they may face losing personal assets. Each limited partner's personal liability is capped to the amount of their investment (and any personal guarantees they have given). While their original investment may be lost in paying off partnership debts, the limited partner's personal assets cannot be accessed by creditors. '''Societas Europaea, or SE companies''' These can be established in all European Economic Area. When established in the UK, SEs are a type of public limited company which can be formed as a subsidiary of another company or as a holding company. SE companies can also be created by mergers or from an existing PLC.

[https://use-land-property-data.service.gov.uk HM Land Registry] (''pub'')

The Land Registry holds records of property ownership in England and Wales. Key datasets include:

- **CCOD (UK Companies that Own Property)**: Lists all UK-registered companies that own land/property
- **OCOD (Overseas Companies that Own Property)**: Lists overseas entities owning UK property

- **Price Paid Data**: Historical transaction prices

Search by company name, address, or title number. Note: Individual residential ownership requires paid searches.
