corporate_registry.wiki_content:
===General Company Information (incl. ownership)===

The first site to check for German companies is https://companyhouse.de. Sastre has an account on this site, and logging in makes some small improvements to what you can see. This website's layout is easily navigable, so it's good to check for a general overview. However, it's not 100% reliable, especially for historical information (including establishment date), so any information to be cited in a report should ideally be verified at https://www.unternehmensregister.de (see below). Moreover, companyhouse.de tries to charge extra for certain information, such as shareholder details, which can be obtained for free from unternehmensregister.de. Never buy any filings from companyhouse.de, because the same documents can all be obtained for free from unternehmensregister.de.

Unternehmensregister.de is very tedious to use, but it has lots of great information, all for free. Here's a step-by-step guide to using it for general corporate information (including ownership):
* In the "Schnellsuche" field on the homepage, enter the name of the company you want.
* In the results page, scroll to find the right company and click on "Registerinformationen des Registergerichts" next to its name. Note that sometimes the company you want doesn't appear at the top of the results, even if you entered the exact name, so be careful not to accidentally choose the wrong company.
* On the following page, click "Registerinformationen anzeigen".
* On the following page, click "AD" for a summary of the company's current details ("AD" stands for "aktueller Abdruck", i.e. "current extract"). For companies with names ending in "KG", this will include ownership information. For other companies, it won't.
* Instead of "AD", you can also click on "DK" in order to access specific filings. In the "DK" page, you'll see a "tree" of options with drop-down lists.
** "Dokumente zur Registernummer" contains all documents filed while the company has been registered in its current location. If the company has ever been registered in other towns/districts, there will be options for "übernommene Dokumente" from previous district courts, i.e. filings submitted while at the old locations. 
** The most commonly needed documents from the "DK" view are shareholder lists (which are only available for GmbH companies). A new list is entered whenever there's a change to the shareholder structure. Click on "Liste der Gesellschafter" and then choose the document with the most recent date to see the current owners (if there are any without dates, choose those too, in case they're the most recent). The actual document should be self-explanatory and clearly dated. By downloading all the lists (including from "übernommene Dokumente", where relevant), you can see the full ownership history.
** From the "DK" view you can also access the company's past and current statutes or articles of association under "Gesellschaftsvertrag / Satzung / Statut", as well as other corporate filings that aren't so commonly needed.
* Whether getting a current registry extract ("AD") or specific individual filings ("DK"), unternehmensregister.de works by adding the documents to your "Dokumentenkorb" ("document basket"). Where given the option, it's best to choose PDF or TIF format, rather than ZIP. Add something to the basket by clicking on "In den Dokumentenkorb legen". To actually download the document you then have to click through several pointless pages: "Dokumentenkorb ansehen", then "Zur Freischaltung", then "Jetzt freischalten", then "Zum Dokumentenkorb", then finally click on the download icon next to each document in your basket.

===Searching for an Individual's Affiliations===

If you want to identify an individual's corporate affiliations, you can search https://companyhouse.de by individuals' names (at least if you're logged in with Sastre's account). Individuals' pages on companyhouse.de should list all past and current affiliations as a director ("Geschäftsführer") or "Prokurist" ("authorized signatory"), as well as their date of birth and (most recent) place of residence. Ownership relationships aren't usually listed (though occasionally they are, especially for KG companies). The date of birth listed on companyhouse.de is reliable, but the dates of affiliations are very unreliable, so affiliations should ideally be confirmed on unternehmensregister.de as outlined above, if you're going to mention them in a report. There's no simple way to search for companies that a person owns; the best approach is to use Unternehmensregister.de to check the ownership of any companies where the subject is a director, or where you have other reason to suspect a connection.

===Company Finances===

Official annual financial statements (called Jahresabschlüsse) are available from both https://companyhouse.de and https://www.unternehmensregister.de. In terms of the statements' contents, both websites are equally reliable, though if for a given company one website doesn't have them, check the other.

On companyhouse.de, you just go to the "Jahresabschlüsse" tab on a company's page and choose the statement you want to see. If you're logged into Sastre's account, they should be free to view.

On unternehmensregister.de, first search a company's name in the "Schnellsuche" field. On the results page, for companies that have statements available, each available statement will be listed beneath the company's name, for example "Jahresabschluss zum Geschäftsjahr vom 01.01.2010 bis zum 31.12.2010" is the statement for 2010.

===Miscellaneous Notes===
* Ownership information isn't (usually?) available for AG companies, unless they publish it themselves on their website or in their annual reports.
* There's no good way to search for a given company's subsidiaries or shareholdings, but these are sometimes listed in Jahresabschlüsse.
* "Geschäftsführer" is best translated as "director" and "Prokurist" is best translated as "authorized signatory".
* Regardless of which websites you use to access German corporate records, it's best to just cite them as "German corporate records" or similar in your footnotes. Don't link directly to companyhouse.de.

===Additional Corporate Registry Resources===

* [https://id.occrp.org/databases/#germany OCCRP ID Database for Germany] (''pub'')
* [https://www.handelsregister.de/rp_web/mask.do?Typ=e Common Register Portal of the] German Federal States (''pub'')
* [https://www.firmen-in-berlin.com/sites/fitber/welcome.aspx Companies in Berlin - Business] Database of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) Berlin (''pub'')
* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?GERMANY&member=1 European Commission E-Justice Overview of] German Business Registry (''pub'')
* [https://www.deutsche-boerse-cash-market.com/dbcm-de/instrumente-statistiken/statistiken/gelistete-unternehmen Frankfurt Stock Exchange Listed Companies] (''pub'')
* [http://www.dihk.de/ihk-finder IHK-FINDER - German Chamber of] Commerce Directory (''pub'')
* [https://www.unternehmensregister.de/ureg/?submitaction=language&language=en The German Company Registry (Unternehmensregister)] (''pub'')
* [https://www.bundesanzeiger.de/ebanzwww/wexsservlet Bundesanzeiger - German Federal Gazette] (''pub'')
* [https://www.companyhouse.de/ Companyhouse - Third-party Corporate Registry] Service (''paid'')
* [https://www.transparenzregister.de/treg/de/start?1 Transparency Register (UBO register)] (''pub'', ''reg'')

---

[http://www.napr.gov.ge/pol	National Agency of Public Registries]

The National Agency of Public Registries operates the country's business register. Search by company or individual entrepreneur name to find status. Little basic information is displayed, but corporate filings in Georgian only may be accessed. Browser translation function does not work on this page; use browser extension TransOver or similar.

English version and browser translation works. Good for quick checks of information.

litigation.wiki_content:
Germany has very stringent privacy laws, as a result of which, when court records are published, they are (almost?) always anonymised, meaning that the names of all parties are redacted (whether individuals or companies). Nonetheless, it's very quick and easy to run checks in the available databases, so we do it anyway just in case.

The first step is to go to [https://justiz.de/onlinedienste/rechtsprechung/index.php this webpage]. From here, click on "Bund" to go to the search portal for federal courts, or click on the name of one of Germany's 16 provinces (Länder) to go to the portal for that province.

On the resulting page, you usually need to click on something like "Entscheidungssuche" ("decision search") to open the search screen, then choose "Volltextsuche" ("full text search") if there are multiple search types available, and select the court(s) whose decisions you want to search (there's usually an option for all courts).

[https://www.bundesgerichtshof.de Federal Court of Justice (Bundesgerichtshof; BGH)] This database holds records for decisions from the highest court in civil and criminal matters in Germany.

Additional litigation resources:

* [http://juris.bundesgerichtshof.de Supreme Court Decision Search] (''pub'')

litigation.wiki_content:
''Context''
Ghana has a common law legal system. Judges look to past, relevant precedential decisions and apply their principles to the legal questions before them. If a similar dispute has been resolved in the past, the court is usually bound to follow the reasoning used in the prior decision. Written opinions for precedent-setting decisions are published online as they are of significance and interest to the general public and legal practitioners alike. Case briefs mainly serve to show how a legal decision was arrived at, which requires, to some extent, recounting the circumstances of the underlying dispute. Personal data may be published in judgments. Court records for cases that are neither precedent-setting nor of public importance are not publicly available. The most comprehensive, online Ghana case law databases are maintained by the Ghana Judicial Service website and the Ghana Legal Information Institute. These databases include decisions from all Ghanaian courts and specialty tribunals. The databases search allows for all courts to be searched at once, making knowledge of the subject's address history unessential.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://rgd.gov.gh Ghana Registrar General's Department] (''pub'') The Registrar General's Department (RGD) is the official body responsible for the registration of companies in Ghana. It operates under the Ministry of Justice and Attorney General and is responsible for ensuring compliance with the Companies Act, 2019 (Act 992). Companies must file specific details as required by legislation. Use the search bar on the RGD website to search by company name, number, or officer name. The search results will be organized by tab. To refine your results to companies, click the relevant tab. For disqualified directors, search for their name and click the 'Disqualifications' tab. Once you click on a company name, you will be brought to its Overview page. Click on the relevant tab to access filings (Filing History), info on officers and shareholders (People), and current and former charges (Charges). Company records are retained by the RGD for 10 years after a company is dissolved. The RGD includes registrations, annual reports, and other corporate filings, directors, and significant shareholders (25% or more). Companies are required to register incorporation details (including previous names), charges/mortgages, and insolvency information, and file annual reports and annual returns. For full date of birth, including the day, look for documents submitted before 2019. * [https://egovonline.gegov.gov.gh/RGDPortalWeb/portal/RGDHome/eghana.portal?_nfpb=true&_st=&_pageLabel=portal_RGDHome_NameSearchPage_page&linksPageTitle=Name+Search&service=namesearch#wlp_portal_RGDHome_NameSearchPage_page Registrar General's Department Portal -] simple name search of registered companies in Ghana (only company status and type available) (''pub'') * [https://gse.com.gh/ Ghana Stock Exchange - lists] all listed companies with capital, incorporation, address, contact information, directors, press releases, financial statements and statistics (''pub'') * [http://directory.africa-business.co... Africa Business Pages Directory -] business directory provided by Africa focused business magazine For '''archived company details and reports''', use [https://data.occrp.org/ OCCRP Aleph] (''civ'') and/or one of the following services: [https://companycheck.co.uk Company Check] (''priv'') [https://www.duedil.com DueDil] (''priv'') [https://www.endole.co.uk Endole] (''priv'') [https://register-of-charities.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-search Charity Register] (''pub'') You can find out what a charity does, where it operates, its trustees, and info on income and assets. Additionally, OpenCorporates has a comprehensive charity register for Ghana that includes registered charities. ===Ownership=== generally available :-reverse: in random cases only, on [https://data.occrp.org/ OCCRP Aleph] (''civ'') Information on [https://www.gov.uk/guidance/people-with-significant-control-pscs People with significant control]
Research Guide
'''Ultimate Beneficial Ownership''' Beneficial ownership can be found on the RGD website by following the chain of ownership or simply looking at the Persons with Significant Control (PSC). PSCs meet one of the following guidelines: the individual directly or indirectly owns over 25 percent of the company's shares or voting rights, or has the right to appoint or remove the majority of the board of directors. '''Publicly Traded''' You can find ownership information and corporate filings on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) and the RGD websites for publicly traded companies. Public companies must have at least two directors and one secretary registered with the RGD. '''Privately Held''' The RGD will often have shareholder information. Ownership/subsidiaries can also sometimes be found in accounts. In the Filing History section, you will find a list of documents. If there are numerous documents, you can narrow your search by keywords such as Capital, Shares, Annual Return, Confirmation Statement, and Incorporation. If there are only a few documents, please search all of them. If a company has numerous shareholders and you are unsure how to report this, contact your CM to notify him/her that the company's ownership structure is complicated. '''Nonprofit''' The Charity Commission in Ghana keeps records of charities. This website will have corporate filings that sometimes include trustee information.
===Directorship=== available :- reverse: yes ===Company Types===
''Details''
'''Private Company Limited by Shares''' This is the most common company type. They usually have 'Limited' or 'Ltd' at the end of the company name. The amount for which shareholders are liable in the event that the company is wound up is limited to the face value of their share in the business. The company cannot sell shares to the general public (like a PLC can). '''Public Limited Company (PLC)''' This type can sell shares to the general public. It must have share capital of GHS 50,000 or more, of which at least 25% must have been paid up before the company can begin trading. Not all PLCs are listed on a stock exchange. The liability of the company is limited to the value of its reserves. '''Private Company Limited by Guarantee''' This type limits the liability of its guarantors to a pre-agreed amount that they have to pay if the company is wound up. Non-profits are often set up like this. There is no share capital or shareholders in this company. Its members/owners are the guarantors. '''Private Unlimited Company''' There is no cap to the amount that its members are required to pay if the company is wound up, so they tend to be used for companies where insolvency is a very low risk. They are not required by law to submit annual accounts to the RGD. This makes unlimited companies attractive to businesses that wish to maintain a level of secrecy about their financial status. '''Limited Liability Partnership (LLP)''' An LLP is owned by its members who have certain responsibilities, including acting in accordance with the partnership agreement. Its members (partners) are only liable for the amount of money they invest, plus any personal guarantees. There's no restriction on the maximum number of partners allowed but there must be at least two members on incorporation, either individuals or limited companies. They are solely for profit-making businesses. '''Limited Partnership (LP)''' This is a business association of one or more 'general partners' alongside one or more 'limited partners'. It is the general partner who is personally liable for the partnership's debts and other obligations. Where there is more than one general partner, they are jointly liable for the partnership's debts. Liability is potentially unlimited, so they may face losing personal assets. Each limited partner's personal liability is capped to the amount of their investment (and any personal guarantees they have given). While their original investment may be lost in paying off partnership debts, the limited partner's personal assets cannot be accessed by creditors. '''Societas Europaea, or SE companies''' These can be established in all European Economic Area. When established in Ghana, SEs are a type of public limited company which can be formed as a subsidiary of another company or as a holding company. SE companies can also be created by mergers or from an existing PLC.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://www.businessregistry.gr/publicity/index GEMI Public Records]

Greece's online corporate register, the GEMI was launched in 2011. Some companies are missing. It is searchable for any commercial disclosures  just one of the following pieces of information relating to the company: Tax Identification Number (A.F.M. - Greek abbreviation) or General Commercial Registry (Γ.Ε.ΜI.) number or company name or short name.

Corporate records in Greece can be accessed for free online, although they usually only go back a few years. They will usually disclose the directors or administrators of a company. Shareholders are sometimes listed in the accounts or articles of association but this is hit or miss. Financial statements are often provided. If you want to be sure you have all of the filings back as far as incorporation, you need to get someone to go to the registry and look through the physical file of the company.

You can only search by company, not by director or shareholder. Use Orbis and OpenCorporates for this or else a contributor (talk to CC). You can search by the company's name, but the best way to search is by using the 12-digit company number (Αρ. Γ.Ε.ΜΗ) or 9-digit tax number (ΑΦΜ). You can get these in Orbis or OpenCorporates. Click through into the company's profile to get to the filings which are listed at the bottom. If you can't find the company in the registry, try finding it in OpenCorporates and clicking through on the link it provides. Note: if you're searching for a Greek company in OpenCorporates, use uppercase Greek letters. The bottom line is that the registry's online search is a little unreliable so be careful about concluding that a company isn't registered there, is inactive or hasn't filed anything. More info here: https://e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?GREECE&member=1

There are five markets operating in ATHEX: regulated securities market, regulated derivatives market, Alternative market, carbon market (for EUAs) and OTC market. In the regulated securities market investors can trade in stocks, bonds, ETFs and other related securities.


[http://www.et.gr/index.php/anazitisi-fek The National Printing House of Greece (Official Gazette)]


Personal Information

Corporate records provide some identifiers for individuals:

Date of birth: this is sometimes found in corporate filings (in the filing relating to change of directors).

Tax number: find this in the filing relating to change of directors.

ID number: same as above.

Address: same as above.

Place of birth: same as above.

Father's name: in corporate filings. This is one of the most frequent ways to identify someone in the registry as their father's name will come up as their middle name. Sometimes, the mother's name is supplied too.


=== Credit and Bancruptcy ===

There are no insolvency registers in Greece. In the case of natural persons, local district civil courts (eirinodikeía) handle insolvency cases, while the courts of first instance (protodikeía) handle the insolvency of corporate entities.

[https://www.adjustice.gr/webcenter/portal/ste/ypiresies/nomologies?_adf.ctrl-state=fcs50g2my_50&_afrLoop=6884628585515749#! The Council of State]

Conduct an internal search using the provided fields.
The Council of State is the supreme administrative court of Greece. This search can yield results of recent court judgements. Note that detailed judgement content is only available in Greek. The Council of State hears petitions for annulment of administrative acts for breach of law, abuse of power, lack of competence or formal omission; appeals by civilian, military, government and other personnel against rulings by staff councils (υπηρεσιακά συμβούλια) on promotion, dismissal, demotion, etc.;petitions for review of rulings by administrative courts.​ More detailed judgement content is only available in Greek and the available records are not comprehensive.


[https://www.areiospagos.gr/en/INDEX.htm Areios Pagos Supreme Civil and Criminal Court of Greece]

The Supreme Court of Greece enables searches of the court's rulings since 2006, by Greek-language keywords, date and number. Penal cases are also listed by category for up to 2018.

Conduct an internal and site search. Note that you need a case number to conduct the internal court ruling search. The Supreme Court hears civil and criminal cases.
Click on αποφάσεις for criminal court decisions after 2007.
Click on ποινικών for criminal cases after 2017.

You can also search Supreme Court records through their websites:

Search Supreme Court decisions from 2007 on here: http://www.areiospagos.gr/ (click on Αποφάσεις on the left-hand side menu).

Search Supreme Court criminal cases on the same page (click on Ποινικές υποθέσεις on the left-hand side menu).


[https://www.adjustice.gr/webcenter/portal/dprotodikeioath?_afrLoop=6885050902675762#!%40%40%3F_afrLoop%3D6885050902675762%26_adf.ctrl-state%3Dfcs50g2my_196 Administrative Court of First Instance]

Administrative courts are responsible for resolving administrative disputes between government administration and citizens. They hear taxation cases, disputes between individuals and social security or social policy organizations and administrative disputes between citizens and national or local government.


[https://extapps.solon.gov.gr/mojwp/faces/TrackLdoPublic;jsessionid=pkJqEipAOphjyiH_98SuC5kbSOsS52R0OKLpmCkoeXu2yKs0yytQ!-2068368237 Court Cases]

You can find out the status of a court case (if you have the case number).

Required for All Companies
Internal search for antitrust, cartels, mergers, and State aid cases. Search by case number or company name.


Legislative Branch

The Greek Parliament (Βουλή των Ελλήνων) has 300 members, elected for a four-year term by a system of reinforced proportional representation in 48 multi-seat constituencies, 8 single-seat constituencies and a single nationwide list.

Judicial Branch

In line with the principle of the separation of powers, justice is independent of the legislative and executive powers.

Types of courts

Courts in Greece are divided into Administrative, Civil and Criminal.

Administrative courts (Διοικητικά δικαστήρια)

Civil courts (Πολιτικά δικαστήρια)

Criminal courts (Ποινικά δικαστήρια)

Court martial (στρατοδικείο), naval court (ναυτοδικείο) and air force court (αεροδικείο)

Supreme Special Court (Ανώτατο Ειδικό Δικαστήριο)

Special court for corruption lawsuits

Special court for liability of Ministers

Special court for disputes on remuneration of judicial officials

Disputes of an administrative nature are under the jurisdiction of the Council of State (Symboulio tis Epikrateias) and the Regular Administrative Courts (courts of First Instance and Courts of Appeal).

Disputes of civil nature and voluntary jurisdiction are under the jurisdiction Civil Courts.

The punishment of crimes and the adoption of all measures required by the criminal laws are under the jurisdiction of Criminal Courts.

The Court of Cassation (Areios Pagos) is the Supreme Court for Civil and Criminal Law. It examines only legal and not factual issues and it is the highest degree of judicial resort.

The auditing of public spending, the control of contracts of a significant economic value where one of the contractors is the State, the audit of the finances of public persons, the submission of reports to Parliament for the statement of accounts and balance sheets of the State are all under the jurisdiction of the Court of Auditors (Elegktiko Synedrio).

The adjudication of objections at the validity of national parliamentary elections, referendums and the resolution of conflicting jurisprudence between courts and administrative commissions or between the Council of State and Regular Administrative Courts, or Civil and Criminal Courts, or between the Court of Auditors and other Courts is under the jurisdiction of the Special Highest Court (Anotato Eidiko Dikastirio).

Another organ of quasi-judicial nature is the Legal Council of State (Nomiko Symboulio tou Kratous). According to article 100A of the Constitution, the Legal Council of the State is assigned with the judicial support and representation of the State and to the recognition of claims against it or to the settlement of disputes with the State.

Administrative Divisions

Greece is divided into 13 administrative regions which are further divided into 74 regional units. The 13 administrative regions (Περιφέρειες, Periféries) are each headed by a popularly elected governor (Περιφερειάρχης, Periferiárhis) and presided over by the popularly elected regional council (Περιφερειακό Συμβούλιο, Periferiakó Simvoúlio). Each of the 74 regional units (Περιφερειακές Ενότητες, Periferiakés Enóti̱tes) are headed by a vice governor (Αντιπεριφερειάρχης, Antiperiferiárhis), who is taken from the same political party as the elected governor. The 13 regions are mostly political and geographically. Greece is home to nine regions: Thrace, with the capital Alexandroupolis, Macedonia, with the capital of Thessaloniki; Epirus; Central Greece; Pelloponese; the Ionian Islands; the Aegean islands; Crete; and Athens.

Greece's 74 regional units are divided into 325 municipalities (Δήμοι, Dhími) which are led by a popularly elected mayor (Δήμαρχος, Dhímarhos) and municipal council (Δημοτικό Συμβούλιο, Dhimotikó Simvoúlio). Each municipality is divided into small municipal units (Δημοτικές Ενότητες, Dhimotikés Enótites) which in turn contain municipal communities (relatively urban communities) and local communities (relatively rural communities). Municipal councils select community members to serve on more local town hall councils which focus on local needs in the municipality's communities and give local feedback to the municipal government.


Litigation records aren't easily accessible in Greece so you will likely need a contributor for this research.

Justis VLex contains very limited filings from certain Greek courts, mostly from before 2000 so not very helpful.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
* '''Court Register (Sudski registar)''' – The official corporate register for Croatia is maintained by the Ministry of Justice.  The public portal allows users to search by company name or registration number (MBS) and view data such as the company’s registration date, legal form, status and court of registration.  The search interface also supports searches by personal name and includes filters for legal form, status (active or deleted) and the court:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.  Documents such as statutes, shareholder lists and historical filings can be downloaded for a fee, and the site provides access to e‑services and name and document verification:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

* '''Croatian Chamber of Economy – Company Directory''' – The chamber operates the Croatian Company Directory, an integrated database of all registered business entities.  According to the site, it provides “easy access to information on individual companies” and detailed data such as contact details, business activity, number of employees, company size, organisation type and primary transaction account:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.  Internet users can access a limited set of data and companies can update their information via a request form:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.

* '''Croatian Export Directory''' – This portal (maintained by the Croatian Chamber of Economy) offers a searchable database of importers and exporters.  Users can search by company name, primary activity, customs tariff (product type) or service category to retrieve contact information, primary business activity, size, ownership structure and share capital.  The site also includes regulatory and investment information.

* '''European Commission business register overview''' – The European e‑Justice portal provides an overview of Croatia’s business register and links to the national register.  It notes that business registers in EU countries store information on legal form, seat, capital and legal representatives, and make this information available to the public:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.

* '''Zagreb Stock Exchange''' – The official website of the Zagreb Stock Exchange lists all shares, bonds and issuers.  Users can access trading data, issuers’ reports, corporate actions, membership lists and data distribution services.

* '''Digitalna komora''' – The “Digital Chamber” portal (Digitalna Komora) is an official corporate register managed by the Croatian Chamber of Economy.  Access requires registration; the site provides company listings, digital services and document filing.

* '''Register of Beneficial Owners (RSV)''' – Managed by FINA, this register records beneficial ownership information for companies and trusts.  Searches are available to registered users and may require an account and fee.

* '''Registry of Financial Statements (RGFI)''' – FINA maintains a registry of financial statements filed by Croatian companies.  Users can search and download annual reports and financial data.  Some documents may require payment.

* '''Insolvency Register (nesolventnost.pravosudje.hr)''' – The Insolvency Register publishes information on bankruptcy and insolvency proceedings against companies and individuals.  Searches can be performed by name or MBS.

* '''Directorship information''' – The Court Register records the names of directors and authorised representatives of each company.  Historical data on directorships can be accessed through the same portal.

* '''Constitutional Court decision search''' – The Constitutional Court’s online database allows users to search decisions made since 2000 by signature, case number, or year and date.  Results return all decisions containing the supplied terms.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
===Ministry of Justice – Company Search===

The official company register database is kept by the Ministry of Public Administration and Justice, accessible here:
[https://www.e-cegjegyzek.hu/?cegkereses Corporate Registry Search] (''pub'')
This Hungarian company search provides free access to incorporation certificates, company addresses, owners, administrators, and shareholder data. Some documents are only accessible offline (uncertified) for free or online for a fee.
	•	Using the search site may prompt a CAPTCHA and a "user declaration" form.
	•	''Cégnév kezdete:'' "company name beginning."
	•	''Székhely:'' "headquarters" or "registered office."
	•	''ir.szam:'' zip code; ''város:'' city; ''utca:'' street; ''hsz:'' house number.
	•	''cégjegyzékszám:'' "company registration number" or "corporate registration number."
	•	''adószám:'' "tax identification number" or "tax ID number."

To search by the name of a natural person, additional information (such as tax ID and place of residence) is required:
[https://www.e-cegjegyzek.hu/?szemelykereses Natural Person Search] (''pub'', ''reg'')

===Ministry of Justice – Annual Reports===

[http://e-beszamolo.im.gov.hu/ Central Depository of Annual Returns] (''pub'')
This portal provides company financial statements and annual reports filed with the Ministry of Justice.

===Court of Company Registrations===

[https://www.e-cegjegyzek.hu/new.htm Ministry of Justice - Company Search] (''pub'')
A separate search from Hungary's Company Registration Court offering annual accounts or other filings when available; some data may be accessible for a fee.

===Budapest Stock Exchange===

[https://bse.hu/pages/section-members Budapest Stock Exchange] (''pub'')
Contains a list of stock issues with details such as addresses, contact information, and names of publicly listed entities.

===Hungarian Business Register Overview===

[https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?HUNGARY&member=1 European Commission E-Justice overview] (''pub'')

The register contains data on registered companies and corporate documents, which serve as the basis for registration. Courts of registration manage this data electronically, and the information is available free of charge at the [https://www.e-cegjegyzek.hu/ Company Information Service].
Accessible data include:

	•	Corporate registration number
	•	Company name
	•	Head office (székhely)
	•	Business facility(ies) (telephelyek)
	•	Branch(es) (fióktelepek)
	•	Activity(ies)
	•	Issued share capital
	•	Tax number
	•	Status of bankruptcy, liquidation, or final settlement proceedings
	•	Whether an executive officer or manager is barred under Section 3:22 of Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code

Additional data—such as membership or share ownership—is updated weekly.

	•	Is access to the Hungarian business register free of charge?
Basic company data is accessible free of charge via the Company Information Service; additional filings may require a fee.
	•	How to search the Hungarian business register
Searches can be conducted by company name, corporate registration number, or tax number.
	•	To which extent can the information in the register be relied upon?
The data, as specified in Article 2 of Directive 2009/101/EC, is accessible online free of charge. Public company information is provided by the court of registration, the Company Information Service, or published in the Company Gazette ([http://www.e-cegkozlony.gov.hu/ link]), the official journal of the Ministry of Justice. Data is stored electronically with rapid regional updates.
	•	Find information per region
While data is centralized, each Hungarian court of registration contributes electronically to the national system, with regional references updated within minutes.

===Commercial Websites===

[https://www.companyregister.hu/comp eGov Consulting – Company Search] (''pub'')
Provides e-information on Hungarian companies.

[http://www.e-cegbeszamolo.hu The official company register database] (''pub'')
For annual reports.

litigation.wiki_content:
Hungary follows a civil law legal system grounded in comprehensive legal codes rather than case law. Judicial decisions, while influential, do not set binding precedent. Legal outcomes and statutory interpretations largely depend on strict adherence to legislation and legal scholarship. Searchable legal databases cover various court levels, though data protection regulations may limit the identification of specific parties.

===National Judicial Council (Országos Bírósági Hivatal; OBH)===

[https://birosag.hu/ National Judicial Council] (''pub'')
Oversees Hungarian courts and hosts a database of judicial decisions. Users can browse verdicts by date or keyword, though personal details are often anonymized.

===Supreme Court (Kúria)===

[https://www.kuria-birosag.hu/ Supreme Court website] (''pub'')
Includes verdicts and resolutions on various cases, providing insight into Hungary's highest judicial decisions. Searchable by case number, keywords, or thematic categories.

===Additional Judicial Resources===

[https://birosag.hu/birosagi-hatarozatok-gyujtemenye Search for court decisions in Hungary] (''pub'')
Allows searches in the body of the court decision or based on court record number, usually anonymized.

[http://hunconcourt.hu/ Constitutional Court]

[https://www.lexadin.nl/wlg/courts/nofr/eur/lxcthun.htm Other Courts]

[http://njt.hu/njt.php?translated Hungarian Laws in English]

[https://inyr.im.gov.hu/Szakertok Legal Experts Database] (''pub'')
Directory of legal experts with contact details and specialties.

===Criminal Litigation===

Criminal litigation filings are available in Hungary, although these are heavily redacted (deletion extending to names of individuals, institutions, companies, as well as any other identifiers). Due to privacy laws, names of individuals, institutions, and companies are generally redacted, and the dataset contains only a selection of judgments.

===Civil Litigation===

The database maintained by the Hungarian Curia portal (Bírósági Határozatok Gyűjteménye) and published by the Ministry of Justice aggregates decisions and judgments from civil courts in all jurisdictions across Hungary. Please note that due to privacy laws, names of individuals, institutions, and companies are generally redacted, and the dataset contains only a selection of judgments.

===Insolvency Proceedings===

Act XLIX of 1991 governs bankruptcy and liquidation for legal persons—bankruptcy aims to reorganize, while liquidation focuses on asset distribution to satisfy creditors. Personal debt settlement for natural persons is regulated by Act CV of 2015, protecting mortgage debtors. Proceedings may be initiated by debtors or creditors, with assets managed by an administrator or liquidator. These processes restrict other enforcement actions and may void acts detrimental to creditors.

===Tax & Solvency===

[https://fizeteskeptelenseg.im.gov.hu Insolvency Register] (''pub'')

[https://www.nav.gov.hu/nav/adatbazisok/adoslista/vegrehajtas_alattiak List of Tax Debtors] (''pub'')

[https://www.nav.gov.hu/nav/adatbazisok/megbizhato_adozok Database of Reliable Taxpayers] (''pub'')

[https://nav.gov.hu/nav/adatbazisok/bejelentkezesi_kotelezettseget_elmulaszto_adozok/bejelentkezesi_kot_elmulasztok Individuals who failed to register with Tax Authority]

[https://www.nav.gov.hu/nav/adatbazisok/adatbleker/Aktv_43_G_szerinti_penzugyi_intezmenyek/Nem_Jelento_Magyar_Penzugyi_Intezmenyek Not-Reporting Financial Services Providers]

[https://www.nav.gov.hu/nav/adatbazisok/adatbleker/afaalanyok/afaalanyok_egyszeru Taxpayers subject to VAT payments]

[https://www.nav.gov.hu/nav/adatbazisok/adatbleker/egyebszerv/egyeb_szervezetek_egyszeru Taxpayers not subject to VAT payments]

[https://www.nav.gov.hu/nav/adatbazisok/adatbleker/egyeni_vallakozok_bevallasi_adatai Taxable income data of companies & sole proprietors]

[https://www.e-cegjegyzek.hu/?eltiltottkereses Individuals prohibited from filling certain registered company positions]

===Bankruptcies, Negative Credit, Disqualifications===

Various Hungarian government bodies publish information relating to individuals' and entities' negative credit record, their compliance with fiscal regulations, and disqualifications from holding corporate roles. These databases include the insolvency register; the National Tax and Customs Administration databases, including a national list of tax debtors and of those individuals who have failed to register with the tax authority or comply with VAT payments; the Ministry of Justice register of disqualified directors.

===Public Procurement===

[http://www.kozbeszerzes.hu/adatbazi Hungarian Public Procurement Portal - Public Tender Search] (''pub'')

[http://www.kozbeszerzes.hu/adatbazi Hungarian Public Procurement Dispute Decision Search] (''pub'')

[https://kozbeszerzes.hu/adatbazis/keres/hirdetmeny/ Public Procurement Contract Database]

Many sectors have dedicated procurement databases.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://find-and-update.company-information.service.gov.uk Companies House] (''pub'')

Companies House is the United Kingdom's registrar of companies and is an executive agency and trading fund of His Majesty's Government, falling under the remit of the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy. All forms of companies (as permitted by the United Kingdom Companies Act) are incorporated and registered with Companies House and file specific details as required by legislation.

Use the search bar to search by company name, number or officer/PSC name. The search results will be organized by tab. To refine your results to companies, click the relevant tab. If searching for disqualified directors, search for their name and then click the 'Disqualifications' tab. Once you click on a company name, you will be brought through to its Overview page. Again, click on the relevant tab to access filings (Filing History), info on officers and PSCs (People), and current and former charges (Charges).

litigation.wiki_content:
* [https://www.courts.ie/judgments The Court Service of Ireland] (''pub'') – searchable database of published judgments from the High Court, Court of Appeal and Supreme Court.  Judgments are anonymised and sorted by date and court.  Use the search bar to filter by keywords, names or dates.
* [http://highcourtsearch.courts.ie/hcslive/cslogin High Court of Ireland records] dating back to 1993 (''pub'') – this database allows you to search High Court cases by party name or case number.  It provides hearing dates and case status, but judgments are rarely included.
* [http://www.bailii.org/ British and Irish Legal Information] Institute – court decisions database (''pub'').  BAILII hosts decisions of Irish courts and tribunals; search by party names or legal references.
* [https://www.ucc.ie/academic/law/irlii/index.php Irish Legal Information Initiative] (''pub'') – provides links to legal resources and includes a case-law search for certain courts.
* [https://arbitrationireland.com/judgements/ Arbitration Ireland] publishes a list of judgements, although there are not many.
* Aggregators [https://www.solocheck.ie/barometer-Extra-Recent-Judgments.jsp SoloCheck] and [https://www.businessbarometer.ie/company-judgment-list Business Barometer] claim to publish judgements recently issued against companies. A free search will reveal whether one or more judgements are on file against a company; details are available via paid credit reports (about €10).  These services remain untested as of May 2025.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
===General Company Information (incl. ownership)===

The first site to check for Irish companies is [https://search.cro.ie/company/CompanySearch.aspx Companies Registration Office] (CRO).  This is the official registry.  A basic search by company name or number returns background data such as the company’s legal form, registration number, status, address and date of incorporation.  To obtain more detailed information you must pay for individual corporate filings (e.g. annual returns or director/shareholder changes).  These filings give only a basic description of changes and do not always include shareholding details.  As of 2025 the search portal is free to use for basic information but each filing costs €2.50.  CRO also publishes weekly gazette lists of companies making insolvency or wind-up filings (see below).

[https://www.solocheck.ie/ SoloCheck] – a paid-for company-check service that is more expensive than the CRO but much more efficient.  A basic report (about €4) provides background data and the names of directors.  A full credit report (about €10) identifies directors (with their dates of birth, addresses and possible other affiliations based on name and DOB combination) and shareholders, alongside key financials for the past five years.  A list of judgments may be provided if relevant.  This is usually cheaper and faster than buying multiple CRO filings for €2.50 each.

[https://ie.globaldatabase.com/ Global Database] – an aggregator which has sometimes provided Irish company shareholder information for free.  It pulls data from a variety of sources.  (See this [https://ie.globaldatabase.com/company/dave-barry-plastics-limited example].)

[https://id.occrp.org/databases/#ireland OCCRP ID – search government] gazettes for company-related notices (''pub'').  This dashboard collates government announcements, company filings and other public datasets.

[https://e-justice.europa.eu/content_business_registers_in_member_states-106-ie-en.do?member=1 European Commission E-Justice – overview] of the Irish business register (''pub'').  This page explains what information is available in the Irish registry and provides links to the CRO portal and other official resources.

[https://register.rbo.gov.ie/ Registered Beneficial Owner (RBO) registry] (''pub'', ''reg'').  The RBO contains details of the ultimate beneficial owners of Irish companies and industrial and provident societies.  Since 2022 the register is not publicly searchable; access is limited to competent authorities and designated persons, so researchers must rely on filings filed before the restriction or request information under applicable regulations.

[http://www.irisoifigiuil.ie/ Irish State Gazette – official] company notices (''pub'').  The official gazette publishes company-related notices (e.g. change of name, dissolutions, liquidations).  It is not searchable; notices are published chronologically in PDF issues.

Additional resources for company research include [https://www.companyhouse.ie/ CompanyHouse.ie] (third-party site for basic company info), [https://www.opencorporates.com/companies/ie OpenCorporates] (aggregated global company database) and [https://www.dubilinfolink.com Company Registration Office Ireland – CRO Search] (alternative portal to CRO).  These sites should be cross-checked with the official CRO.

===Searching for an Individual’s Affiliations===

If you want to identify an individual’s corporate affiliations, you can search [https://ie.globaldatabase.com/ Global Database] by a person’s name.  SoloCheck offers an “Individual Credit Report” (about €9) which pulls information from the Revenue Defaulters database and other sources; it will reveal whether there are judgements or defaults against the person.  However, there is no comprehensive public register of shareholders.  To determine ownership of companies where a person is a director, check the share registers in CRO filings (e.g. “Annual Return B1”) or use Global Database if available.  The RBO (beneficial ownership) register is not public; only competent authorities and designated persons can search it.

===Company Finances===

Official annual financial statements for Irish companies are filed with the CRO and are available through the CRO search for €2.50 per document.  SoloCheck and Global Database often provide recent financial statements and key ratios (profit, turnover, assets and liabilities) in their paid reports.  If the CRO or SoloCheck doesn’t have a given year’s statement, check the company’s own website or press releases; publicly listed companies also file accounts with the Irish Stock Exchange (see below).

===Miscellaneous Notes===

* Some small Irish companies are exempt from filing detailed accounts (micro companies), so only basic financial statements may be available.
* The CRO provides a list of disqualified directors and details of persons who are restricted from being directors; this can be searched via the advanced search function at [https://core.cro.ie/search Director Disqualifications].
* The RBO search has been restricted since 2022; you can no longer freely search beneficial owners.
* Whenever citing Irish corporate records in a report, describe them generically as “Irish corporate records” rather than linking directly to third-party sites.
* There is no free comprehensive register of company subsidiaries; these may be listed in annual financial statements.

===Additional Corporate Registry Resources===

* [https://id.occrp.org/databases/#ireland OCCRP ID Database] (''pub'') – includes Ireland among its covered jurisdictions.
* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?member=1 European Commission E-Justice portal] (''pub'') – lists and links to EU member business registers, including Ireland.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
===Official Registry===

The official corporate registry can be accessed at this address: https://www.gov.il/en/service/company_extract

Here you can search by (Hebrew) company name or company number, and you can either obtain basic information for free, or a full extract for 11 shekels.

The free basic information includes Hebrew name, English name, company number, establishment date and address.

The full extract includes Hebrew name, English name, company number, establishment date, address, purpose, share capital, directors (name, citizenship, identification number, home address, date of appointment), shareholders, and a timeline of changes to these things.

* [https://ica.justice.gov.il/GenericCorporarionInfo/SearchCorporation?unit=8 Israel Corporation Authority website for] official company information (''pub'')

===Unofficial Site===

This unofficial site has some information visible for free that's not free from the original registry: https://www.checkid.co.il/

This site doesn't allow searches by the names of directors or shareholders, but a Google site search of a person's name will bring up any mentions.

litigation.wiki_content:
=== Court System in Iceland ===
Iceland has a structured court system with various levels including District Courts and the Supreme Court. The District Courts handle both civil and criminal cases at the first instance, while the Supreme Court handles appeals.

[District Courts](https://www.heradsdomstolar.is/heradsdomstolar/)  
The Icelandic justice portal enables search for legal decisions and case information from the district courts. It provides access to court decisions, procedural history, and other relevant case details. This covers the seven district courts. (pub)

[Supreme Court](https://www.haestirettur.is/)  
The Supreme Court is responsible for appeals from the district courts. It provides access to final decisions on significant cases and maintains a searchable database of its rulings. The Supreme Court offers a search service for case law since 1999 on its website. However, parties to cases are anonymised. (pub)

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
=== Companies in Iceland ===
Icelandic companies are registered and maintained by the Ríkisskattstjóri (Directorate of Internal Revenue).

[Iceland Corporate Register](https://www.rsk.is/fyrirtaekjaskra)  
The Iceland companies register is run by the Ríkisskattstjóri (Directorate of Internal Revenue). It provides comprehensive information about companies registered in Iceland. The registry supports searches by company name and provides details such as company status, registration number, and more. Search by company name to get basic company information with information on postal address, municipality, legal form, type of business. Annual accounts are available for free download by email. (pub)

[Legal Gazette Iceland Lögbirtingablað](http://www.logbirtingablad.is/) (pub)

=== Ownership ===
Ownership information is available for companies listed in the registry. Reverse ownership searches are generally not available.

=== Directorship ===
Directorship information can be obtained through the Iceland Corporate Register. This includes details about the directors and their roles within the company.

The Japanese Corporate Register is maintained by the Ministry of Justice and provides comprehensive information about companies registered in Japan. Access to the database requires a login.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
=== Companies in Japan ===
Japanese companies are categorized under various types including Kabushiki Kaisha (KK) and Godo Kaisha (GK).

Kabushiki Kaisha (KK) is a type of corporation similar to a public company in the Western context, where shares can be offered to the public. Godo Kaisha (GK) is similar to a limited liability company, typically used for smaller businesses.

See the detailed regulations for each type of company in Japan Regulatory.pdf

=== Japanese Corporate Register ===
[Japanese Corporate Register](http://www1.touki.or.jp/gateway.html)
The Japanese Corporate Register is maintained by the Ministry of Justice and provides comprehensive information about companies registered in Japan. Access to the database requires a login.

=== Japanese Corporate Register - Information ===
[Japanese Corporate Register - Information](http://www1.touki.or.jp)
This site run by the Ministry of Justice allows searching for companies, directors, and ownership information. Details available include company name, registration number, and directors' information.

=== Japanese Corporate Register - Business Names ===
[Japanese Corporate Register - Business Names](http://www1.touki.or.jp)
You can search the business names register by the family and given name of a person holding business names. The information retrieved includes current person name details, roles held, and current business name details.

=== Japanese Corporate Register - Public View ===
[Japanese Corporate Register - Public View](http://www1.touki.or.jp)
Provides access to publicly available information supplied by businesses when they register. Supports search by company's name and registration number.

=== Ownership ===
Ownership details are generally unclear and require specific searches through the corporate register. Reverse searches are not commonly available.

=== Directorship ===
Directorship information can be obtained through the Japanese Corporate Register. Details include the directors' names and roles within the company.

=== Additional Resources ===
* [Japan Exchange Group](https://www.jpx.co.jp/english/) - includes listed company search with incorporation date, office address, shareholders, representatives and total shares (pub)

* [Ministry of Justice Registry](http://www1.touki.or.jp/gateway.html) - company and real estate registries (only in Japanese) (pub, reg)

* [Japanese Corporate Register](http://www1.touki.or.jp) - maintained by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (pub, paid, reg)

* [American Chamber of Commerce in Japan](http://www.accj.or.jp/commercial-me...) membership directory

litigation.wiki_content:
=== Court System in Japan ===
Japan has a well-structured court system divided into several levels including the Supreme Court, High Courts, District Courts, Family Courts, and Summary Courts. Each level of court handles different types of cases ranging from criminal, civil, to family matters.

=== Key Resources ===

==== AustLII ====
[AustLII](http://www6.austlii.edu.au/)
This database contains full text decisions of various Japanese courts and publishes public legal information including primary legal materials (legislation, treaties, and court decisions).

==== JADE ====
[JADE](https://jade.io/)
The Judgment and Decisions Enhanced website provides a professional legal research platform designed for the legal profession. It includes decisions of Japanese and international courts and tribunals.

==== Supreme Court Judgements ====
* [Judgements of the Supreme Court of Japan](https://www.courts.go.jp/app/hanrei_en/search?) (pub)

litigation.wiki_content:
=== Court System in Kenya ===
Kenya has a structured court system with various levels, including the Magistrate Courts, High Courts, and the Supreme Court. The Magistrate Courts handle first instance criminal and civil cases, while the High Courts handle appeals and constitutional matters. The Supreme Court is the highest court, handling significant appeals.

===Disclaimer===

Searches of Kenyan litigation records, including those held by civil, administrative, commercial, labour, criminal and succession litigation filings for all Courts of Appeal, High Courts, Employment and Labour Relations Courts, all Environmental and Land Court and the Supreme Court did not find any reference to ***.

===Court Databases===

[Kenya Law](http://www.kenyalaw.org/CaseSearch/)  
Kenya Law maintains a searchable database of over 30,000 cases dating back to 1976. The database includes civil and criminal filings from the High Courts, Appellate Courts, and employment/labor courts.

[The Judiciary of Kenya](http://www.judiciary.go.ke/)  
The Judiciary of Kenya website provides access to cause lists and selected judgments available for the past six months.

[http://www.juricaf.org Juricaf (Cambodia)]

Database of case law in French providing the decisions of supreme courts across the French speaking world. Funded by the French Ministry of Justice and the International Organisation of La Francophonie. Is very limited in scope. 

The judicial system of Cambodia is divided into three parts:		
		
Provincial Court of the First Instance and provincial municipal courts
	
Appeal courts		

Supreme Court		

In addition, there are two other special courts: the Military Court, which deals with cases related to military crime or discipline; and the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, which receives international assistance through the United Nations Assistance to the Khmer Rouge Trials (UNARKT).	
	
Limited judgements (mostly from the year 1994 to 2006) are available from the website of the Supreme Court, which is accessible only in Khmer: http://www.supremecourt.gov.kh/		
For the most part, judgements and case records in Cambodia are not publicly accessible.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[http://www.registrucentras.lt/jar/p/ Centre of Registers] (''pub'', ''paid'', ''reg'')

This is the official corporate registry. Basic company information and a list of all filed documents is available for free to anyone. Detailed company information is only available to Lithuanian citizens with a Lithuanian e-ID, residency or bank account. A simple extract (called a "master data statement in electronic form") costs €3.69 and lists directors, alongside other usual basic information, but it won't contain shareholders. There are also myriad other documents that can be bought separately for similarly small fees, including financial reports and the company statute. If there's one available called "shareholders' decision", that should list the shareholders (and their respective percentages) as of the date the decision was made. If there aren't any shareholders' decisions, there probably won't be any ownership information available.

Search by director or shareholder is not available due to legislation on protecting personal information. 

[https://rekvizitai.vz.lt/ Directory of Lithuanian companies]

This is a third-party registry that provides some more information for free than the official one, and it also allows anyone to buy specific documents (the same ones available in the official registry). Usefully, as each company page typically lists current directors (for free), this site provides the only way to search for a person's Lithuanian directorships. The site doesn't contain this function itself, but you can do a Google search with the person's name and site:rekvizitai.vz.lt. Of course, these types of searches shouldn't be considered definitive/exhaustive.

[https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?LITHUANIA&member=1 European Commission E-Justice] (''pub'')

European Commission overview of the Lithuanian business registry, including links to the registry, description of how to search and what can be found as well as legislation behind it.

[http://www.lursoft.lv A private corporate register run by the Latvian company Lursoft IT] (''paid'')

A private corporate register run by the Latvian company Lursoft IT in cooperation with the Lithuanian Register center provides access to the database of Lithuanian companies. Company profiles contain information on 100 percent shareholders only. Account registration is only possible with Baltic bank account or ID.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
The [https://www.lbr.lu/ '''Luxembourg Business Registers'''] website provides access to the Trade and Companies Register ("RCS"; corporate registry), Electronic Compendium of Companies and Associations (corporate announcements publication) and Register of Beneficial Owners. The latter is inaccessible as of January 2024 due to an EU ruling restricting access to beneficial ownership records.

Upon accessing the RCS, click the login link in the top left and log in "as an anonymous user", which does not require a profile. Without logging in, you will only be able to search the RCS and access basic background information on companies: name, registered address, date of incorporation, legal form, activity, and dissolution/liquidation data if applicable. 

After logging in and navigating to subject company page, additional information can be accessed through corporate filings, listed below the background information. Each filing is listed with a description stating the information changed/added upon submission of that filing. Filings dating prior to approximately 2002 will be available in a separate tab entitled "Archived files", if applicable - open the "Publication" file to see all filings with changes to company data since incorporation (and ignore the arbitrary date of "1950"). Click the "pdf" icon next to each filing to access it, and it will open in a new browser page. The site only permits a user to access one filing at once.

Filings are published in French (with German translation), and cannot be machine translated in the page due to the pdf format (try Google Translate mobile app through camera), but in a relatively intuitive submission form format. Annual accounts of international companies may be submitted in both French and English. Note the following non-standard translations of filing descriptions:

*''Exercise from [date] to [date]'' = the company's annual accounts for that period
*''social capital / social funds'' = changes to share capital (and sometimes ownership)
*''associates'' = owners
*''social object'' = company activity
*''administrators/managers'' = statutory directors / board members
*''daily management delegates'' = executives (usually CEO or Managing Director only)
*''registration'' = incorporation

The RCS also offers an extract of current data on a company for EUR 12.20. As of January 2024, the author of this guide has never had cause to spend this money, and is unaware of the extract's contents. However, given the general similarities between the Luxembourgish and French corporate filing systems, the author proposes that the information available may broadly match extracts available from the [http://3.142.143.3:4001/index.php/France#Commercial_Court_Registry_Database '''French Commercial Court Register'''].

The aforementioned Electronic Compendium of Companies and Associations also provides access to company filings, with the same information as given in the RCS. Alongside providing information on non-business entities, its main difference from the RCS is that its name search function returns all filings from companies whose name matches the search term.

Additional corporate registry resources include:
* [https://memorialc.public.lu/ Archive] of corporate announcements (not filings) published between 1997 and 2016. Receptive to site search - making it the only option for reverse director searches. Results are delivered as French-language pdfs with announcement text, brief description of changes.
* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?LUXEMBOURG&member=1 European Commission E-Justice (Luxembourg)]  (''pub'')
* [https://www.lbr.lu/mjrcs/jsp/IndexActionNotSecured.action?time=1553687414220 Luxembourg Business Registry]  (''pub'', ''paid'')
* [https://ebr.bundesanzeiger-datenser... European Business Register (Luxembourg) via] the Bundesanzeiger Verlag (''pub'', ''paid'', ''reg'')
* [http://www.legilux.public.lu/entr/s... Legilux - official judicial portal] of the Government of Luxembourg (''pub'')

'''Ownership'''

To identify a company's ownership, check '''all''' (or at least several) corporate filings bearing the "associates" description. These only present information on what was changed upon the announcement - note that this can be just a change to an individual shareholder's information (e.g. change of address). Previously-existing shareholdings omitted from a given filing will not have changed, and you will need to check previous (sometimes several) "associates" filings to identify other information; if in doubt, check how much share capital the company declared in its most recent annual report, and compare this with all known shareholdings. In cases of a change in ownership, the previous owner will be shown in strikethrough (in recent, non-archived filings) in the submission form. Also check the filings described as "social capital", as these may involve changes in existing shareholders' relative stakes. Both "associates" and "social capital" filings will present details on the change first in a submission form format, and further down include the full original corporate announcement on the change, which will describe the process and potentially rationale behind the change (but will likely limit itself to describing the ownership change only, not the full ownership structure). Such announcements (usually written in French, but sometimes in English) may also give the company's full statutes, which can give useful background information.

If there are no "associates" filings, check the first "registration" filing, which will identify the company's owners upon incorporation - but only in the section of the filing giving the original corporate announcement. If the company was incorporated before ~2002, its initial incorporation filing will be available from the "Publication" file under the "Archived files" tab. Ordinarily, the announcement will begin by stating that "on [date], before [Notary name] appeared Shareholder X and Shareholder Y... to request the formation of a company between them", then give the company's statutes, and after the statutes present a table or list of initial share capital subscriptions. After collecting initial shareholding information in this manner, be sure to then work forward and check for changes to share capital which might affect the initial ownership structure. 

Filings give natural persons' (owners and directors) full name, contact address, and date and place of birth (but not citizenship - although company establishment announcements sometimes give foreign direct shareholders' passport numbers, and also sometimes occupation). Luxembourgish corporate shareholders and directors are identified by their name and ID number. For foreign corporate shareholders and directors, the RCS gives name, country of registry, ID number, entity type, and address; note that these details' veracity can only be guaranteed as of the date of filing.


'''Directorship'''

Directorship searches are not available. Check a company's "administrators/managers" and "daily management delegates" filings to identify principals. Note that these will be submitted if a principal's data (e.g. address) changes, not just if a new person is appointed. The one-page form of information given on a principal will indicate their date of appointment at the bottom - but, if the principal was appointed for a fixed term, the appointment date indicated may actually be the date the position was most recently renewed, so it is worth checking historic records as well to confirm.

'''However''', while no specific directorship search is available, some historic information is available from archives of ''Mémorial C'', the corporate announcements section of the Luxembourg Gazette, which was discontinued in June 2016 and replaced with the Electronic Compendium of Companies and Associations referenced above. A digitised archive of announcements dated 1996-2016 is hosted on '''https://memorialc.public.lu/''' which is receptive to Chrome site search. No alternative is available for filings dating since 2016.


'''Insolvency'''

The RCS manages Luxembourg's Insolvency Register, which maintains details on corporate entities only. Every month, the RCS publishes a list of insolvencies recorded in the previous period. Archives are not available. However, if a company is currently in insolvency, this will be displayed prominently on its RCS profile page. 

A "negative certification", checking for historic insolvencies, on a subject company may be ordered for EUR 4.50.

* [https://www.lbr.lu/mjrcs/jsp/DisplayCourtOrderActionNotSecured.action?FROM_LANGUAGE_CHANGE=true&CURRENT_TIMESTAMP_ID=&FROM_MENU=true&currentMenuLabel=menu.item.courtorder&time=1630056293586 The Luxembourg Business Register publishes] lists of company bankruptcies, liquidations and administrations monthly (''pub'')

litigation.wiki_content:
Luxembourg has a single source for litigation records - the [https://justice.public.lu/fr/jurisprudence/jurisprudence-judoc.html '''JUDOC'''] database maintained by the Ministry of Justice.

The database has several more specific search functions, providing access to decisions from the:

*[https://justice.public.lu/fr/jurisprudence/juridictions-judiciaires.html '''Civil courts'''] 
*[https://justice.public.lu/fr/jurisprudence/juridictions-administratives.html '''Administrative courts'''] (full anonymised decisions)
*[https://justice.public.lu/fr/jurisprudence/cour-constitutionnelle.html '''Constitutional Court''']
*[https://justice.public.lu/fr/jurisprudence/cour-cassation.html '''Court of Cassation''']
*[https://justice.public.lu/fr/jurisprudence/conseil-superieur-securite-sociale.html '''Higher Social Security Council''']

However, decisions are pseudonymized in line with GDPR. Additionally, decisions are not systematically published.

* [https://justice.public.lu/fr/jurisprudence.html This page allows you to] consult court decisions rendered by various courts including the Constitutional Court (''pub'')

Luxembourg Supreme Court judgements are also published on the [https://juricaf.org/recherche/+/facet_pays%3ALuxembourg '''Juricaf'''] international database of francophone supreme court judgements.

* [http://www.juricaf.org Database of case law in] French providing the decisions of supreme courts across the French speaking world (''pub'')

===Criminal Records===

Criminal litigation is not publicly accessible. 

Both legal entities and natural persons can request a criminal record check from the [https://guichet.public.lu/fr/organismes/organismes_citoyens/parquet-general/casier-judiciaire.html '''Criminal Records Service'''].

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://www.ur.gov.lv/en/ The Register of Enterprises of the Republic of Latvia] (''pub'', ''reg'')

Official corporate registry.

[https://info.ur.gov.lv/#/data-search Register of Enterprises] (''priv'')

Latvia's '''Register of Enterprises''' provides access to a consolidated database of entities, including associations and foundations, public organisations, religious organisations and relation institutions, representative offices, public persons and authorities, political parties and organisations, and trade unions.

However, only very limited data (registration number, registration date, address and an inidicative list of filings) is available openly. '''Access to advanced data and filings is only possible by logging into the commercial register or Lursoft with eID or Latvian bank account login credentials.'''

[https://www.lursoft.lv/ Lursoft] (''priv'')
 
The '''Lursoft''' database (provided by a private company) is the best one-stop shop for corporate data and information on Latvian businesses and individuals, consolidated from various databases. Current and historical information regarding rightholders (companies, associations, etc.), natural persons or legal documents, as well as statements that such information has not been entered, amended, or registered or the relevant documents have not been filed, is in most cases available. 

One can search with a subject's personal ID number and will get all current and historical data - this includes current and historical positions, membership, beneficial ownership, marriage contracts, commercial pledges - and one will also be able to get data on hits in sanctions lists, driving licenses, revoked powers, verification of power of attorney (Power of attorney register), inheritance register and publications (corporate news, media coverage). 

The range of documents available (if submitted) includes:
*registration certificates of foreign companies
*protocols/decisions of a company/organisation
*annual reports (full)
*decisions of a prosecuting authority (police letters, letters from the prosecutor's office)
*bank statements or other documents regarding the payment of equity
*memorandum of association 
*shareholders' registration
*auditor's reports
*appraisal reports
*articles of association
*amendments to the articles of association
*plans for the division of assets of the company
*receipts on the publication and 
*list of members of the board / supervisory board
*notice of resignation of a member of the board / supervisory board
*registration certificates 
*orders/request/cover notes of court bailiffs 
*statement regarding beneficial owners
*power of attorney, act of empowerment
*consent of a member of the board / executive director
*statement of the board regarding payment of equity
*consent of members of the supervisory board
*decisions/letters/protocols of public notaries
*reorganisation agreements / draft agreements, amendments of the drafts
*regulations for the increase/reduction of the equity
 
Note: the publications search portal directs through News.lv, which in some instances provides also the personal ID numbers of mentioned individuals (though not in all cases). litigation.wiki_content:
Litigation records are available through various sources in Morocco.

===Federal Judiciary===

The courts in Morocco are divided into several levels:

1. '''Supreme Court of Morocco''' - The highest court, composed of justices.
2. '''Appeals Courts''' - Spread across various geographic areas.
3. '''District Courts''' - Handle federal cases including civil, criminal, and administrative matters.

===Key Resources for Litigation Searches===

* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Paid service providing limited case docket information.
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Google site search required for all subjects.
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Use the site's internal search bar.
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Subscription required for internal searches.
* [http://www.coursupreme.ma/en/default.asp Supreme Court of Morocco with] searchable court decisions (primarily in Arabic) (''pub'')
* [http://www.mahakim.ma/Ar/Annonces/RechercherAnnonces/?Page=AnnoncesJudiciaires Justice portal displaying case law] with search by date for cases of courts of first instance and commercial courts (''pub'')
* [http://www.jurisprudence.ma/ Private subscription based service offering] access to judgements from various courts (''paid'', ''reg'')
* [http://www.juricaf.org/recherche_av Juricaf database of case law] in French providing decisions of supreme courts across the French speaking world (''pub'')
* [http://www.jurisprudence.ma/recherc Moroccan Jurisprudence Portal with case] search and keyword search providing full records on click through (''pub'')

===State-Specific Judiciary Searches===

Each state in Morocco has its own judiciary system. The judiciary websites for each state provide search functionalities for local cases. Examples include:

* '''Judiciary of Casablanca'''
* '''Judiciary of Rabat'''
* '''Judiciary of Marrakech'''
* '''Judiciary of Fes'''

(Refer to each state's judiciary website for specific search instructions).
