corporate_registry.wiki_content:
Various sources of corporate records are available in Morocco.

===National Enterprise Register===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

Morocco's National Enterprise Register is managed at the national level by the relevant government body. The search engine supports searches by company name, number, and other characteristics. Company pages on the Enterprise Register give basic information, including those listed below. Directors, other principals, and UBOs (where disclosed as required) are identified, with the DOBs of directors and UBOs given.

* Name
* Corporate ID
* Activity
* Entity type
* Share capital
* Wholly-owned (Y/N)
* Branch registrations
* Date of registration with its current commercial court

Note: The company's date of ''registration'' may not be its date of ''incorporation''. Look for a date of activity commencement or historical filings to check.

===Commercial Court Registry Database===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

The older corporate database, maintained by the Commercial Court Registries. Compared to the National Enterprise Register, this database may only offer corporate filings for a fee. However, it does offer various company details for free, including those listed below. Directors and other principals are listed.

* Address
* Trade name
* Legal form
* Last year's turnover (where declared)
* Activity
* Branch registrations
* Date of registration at the current Commercial Court

Further detailed documents may be obtained for a fee. The most useful of these are individual filings and annual accounts.

===Commercial Gazette Records===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

The Official Bulletin of Announcements regularly publishes announcements that companies are required to make on changes made. It may be searched by company name or ID, and also by keyword, which can identify directors.

===Free Corporate Filings===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

This database provides basic identity data on companies and, if available, a table presenting details from their most recent accounts. Further down the company page, a list of the company's corporate announcements is given. Beyond the corporate announcements, the database lists the company's corporate filings and makes them available for free download.

===Associations and Foundations===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

The Official Journal publishes announcements by associations and foundations (charities).

===Note on Identifying Ownership===

Ownership identification can be complex in Morocco. Always check a public company's accounts first to save time.

Moroccan companies declare changes in ownership in individual filings to the corporate registries. These filings are available through the '''National Enterprise Register''', '''Commercial Court Registry Database''' (for a fee), and '''Free Corporate Filings''' (overall best option). Scrolling down the list of filings, look for ones described as a change to share capital. Typically, these will consist of notes on a company shareholder meeting detailing the change, and then updated company statutes.

===Directorships===

Directorship searches are available through all of the official corporate records sources listed above, namely:

* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - search by name, surname, and birthdate through the Advanced Search
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - search by name, surname through the Advanced Search
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - search director's "[surname, name]" as a keyword
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Provides a surname/name search for directors and sole partnerships.

Note that while a register of disqualified directors exists in Morocco, it is not publicly accessible.

===Additional Corporate Registry Resources===

* [https://www.directinfo.ma/ Moroccan Office of Industrial and] Commercial Property database search function covering companies and trademarks with basic company data available for free (''pub'', ''paid'')

* [http://www.ammc.ma/en Moroccan Authority of Capital Markets] with issuer information, management details, incorporation data, shareholder and financial information (''pub'')

* [http://www.directinfo.ma/ Database of companies searchable by] company name, patent, design and other keywords (''pub'', ''paid'')

* [http://www.mahakim.ma/Ar/Services/RC/?Page=RC Moroccan e-justice portal offering limited] corporate data with searches requiring selection of the correct commercial court (''pub'')

* [https://servicesenligne.justice.gov.ma/Home/Index Ministry of Justice corporate extracts] providing basic corporate data including personal details of directors (''pub'', ''paid'')

* [http://www.casablanca-bourse.com Casablanca Stock Exchange]  (''pub'')

litigation.wiki_content:
Litigation records are available through various sources in Moldova.

===Supreme Court Judgements===

[http://cauta.csj.md/cedo/ac-admin/#/app Supreme Court of Justice Judgements Database] (''pub'')
This resource provides access to a broad range of civil and criminal decisions from Moldova's Supreme Court of Justice. Note that individual litigant details may be anonymized for privacy reasons.

===Additional Supreme Court Decisions===

[http://www.lex.md/ Lex.md] (''pub'')
A paid-access database offering supplementary supreme court decisions, though access is restricted.

===Court of Audit Judgements===

[http://ccrm.md/ Court of Audit of Moldova] (''pub'')
This portal publishes judgments and audit reports, including cases related to corruption and financial oversight of banks and firms.

===Constitutional Court===

[http://www.constcourt.md/ Constitutional Court of Moldova] (''pub'')
The Constitutional Court's database provides access to decisions, opinions, and complaints dating from 1995, available in Romanian, Russian, and English.

===State Registry of Judicial Acts===

The State Registry of Judicial Acts of the Republic of Moldova contains official civil and criminal court records and other legislative information. Searches can be performed by area, name, or offense.

===Chisinau Court of Appeal===

[https://cac.instante.justice.md/ Chisinau Court of Appeal] (''pub'')
This resource offers a searchable database of appellate court decisions from Chisinau.

===District and Regional Courts===

Numerous district and regional courts across Moldova—such as those in Balti, Bender, Cahul, and other localities—maintain searchable databases of their decisions, covering a wide array of civil and criminal cases.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
* '''Central Register of Economic Entities (CRPS)''' – [http://www.pretraga.crps.me:8083/ Central Register of Economic Entities] (official name: Central Register of Business Entities of Montenegro).  This register, maintained by the Tax Administration, is the primary source for corporate information in Montenegro.  It provides details on company incorporation, legal form, registration number, business activity and historical data.  The system offers an “Advanced Search” that allows queries by company name or registration number, and a “Lice” search bar to look up directors or shareholders by personal ID number.  Access is free but may require knowledge of Montenegrin.

* '''Central Securities Depository and Clearing Company (CDA)''' – [http://www.cda.me/EN/Pages/Naslovna.aspx Central Securities Depository] (currently inaccessible).  The CDA maintains the registry of shareholders for all publicly traded companies.  Users can search by company ID to obtain the company name, address, share capital and list of registered shareholders.  Some sections of the site may require registration.

* '''Montenegro Stock Exchange – Podgorica (Montenegrobberza)''' – [https://mnse.me/ Montenegro stock exchange].  The exchange publishes real-time trading data, company reports and shareholder information.  The homepage displays stock indices (MNSE 10 and MONEX), market capitalisation, daily trading tables and lists of winners and losers; it also links to financial and audit reports and corporate news.  Investors can access issuer reports, ownership details and headline financial figures for each listed company.

* '''Montenegro Stock Exchange – NEX''' – [http://www.montenegroberza.com/code/navigate.asp?Id=87 Montenegro Stock Exchange].  The Podgorica and NEX exchanges have merged under the MNSE name.  Historical links may still exist.

The portal is primarily in Montenegrin and may require registration for full access.

=== Court System in Madagascar ===
Madagascar has a hierarchical court system that includes courts of first instance, appellate courts, and the Supreme Court. Information on litigation cases can be found through the official court records.

[http://justice.mg/ Madagascar Judiciary]

* [http://www.saflii.org/content/madagascar-index Southern African Legal Information Institute] - database of decisions from the Madagascan Constitutional Court (''pub'')

* [https://juricaf.org/recherche/+/facet_pays:Madagascar Over 3,000 judgements by the] Supreme Court (''pub'')

* [http://www.juricaf.org/recherche_av Database of case law in] French providing decisions of supreme courts across the French speaking world (''pub'')

=== Supreme Court of Madagascar ===
Conduct the internal Supreme Court Search and a Google Site search in both Malagasy and French. Note that the internal search requires a case number.

=== International Criminal Court ===
Conduct an internal and site search for your subject with the ICC. This is important in case your subject is a hold-over from past regimes.

=== African Court on Human and Peoples' Rights ===
Conduct a site search in addition to running a page find search of the following tabs:
- Latest Decisions
- Finalized Decisions
- Pending Decisions

=== WorldLII ===
Conduct internal and Google site searches in both Malagasy and French.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
Various sources of corporate records are available in Mexico.

===National Enterprise Register===

'''[https://data.inpi.fr/ Registro Público de Comercio (RPC)]'''

Mexico's National Enterprise Register is managed at the state level by the Public Registry of Commerce (RPC). The search engine supports searches by company name, number (RFC), and other characteristics. A search by director name is also available. Company pages on the Enterprise Register give basic information, including those listed below. Directors, other principals (e.g., secretaries, auditors), and UBOs (where disclosed as required) are identified, with the DOBs of directors and UBOs given.

* Name
* Corporate ID
* Activity
* Entity type
* Share capital
* Wholly-owned (Y/N)
* Branch registrations
* Date of registration with its current commercial court

Note: The company's date of ''registration'' may not be its date of ''incorporation''. Look for a date of activity commencement or historical filings to check.

'''[https://rpc.economia.gob.mx/siger2/xhtml/login/login.xhtml Registro Público de Comercio (SIGER)]'''

After registering, the website allows to search for company information according to the name of the company, its partners or the FME number (Folio Mercantil Electrónico). (''pub'', ''paid'', ''reg'')

===Commercial Court Registry Database===

'''[https://www.buholegal.com/ Buho Legal]'''

Buho Legal is a legal records research service that provides access to limited information about Mexican subjects' litigation history. Buho Legal's reports are not comprehensive as they usually provide only snapshots of case dockets and no complaints or final judgment documents. The information provided by Buho Legal (dates of filing parties, case descriptions, case status) should be used to write brief case summaries that are supplemented where possible by information identified in targeted media and government portal searches.

===Commercial Gazette Records===

'''[https://www.dof.gob.mx/ Diario Oficial de la Federación (DOF)]'''

The Official Gazette of the Federation (DOF) is Mexico's official journal and regularly publishes announcements that companies are required to make on changes made. It may be searched by company name or ID (RFC), and also by keyword, which can identify directors.

===Free Corporate Filings===

'''[https://www.sayari.com/ Sayari Graph]'''

Sayari Graph provides comprehensive information on Mexican companies, including their Constitution of Society and company records from the Mexico Public Registries of Commerce. These records include the most up-to-date share capital, officer, and ownership information available.

===Associations and Foundations===

'''[https://www.gob.mx/indesol Comisión de Fomento de las Actividades de las Organizaciones de la Sociedad Civil (CFOSC)]'''

The CFOSC is an interagency government organization that regulates civil societies, civil associations, and other NGOs. The Civil Society Search maintained by the CFOSC provides basic identification information for an NGO including date of registration, status, and a disciplinary record.

===Additional Corporate Resources===

'''[https://www.gob.mx/compranet/acciones-y-programas/registro-unico-de-proveedores-y-contratistas-rupc Registro Único de Proveedores y Contratistas]'''

The complete and updated list of suppliers and contractors registered with the government. (''pub'')

'''[http://cnet.hacienda.gob.mx/servicios/consultaRUPC.jsf Single Registry of Suppliers and Contractors (RUPC)]'''

Search portal for government suppliers and contractors. (''pub'')

'''[https://siem.gob.mx/consulta/ SIEM (Sistema de Información Empresarial Mexicano)]'''

Access to basic contact information, addresses, and commercial activities of companies. (''pub'')

'''[http://www.bmv.com.mx/ Mexico Stock Exchange]'''

List of all issuers and basic company information. (''pub'')

'''[https://psm.economia.gob.mx/PSM/inicioPSM.jsf Ministry of Economy website]'''

Offers access to official announcements from companies. (''pub'')

'''[https://psm.economia.gob.mx/PSM/busqueda_resultados.jsf Search for dissolution and liquidation announcements]'''

Search portal for company dissolution and liquidation notices. (''pub'')

'''[http://www.tuempresa.gob.mx/mua/bus... Tu Empresa]'''

Allows you to search for previously registered company names in Mexico. (''pub'')

'''[http://cnet.funcionpublica.gob.mx/s... CompraNet]'''

Data portal from the Ministry of Public Administration with information on registered providers and contractors. (''pub'')

===Note on Identifying Ownership===

Ownership identification can be complex in Mexico. Always check a public company's accounts first to save time.

Mexican companies declare changes in ownership in individual filings to the corporate registries. These filings are available through the '''National Enterprise Register''', '''Buho Legal''' (for a fee), and '''Sayari Graph''' (overall best option). Scrolling down the list of filings, look for ones described as a change to share capital. Typically, these will consist of notes on a company shareholder meeting detailing the change, and then updated company statutes. If you are (very) lucky, the meeting notes will give an ownership breakdown. However, it is more likely that the change in share capital (and new/departing owners) will be described, but without a description of the status quo pre-change. You will need to work backward (and often forward from the founding statutes) to identify this. If your subject is described as having a sole shareholder, immediately move on to checking the sole shareholder's filings to identify ownership.

===Directorships===

Directorship searches are available through all of the official corporate records sources listed above, namely:

* '''[https://www.buholegal.com/ Buho Legal]''' - search by name, surname, and mm/yyyy of birth through the Advanced Search
* '''[https://www.sayari.com/ Sayari Graph]''' - search by name, surname through the Advanced Search
* '''[https://www.dof.gob.mx/ Diario Oficial de la Federación]''' - search director's "[surname, name]" as a keyword
* '''Registro Público de Comercio (RPC)''' - Provides a surname/name search for directors and sole partnerships.

Note that while a register of disqualified directors (''Fichero Nacional de Directores Descalificados'') exists in Mexico, maintained by the National Council of Commercial Court Clerks, it is not publicly accessible.

litigation.wiki_content:
Mexican litigation records are not systematically published, and names of individual parties are widely anonymized. Criminal cases are least publicized of all, but cases of public interest may be covered in the press.

===Federal Judiciary===

The courts in Mexico are divided into several levels:

1. '''Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation (SCJN)''' - Mexico's highest court, composed of eleven justices.
2. '''Circuit Courts''' - Spread across 32 geographic areas called judicial circuits, with collegiate (three magistrates) and unitary (one magistrate) courts.
3. '''District Courts''' - Handle federal cases including civil, criminal, and administrative matters. Specialized courts exist in major cities.

===Key Resources for Litigation Searches===

* '''[https://www.buholegal.com/ Buho Legal]''' - Paid service providing limited case docket information.
* '''[https://www.cjf.gob.mx/ Council of the Federal Judiciary (CJF)]''' - Google site search required for all subjects.
* '''[https://www.tfja.gob.mx/ Federal Tax and Administration Court (TFJA)]''' - Use the site's internal search bar.
* '''[https://www.poderjudicialvirtual.com/ PoderJudicialVirtual.com]''' - Subscription required for internal searches.

===State-Specific Judiciary Searches===

Each state in Mexico has its own judiciary system. The judiciary websites for each state provide search functionalities for local cases. Examples include:

* '''Judiciary of Aguascalientes'''
* '''Judiciary of Baja California'''
* '''Judiciary of Baja California del Sur'''
* '''Judiciary of Campeche'''
* '''Judiciary of Chiapas'''
* '''Judiciary of Chihuahua'''

(Refer to each state's judiciary website for specific search instructions).

===Federal Judiciary===

The courts in Mozambique are divided into several levels:

1. '''Supreme Court of Mozambique''' - The highest court, composed of justices.
2. '''Appeals Courts''' - Spread across various geographic areas.
3. '''District Courts''' - Handle federal cases including civil, criminal, and administrative matters.

===Key Resources for Litigation Searches===

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
- [https://www.kvk.nl Dutch Chamber of Commerce]  
  Type in your company or its registration number in the search bar. Select one of the following products:
  - Uittreksel: Provides information about registration (section "Rechtspersoon") offices ("Vestiging") managers including their birth date and year, title, and profession ("Bestuurders"), and plenipotentiary of the firm. Costs EUR 2.30. Select for smaller inquiries.
  - Bedrijfsprofiel: Very detailed; has all the information from the Uittreksel plus history (e.g., former names, managers, sole shareholders, as well as their tenure), annual reports, deposits, and concern relations if applicable. Costs between EUR 2.65 and EUR 9.50 depending on what information is available. Select for Smartsource and ICV.

- [https://www.kvk.nl/producten-bestellen/ Kamer van Koophandel - Official] Corporate Registry with company profiles, management, excerpts, and ownership information (pub, paid)

  This is a free text search of the Dutch Staatscourant, the official gazette. Run an internal site search.

- [https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/zoeken/zoeken.do Official Notices Search]  
  This searches a number of publications by the Dutch government, including several Gazettes. Searching this site can yield important corporate and directorship info for your subjects as well as possible enforcement/notices etc. Run an internal site search.

- [https://opencorporates.com OpenCorporates]  
  See instructions in Global Databases & Sources.

- [https://www.aex.nl Dutch Stock Exchange]  
  Conduct an internal and site search.

- [https://www.opencorporates.com/charities OpenCorporates Charity]  
  Internal search bar. It has added the Netherlands Register of Charities (Public Benefit Institutions or Algemeen Nut Beogende Instelling - ANBI) to its database, which brings over 50,000 charity records.

- [https://www.anbi.nl ANBI]  
  Additional information about the non-profit can be found through the ANBI portal if the non-profit has a profile. Profile is not guaranteed: ANBI requires non-profits to be a member and have a registration number with the Dutch Chamber of Commerce.

- [https://www.government.nl/topics/contracts-with-the-central-government Government Contracts]  
  There is no comprehensive database with information about all existing government contracts ("Rijkscontracten"). However, a digital register can be obtained with information about contracts that fall under category management of the government. Companies are listed that provide goods and services such as clothing, catering, and office supplies. Download the PDF Document "Rijkscontracten". Please note that the list refers to the company through its registration number. It is advised to determine your company's registration number with the Dutch Register of Commerce (Kamer van Koophandel) and subsequently search the register for that number in the PDF Document.

litigation.wiki_content:
In the course of our investigation, we conducted searches of available litigation records in the Netherlands including records from the Supreme Court (Hoge Raad); Council of State (Raad van State)[1]; Central Board of Appeal (Centrale Raad van Beroep);[2] Trade Union Appeals Board (College van Beroep voor het bedrijfsleven);[3] the Constitutional Court of Sint Maarten (Constitutioneel hof van Sint Maarten);[4] and courts in Amsterdam, the Hague, Gelderland, Limburg, Central Netherlands, Northern Netherlands, East Brabant, Overijssel, Rotterdam and Zeeland-West Brabant.
 
We note that litigation records in the Netherlands are typically anonymised and not accessible to third parties. Therefore, our search cannot be considered comprehensive.
 
[1] A constitutionally established advisory board to the Dutch government, the Council of State serves as one of the four highest courts of appeal in administrative matters.
[2] The higher court of appeal on administrative matters.
[3] An appeal court specialising in socio-economic aspects of administrative law.
[4] The only constitutional court in the Netherlands.

- [http://www.rechtspraak.nl De Rechtspraak]  
  All subjects - Search general court opinions for Netherlands. Use this first for litigation search. Search the provided keyword field. This is a general litigation search that covers High Courts, Supreme Court, Council of State, Appeals, Civil/Criminal.

- [https://uitspraken.rechtspraak.nl/ Dutch Court Decisions Database -] Keyword-based search of court pronunciations (pub)

- [https://www.rechtspraak.nl/Zoeken/Paginas/default.aspx?k=a Justice website with advanced search] options by district courts or courts of appeal (pub)

- [https://www.rechtsorde.nl/#uitgelicht Private case law service including] all case law from Rechtspraak and other sources (paid, reg)

- [https://www.rechtspraak.nl/English/NCC/Pages/default.aspx Netherlands Commercial Court]
  All subjects - Go to the hearings and judgments tab to conduct this search. Please look for your subject through the Hearing List.

- [https://www.politie.nl Netherlands National Police]  
  Individuals - This is the website of the Dutch National Police. The site contains information on crimes and investigations. Conduct internal and site search. Search the wanted persons list.

- [http://ec.europa.eu/competition/elojade/isef/index.cfm European Competition Commission Case Search]  
  All subjects - This is the competition case search for the European Commission.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://www.brreg.no/ Business Registration Center]

Login: Saved in Zoho

Required for Companies

The Brønnøysund Register Center is the centralized, and official, registration center for all Norwegian or foreign companies registered in Norway. You will be required to login to order statements such as financial statements and/or yearly reports, etc. These documents are free of charge. Once the documents have been ordered, they will be sent to the email address registered in the Brønnøysund website. Please ask a supervisor to forward these documents to you. 

How to search for a company:

Put the name of the company (the Norwegian characters as well as the English characters) in the field 'Navn' or VAT number in the field "Organisasjonsnummer" and press "SØK". Click on the searched company name to obtain registry information.

Once you have found the company you are searching for, click on it (it should be highlighted in blue), then scroll down to the bottom of the page. Under 'Flere opplysninger om enheten' (more details about the entity), click on the type of document/s required. These ones are useful:
'Utskrifter og attester' (print outs and certifications) will give you annual reports and financial statements.

'Kunngjøringer' will give you corporate annoucements such as change in company name, capital and/or change in the company's board of directors, etc.

[https://w2.brreg.no/enhet/sok/ The Brønnøysund Register Centre Company] Search - Official Norwegian Register for Legal Entities (''pub'', ''reg'')

[http://w2.brreg.no/kunngjoring/index.jsp?spraak=en The Brønnøysund Register Centre Gazette] - Registry entries, annual accounts, board and auditor reports (''pub'')

Search announcements published by the by the Norwegian Register of Business Enterprises, Register of Company Accounts and Register of Bankruptcies. The Database is maintained by the official Brønnøysund Register Centre. You can search both current and deleted companies by company name or company number.​

[http://www.bdb.no/ Bedriftsdatabasen] - Aggregate database for directorship and ownership information

This is a useful aggregate database for directorship and ownership information.

[https://www.proff.no/ Proff]

This is a business finder.

[http://www.proff.no/ Third-party website for company connections] and relations between board members, managing directors and stock owners (''reg'')

[https://www.purehelp.no/m/ Purehelp]

This source is useful for finding information on Norwegian companies and individuals. Enter your subject's name in the search bar at the top of the page.

[https://www.purehelp.no Information on Norwegian companies and] individuals

[https://www.regnskapstall.no/ Search Engine for Aggregated Company Information]

This search is useful for finding financial information on Norwegian companies. Enter your company's name or organizational number in the search bar in the middle of the page.

[https://www.regnskapstall.no Search engine for aggregated financial] information on Norwegian companies

[https://www.aksjeeiere.no/ Norwegian Shareholder Search] - only available in Norway: use VPN

Required for Individuals/Companies

This is a search for shareholders of Norwegian companies and should be conducted even if your subject is a company in order to ascertain its owners.​

The page contains only data that was registered in the Shareholder Register on 31.12 in 2014 , 2015, and 2016. Changes in ownership after this date are not included, and the data thus does not necessarily provide a correct picture of today's ownership. Only data that is made available for access by the Tax Administration is searchable on this page.​

[https://www.aksjeeiere.no/ Norwegian Shareholder Search - Data] from the Shareholder Register (''pub'')

[https://opencorporates.com/companies/no?q= OpenCorporates – Norway]

Not Required – Recommended for Companies & Directors

This is a corporate aggregator website, which should be run if you were unable to identify your company via official records. Often, this site will have a url that directs you to the official corporate registry page if it exists. It is also useful for identifying prior directorships of individuals.

[https://ebr.bundesanzeiger-verlag.de/european-business-register/unternehmenssuche/ European Business Register (Norway)]

Norwegian corporate registry via the European Business Registry (EBR) on the website of theBundesanzeiger Verlag. Supports search by country and company name. Can retrieve name and city of companies registered in Norway. Registration and payment is required to access more information.

* [https://consultafallos.organojudicial.gob.pa/_index.php Panamanian Judicial Organ: Automated Judicial Management System] Search for court cases by party name, alongside other data. The database search accepts certain Boolean operators. Note that the Judicial Organ website also publishes case reports from a monthly bulletin (2010-21 available as of May 2025) and other assorted sources. It is unclear whether these results are also available through the Judicial Management System. The Judicial Organ web domain is receptive to site search, so it's best to run both a site search and Judicial Management System database search.

The Judicial Management System publishes selected rulings issued by the Supreme Court of Justice and Superior Tribunal, including the latter's specialised chambers for appeal, labour, maritime and family cases. The database includes selected civil and criminal judgements issued since 1993. Research in May 2025 indicated that litigation records on cases examined by Panama's regional-level Circuit Courts and first-instance Municipal Courts is not available online.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
In the Philippines, official records for corporations and partnerships can be obtained through the [https://www.sec.gov.ph/online-services/sec-express-system/ '''Securities and Exchange Commission's Express System'''] website. 

Official records for corporations and partnerships are available through the [https://www.sec.gov.ph/online-services/sec-express-system/ '''Securities and Exchange Commission's Express System'''] website. However, reverse directorship checks are not available in the Philippines.
For corporations and partnerships, you can order General information sheets which include information such as dates of incorporation, identities of directors and shareholders, subsidiaries, and contact information.

To identify a company's ownership, check all corporate filings bearing the "associates" description. These only present information on what was changed upon the announcement - note that this can be just a change to an individual shareholder's information (e.g. change of address). Previously-existing shareholdings omitted from a given filing will not have changed, and you will need to check previous (sometimes several) "associates" filings to identify other information.
If there are no "associates" filings, check the first "registration" filing, which will identify the company's owners upon incorporation.

These records can be paid for online using a credit card, but they cannot be viewed online. Instead, they are couriered to a physical address in the Philippines, which typically takes between 5-7 working days. Alternatively, you can schedule an appointment to pick them up in person at the SEC.

If you don't have someone in the Philippines who can receive, scan, and send these documents to you, you'll need to use a third-party provider.

For sole proprietorships, the only information you can check online is whether the business name has been registered. This can be done by starting the process of registering a new entity on the [https://bnrs.dti.gov.ph/ '''Department of Trade and Industry's Business Name Registration System'''] website.

Additional resources:
* [http://www.sec.gov.ph/online-services/search-registered-companies/ Securities and Exchange Commission Philippines] (''pub'')
* [https://bnrs.dti.gov.ph/search Business Name Registration Search (BNRS)] - Department of Trade and Industry (''pub'')
* [http://www.poea.gov.ph/cgi-bin/agli... Philippines Overseas Employment Administration -] Recruitment Agency Search (''pub'')

litigation.wiki_content:
The Philippine judiciary has four levels: Supreme Court, Court of Appeals, Regional Trial Courts, Municipal and Metropolitan Trial Courts. At equal rank with the Court of Appeals are the Court of Tax Appeals and the Sandiganbayan, which has jurisdiction over criminal and civil cases involving offences committed by public officers and employees (e.g. graft).

The [https://elibrary.judiciary.gov.ph/ '''e-Library of the Supreme Court'''] has a searchable database of decisions and its resolutions and those of the Court of Appeals. You have to make an account to search (it's free). The Supreme Court database goes back to 1996 and is fairly comprehensive, albeit with some holes. The Court of Appeals database only has partial records from 2006, 2013, 2014 and 2015.

The [http://ca.judiciary.gov.ph/ '''website of the Court of Appeals'''] has a searchable database of its decisions and resolutions. It is unclear how comprehensive it is and how far it goes back, however.

The [http://cta.judiciary.gov.ph/ '''website of the Court of Tax Appeals'''] has a searchable, comprehensive and up-to-date database of its decisions. It is unclear how far it goes back, however.

The [http://sb.judiciary.gov.ph/ '''website of the Sandiganbayan'''] has a searchable, comprehensive and up-to-date database of its decisions and resolutions going back to 2003.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
The official registry can be accessed [https://wyszukiwarka-krs.ms.gov.pl here]. It can't be searched by individuals' names, but otherwise it provides quite detailed information, including shareholders. To see the current information only, download a PDF of "Informacje aktualne". To see full historical information, download a PDF of "Informacje pełne". To navigate the historical extract, use the key at the start, which lists numbers alongside dates, corresponding to each time the registry information was changed.

There's also an official registry of beneficial ownership, which can be accessed [https://crbr.podatki.gov.pl/adcrbr/#/wyszukaj here]. You can enter a company's name to see its beneficiaries, and if you know an individual's PESEL (personal identification mumber), you can enter that and see all Polish companies of which they're a beneificiary. To find a person's PESEL, pull a corporate registry extract for any company of which they're a shareholder or director, and it will be listed by their name.

You can also use the third-party registry called [https://rejestr.io/ Rejestr.io]. Its main advantage is that it can be searched by an individual's name. Without a subscription, you can search an individual's name and see all their current affiliations. With a subscription, you can see their historical affiliations too. With a subscription, you can also download a company's annual financial reports (these should also be available from an official database, probably for free, so try to find that rather than buying a subscription just to get annual reports, and update the wiki if you find it). The subscription isn't too expensive and can be cancelled any time, so it can be worth paying for a month just for a single project (just remember to cancel before the month ends). You can also get a 14-day free trial, though you'll need to use a card that's never been used for this before.

===AI copypasta===

[https://rar.ms.gov.pl RAR registration browser]

Company registration filings can be accessed through a separate portal. These can be downloaded separately and provide a range of information disclosed to the court register. However, some filings are locked behind a court-authorised login system.

[https://wyszukiwarka-msig.ms.gov.pl MSIG gazette search]  

Search engine for gazette announcements. No information on a target found during testing.

[https://prod.ceidg.gov.pl CEIDG search]

Confusingly named the Central Registration and Information on Business Activity database, this source provides information on individuals registered as sole traders. Search by company name, name of individuals, registration number, taxpayer identification number and / or address to retrieve information.


[https://n23.infoveriti.pl/ Third-party corporate aggregator]

Third-party corporate aggregator provides a reverse directorship search which allows the user to specify age, in situations where a principal's DOB is known.

[https://www.gpw.pl/en-home Warsaw Stock Exchange]  

WSE is the only Polish stock exchange, established in 1991 by State Treasury. Company profiles include date of listing, share issuing, full name and address, names of board members and links to reports on corporate actions. The listings are searchable by full or partial company name.	

[https://wig.waw.pl The Warsaw Chamber of Commerce]

The Warsaw Chamber of Commerce publishes bulletins on the Polish private sector as well as a minimal membership directory, though little information is provided on member companies other than brief descriptions of their activities.

[http://www.monitorb.pl Monitor Polski B]

Monitor Polski B is an official outlet publishing financial statements of companies in Poland. Users can search for whether or not records exist by company name for free, but need to pay for the actual gazette content.

[https://biznes.pap.pl Info Strefa]

Info Strefa is an information portal providing news bulletins and details of official corporate actions by companies listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange. It is operated by the Polish Press Agency.

[https://newconnect.pl NewConnect]

NewConnect is an alternative share trading market supervised by the Warsaw Stock Exchange. Companies listed on the market can list shares at a lower cost and with a lower reporting burden than on the Warsaw Exchange. Company profiles include turnover, registered address, web address and name of chairman.

[http://stary.przeswietl.pl Prześwietl (X-ray)]

Privately-run company directory combining public registry information. Paid access required.

[https://spis.ngo.pl Poland NGO Database]

A database of Polish NGOs administered by the Maple/Sycamore Association (Stowarzyszenie Klon/Jawor). Organisation profile pages include the legal form, address, year of foundation, national register number, VAT number and, in some cases, board members.

[https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?POLAND&member=1 European Commission overview of Polish business registry]

The European Commission provides an overview of the Polish business registry system on its e-Justice portal.

litigation.wiki_content:
As of April 2025, it appears that the following official databases are available:

* Decision database for common courts (''sądy powszechne''): https://orzeczenia.ms.gov.pl/search/advanced
* Decision database for administrative courts (''sądy administracyjne''), including the Supreme Administrative Court (''Naczelny Sąd Administracyjny''): https://orzeczenia.nsa.gov.pl/cbo/query
* Decision database for the Supreme Court (''Sąd Najwyższy''): https://www.sn.pl/wyszukiwanie/SitePages/orzeczenia.aspx
* Sex offenders' register: https://rps.ms.gov.pl/pl-PL/Public#/home
* Insolvency register: https://krz.ms.gov.pl/#!/application/KRZPortalPUB/1.9/KrzPortalPubGui.StronaGlowna?params=JTdCJTdE&itemId=item-0&seq=0

However, apart from the insolvency register and the sex offenders' register, all of those databases have extensive anonymization. The specific rules of anonymization are:

* Individuals' names are replaced with their initials, '''unless''' the individuals are mentioned in the capacity of a public official, in which case there's no anonymization.
* Names of companies, co-operatives, organizations, associations, foundations, trade unions, churches, etc are completely redacted (only leaving entity suffixes like "SA" or "Sp. z o.o."), '''except''' for public bodies and other institutions performing public tasks, for which there's no anonymization.
* Personal identification numbers and company identification numbers of all types are completely redacted.
* Names of cities are replaced with their initials.
* For street names and similar, the main part of the name is redacted, leaving only words like "ulica" ("street").
* Other geographical names are completely redacted (e.g. vovoideships, rivers, city districts, etc).

* [https://www.risco.ro/business-dictionary/registrul-comertului Business Register (entity)] / [https://www.risco.ro/business-dictionary/registrul-comertului (individual)] (''pub'')

The Business Register is Romania's official portal providing details of all entrepreneurs, companies, and other legal entities. The Register is administered by the Ministry of Justice and is kept by the district courts.

Search by trade name [denumire comercială] or identification number [număr de identificare], registered office [sediu], reference number [număr de referință], or a person's surname/first name [nume și prenume persoană].

The Register provides dates of registered addresses of all officers.

* [http://www.snia.ro/Romanian/Search National Business Information System] - A search tool for business information in Romania, administered by the Romanian Chamber of Commerce. This source requires a login.

* [https://portal.onrc.ro ONRC] - Corporate registry in Romania. Users need an account in order to search. After the login, free information includes registration date, status of the company, registration number and full name as well as county. For further information a paid report can be ordered. Besides company registration information, you can also access the Insolvency Bulletin and search for names in it free of charge ('Persoane publicate în BPI').

* [https://www.bvb.ro/ Bucharest Stock Exchange] - Romanian national registry that allows you to see listed companies and find information on issuer profiles, trading info, financial data & calendar, info on shareholders and share capital changes.

* [http://www.bvb.ro/Companies/ListedCompanies.aspx Bucharest Stock Exchange - Listed] Companies (''pub'')

* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?ROMANIA&member=1 European Commission e-Justice] - European Commission overview of the Romanian business registry, including links to the registry, description of how to search and what can be found, as well as legislation behind it.

* [https://portal.onrc.ro/ONRCPortalWeb/ONRCPortal.portal Ministry of Justice] - Limited online search for companies is available. Full records are only available in person at the registry.

* [https://portal.onrc.ro/ONRCPortalWeb/appmanager/myONRC/public?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=login#wlp_login Romania Company and Insolvency Search]  (''pub'', ''reg'')

* [https://www.paginiaurii.ro/ Yellow Pages Romania] - The online Yellow Pages service for Romania.

* [https://www.listafirme.ro Romanian Companies] - In Romanian and English. Contains corporate contact details, searchable by name, region and domain. Insolvent companies are also searchable. Lists company name, registry number and fiscal code. Also information on profits and losses, and company rankings. Users need to pay to display information in full.

* [http://www.listafirme.ro/ Romanian Companies Database]  (''paid'')

* [https://www.stiri.ong/ Romanian NGO Database] - Stiriong.ro is a project developed by the Trust for Civil Society in Central and Eastern Europe. The site hosts a database of NGOs operating in Romania with basic profiles of their operations. Further details are available to registered users.

* [https://civilportal.ro/ Transylvanian Association of Hungarian Civil Organizations] - A database of Romanian NGOs based in Harghita county. The site lists the organisation's aims, owners and contact details. Hungarian and Romanian versions available.

* [https://civilportal.ro/ Non-Governmental Organizations Database]  (''pub'')

* [https://www.ebrd.com/ European Bank for Reconstruction and Development] - Database with projects of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD). Supports search by project ID or title keyword. Retrieves information about the date, project ID, country, project name, sector, public/private, and status. By clicking on the project name more information can be obtained (such as a description of the project, the client, environmental impact etc).

===Ownership===

In Romania, not all companies are required to disclose their shareholders. For joint stock companies with more than one shareholder, the shareholders are not disclosed in the commercial register. In these cases, information on the shareholders can only be accessed through the central securities depository by certain authorized persons, such as law enforcement, tax administration, and public bodies. Sole shareholders are disclosed.

* [https://www.onrc.ro/index.php/en/central-register-of-beneficial-owners UBO Register] - Information on who meets the criteria of a beneficial owner.

====Ultimate Beneficial Ownership====
Ultimate beneficial ownership may be found through the Register of Public Sector Partners (RPVS). RPVS is a legally established list of data on public sector partners, and these partners are obliged to provide information on all direct and indirect shareholders.

A public sector partner is a natural person, a natural person-entrepreneur, and a legal entity that receives from the state, local government, and other entities of the public sector monetary payment or property above the limit specified by law.

Public sector partners are required to register with an authorized person who performs all actions related to the RPVS on behalf of the public sector partner.

===Directorship===

* Available
* Reverse: yes

===Company Types===

====Limited Liability Company (s.r.l.)====
One of the most common types of companies in Romania is the limited liability company. Such types of Romanian companies must be formed with a minimum investment of RON 200. A minimum of one shareholder and one director are essential for forming a limited liability company in Romania. The shareholders may be either natural persons or corporations. An s.r.l.'s shareholders assume limited responsibility for the organization, meaning they are not personally liable for the various monetary loans or liabilities of the corporation.

====Joint Stock Company (S.A.)====
A JSC's stockholders have restricted responsibility, which implies that if the business accrues difficulties or obligations, their finances are not in danger. As such, the stockholders of an S.A. are only financially responsible for their investment's value. Such types of companies in Romania must have RON 90,000 as the required capital in order to be formed.

====General Partnership (s.n.c.)====
A General Partnership is one of the types of business in Romania where two or more individuals jointly control and run the business that is operating under a single trade name. Partners in such businesses split their earnings and expenses equally. Every member is entirely accountable for the financial commitments and responsibilities of the partnership company.

====Limited Partnership (s.c.s.)====
In a limited partnership, the general partners are fully responsible for the monetary debts and responsibilities associated with the firm. The general partner is in charge of running the business in such types of companies in Romania. Limited partners have restricted liability and as such, they are only responsible for the value of funds they have contributed to the partnership.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
Russia's corporate registry, the Single State Registry of Legal Persons, may be accessed directly in a number of ways, with a search function available on the Federal Tax Service [https://egrul.nalog.ru/index.html '''website''']. Search by name, corporate ID ("OGRN") or tax ID ("INN"). The search results will deliver company IDs, status, address, and dates of registration ("OGRN assignment date") and termination as relevant, and offers a pdf download of a current extract in Russian only ''(see sources below if you need to machine translate)'' . Current extracts offer various details, all of which are accompanied by the date on which the detail was registered, i.e. last changed, with only current information displayed. Note that the current corporate registry system became active in July 2002, with extracts for companies established before then including a creation date.

The same Tax Service search engine can also identify sole traders ("individual entrepreneurs") by their name and tax number. For individual subjects, this search can deliver useful ID information such as tax number, associated address, and citizenship.

[http://russianpartner.biz/ '''Enquiry Service of Legal Entities''']

A commercial database with the ability to purchase official information for a company, some extra details and financial metrics.

[http://www.ffms.ru/hd_base/co_schema/ '''Federal Service for Financial Market''']

A list of financial companies (mostly banks) with their beneficiaries.

[http://egrul.nalog.ru/ '''Federal Tax Authority''']

State database of companies, which provides the ability to search for any business in Russia by the company name, INN or OGRN.

Note that the aforementioned ID numbers are of more use for research on Russian companies than for those from other European jurisdictions, due to a marked (Soviet?) lack of imagination in company naming. Tax IDs will frequently be featured on company websites, usually either at the bottom of the homepage, or on a "contact" page. Company names also frequently include a set of words or initials categorizing the company's activity followed by a company name, always indicated in speech marks. Activity categories (initials) should not be confused with entity types, which are as follows:

*Limited liability company (OOO or LLC) (Russian: Общество с ограниченной ответственностью, OOO)
*Sole proprietor or "individual entrepreneur" (IP) (Russian: Индивидуальный предприниматель, ИП)
*Joint-stock company (AO or JSC) (Russian: Aкционерное общество, АО) '''Note:''' ''such entities' ownership will not be displayed in official corporate records, but may be available on company websites/in annual reports''
*Public joint-stock company (PAO or PJSC) (Russian: Публичное акционерное общество, ПАО)
*Non-public joint-stock company (NAO or NPJSC) (Russian: Непубличное акционерное общество, НАО)
''Joint-stock companies registered before a 2014 change in legislation are frequently still officially registered as:''
*Private/Closed joint-stock company (ZAO or PJSC) (Russian: Закрытое акционерное общество, ЗАО) or
*Open joint-stock company (OAO or JSC) (Russian: Открытое акционерное общество, ОАО)

===Transparent Business===

The Federal Tax Service maintains the "Transparent Business" website, with a search function which displays the same information as the corporate registry proper (in machine-translatable format). Additional information is also sometimes available, such as information on tax or other debts, amount of tax paid, and number of employees. A company's page will also include a link to its page on the accounting records database, if available.

Transparent Business also offers a reverse affiliation search, which functions for both legal and natural persons, (select the "participation in legal entities" search tab) and an address search ("legal address"; useful for identifying possible affiliates), alongside searches for disqualified directors ("disqualifications") and a similar regulatory sanction against business owners ("restrictions on participation in a legal entity").

===Private Services===

While a lot of key information is available from the official services described above, they omit historic information. This is often available through a range of third-party services.

[https://spark-interfax.ru/en '''Spark Interfax''']

Local gold standard, providing a wide range of registration, accounting and legal information and convenient navigation, but at a corresponding price. Commercial database which provides a lot of information about companies (collecting it from official sources). Usually it has owners, CEO, connections, financial reports, court cases and much more.

[http://e-disclosure.ru/poisk-po-kompaniyam '''Interfax disclosure''']

A database with some public companies that provides annual reports, affiliate lists and financial documents.

[http://www.disclosure.ru/datacapital_tools/extsearch.jsp '''disclosure.ru''']

Additional search tool for corporate disclosures and capital information.

[https://disclosure.skrin.ru/issuers.asp?id=4 '''skrin.ru''']

A database with some public companies that provides annual reports, affiliate lists and financial documents.

[https://www.list-org.com/ '''List-org''']

Provides a range of information - including historical registration data and excerpts from litigation - for free.

[https://www.rusprofile.ru/ '''Rusprofile''']

Provides basic information for free. As of January 2024, a 1-month subscription purportedly including access to historical information, affiliation mapping and litigation cost RUB 590 (~EUR 6).

'''Kontur Focus'''

As with other services, [https://focus.kontur.ru/search?country=RU '''searches'''] provide limited, basic information for free. Popular with Russian media. As of January 2024, 24-hour one-time access was [https://focus.kontur.ru/site/price-periodical '''available'''] for RUB 1,300 (~EUR 13).

===Financial Information===

The Federal Tax Service maintains a [https://bo.nalog.ru/ '''database'''] of data harvested from accounts submitted by certain companies. It is quite new, so displays information only from recent years. Data quality varies due to its self-submitted nature.

litigation.wiki_content:
A range of official litigation sources are available. If your subject is a corporate entity, consider the third-party corporate records providers listed above. Individual parties to cases are usually, but not always, identified in the format (Surname) (First name initial) (Patronymic initial). They may also be identified by their tax number.

[http://fssprus.ru/ '''Federal Service of Court Bailiffs''']

A database of Russian citizens who have any court debts. Searchable by name.

'''Official database'''

The official [https://sudrf.ru/index.php?id=300&searchtype=sp '''Pravosudie'''] litigation database presents records from the Constitutional Court, federal and regional-level Courts of Arbitration, federal and regional-level general jurisdiction courts and selected magistrates courts, dating back to 1999. Records on criminal, civil and administrative cases are available. Access the search function by clicking [https://bsr.sudrf.ru/bigs/portal.html '''search by cases and texts'''] from the homepage linked above (as of writing in January 2024, this page was working only intermittently).

'''Arbitration Database'''

The [https://ras.arbitr.ru/ '''Arbitr'''] database provides access to nation-wide arbitration cases. Official web-site of Russian Arbitrage. Provides the ability to search by the name (of person or a company) and gives access to decisions and documents.

'''Court Websites'''

The federal-level [https://vsrf.ru/lk/practice/acts '''High Court'''] publishes decisions on its website.

While various databases provide access to rulings from a range of (regional) general courts and (local) magistrates courts, it is worth checking whether specific local courts relevant to the subject (particularly individuals) publish records online. Single websites for magistrates courts in [https://mos-sud.ru/search '''Moscow'''] (dating back to 2010) and [https://mirsud.spb.ru/ '''Saint Petersburg'''] are available, and Moscow also maintains a [https://mos-gorsud.ru/ '''database'''] of general jurisdiction rulings. For others, identify relevant local courts based on address history and through [https://sudact.ru/regular/area/ this] third-party list of courts, then navigate to the relevant court websites to search for rulings.

'''Third-party databases'''

The [https://sudact.ru/ '''SudAct'''] database presents a collection of rulings from the High Court, Courts of Arbitration, general courts and magistrates courts, and claims to cover all Russian courts. Records on criminal, civil and administrative cases are available. It is also searchable through an external site search, which is useful for specifying subject names using boolean operators - note, however, that Russian grammatical rules can vary the spelling of most surnames, so a specific search may not find all results. A web-site that collects different court cases and provides documents. Available only with Russian IP.

A third-party database aggregating rulings from Russia's [https://xn--90afdbaav0bd1afy6eub5d.xn--p1ai/ '''courts of general jurisdiction'''] is available, but the site was functioning intermittently as of January 2024. This database appears similar to the [http://www.gcourts.ru/ GCourts] database, which has run afoul of the data privacy regulator in the past and was offline as of January 2024.

The market-leading [https://www.consultant.ru/about/software/cons/specpoisk_sudpraktiki/ '''Konsultant'''] and [https://www.garant.ru/ '''Garant'''] legal databases offer comprehensive access to legal records, but are priced accordingly.

The [https://sudrf.cntd.ru/ '''Kodeks'''] database provides limited searches of its database of records from regional arbitration and general courts to unregistered users.

===Criminal Searches===

Access to criminal records is restricted, although individuals may request criminal record checks on themselves for official purposes. 

The Ministry of Internal Affairs maintains a [https://xn--b1aew.xn--p1ai/wanted '''database'''] of wanted persons on its website. In order to avoid providing an email address to get results, run a site search of subject's name (format: Surname-Name-Patronymic).

If an individual subject is a known prisoner, additional information on them may be available in a database of incarcerated individuals on the relevant institution's website, although not all penitentiaries maintain such databases. The NGO Sova maintains a [https://www.sova-center.ru/database/ '''database'''] of incarcerated individuals.

The Federal Service for Financial Monitoring maintains a [https://fedsfm.ru/documents/terrorists-catalog-portal-act '''database'''] of individuals and organisations recognised as terrorists or extremists by the Russian government. Note that the latter category is frequently imposed on political opponents of the current government.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://www.bolagsverket.se/ Bolagsverket]

Bolagsverket is the official Swedish corporate registry. The Swedish‑language version of the website offers more options than the English one. Without registration you can see a company’s name and organisation number; registration (about €50) gives access to corporate filings which may be downloaded for a fee. Only name and ID number are available without registration. The register contains information on companies, including business purpose, registered office and directors.

Company filings

To purchase filings through Bolagsverket:

On Bolagsverket’s website, click Köpa registreringsbevis.

Input the company’s name or registration number.

Select the documents you want to purchase. Options include:

Certificate of registration – standard company registry extract including basic registration information, address, directors, signatories, capital and name history (not shareholders).

Current assignments – lists roles the company has in other companies and organisations.

Uppgifter ur registret över verkliga huvudmän – lists the ultimate beneficial owners (UBOs) of a company controlling at least 25 % of votes or shares.

Bolagsordning – articles of association/statutes.

Protokoll – meeting minutes (e.g. AGM, extraordinary meetings, board meetings).

Årsredovisning – annual financial reports.

Tick your choices and click Lägg i kundvagn (Add to cart).

Click Till kassan (Checkout) and fill in your contact details.

Pay by credit/debit card.

You will receive an email with download links.

Shareholding information appears in the annual report, not in the standard registry extract. A company’s historical boards of directors are accessible only to Bolagsverket clients with Swedish personal identity numbers. Contact a Sweden‑based researcher for assistance if necessary.

Directorship checks

Every long‑term Swedish resident has a personal identity number (personnummer) consisting of the date of birth (YYYYMMDD) plus four digits (e.g. 851125‑5477). You need this number to run directorship checks in the official registry. To find a person’s ID number, you can register for free with Ratsit (below) and search by name and date of birth; you will need approximate age and/or location to avoid namesakes. Another option is [https://mrkoll.se Mrkoll], a commercial aggregator of personal information. It is useful for rarer names or when you already know the subject’s address but generally requires a Swedish VPN.

UBO checks

It is mandatory for Swedish companies, trusts and other eligible organisations to report their UBOs (those who control at least 25 % of votes or shares) to Bolagsverket. Searching the UBO register requires a Swedish digital ID (Bank‑ID) and login at Bolagsverket’s e‑service. Short‑term residents (less than one year) or people who have moved abroad will not appear in searches.

Corporate information

[https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?SWEDEN&member=1 European Commission E‑Justice overview] – explains the Swedish business register and links to official sources.

[https://foretagsinfo.bolagsverket.se/sok-foretagsinformation-web/ Företagsinfo] – Bolagsverket’s database supporting search by company name or registration number. Returns name, registration number, location, legal form and status; certificates of incorporation and annual reports are available for about €25 each.

[https://snr4.bolagsverket.se/snrgate/startIn.do Bolagsverket business register] – the older Näringslivsregistret; provides basic company information and a bankruptcy search (requires registration; will be discontinued in September 2025).

[https://poit.bolagsverket.se/poit/PublikPoitIn.do Swedish Gazette] – the official gazette for incorporation/company announcements; covers the past four weeks.

Company information aggregators

[https://proff.se/foretag/ Proff] – private aggregator listing active companies and directorships; provides key company details including name, ID, address, establishment year, management and ownership, basic financials.

Allabolag – similar to Proff and Ratsit (search at [https://www.allabolag.se Allabolag]).

[https://ratsit.se/ Ratsit] – third‑party aggregator sourcing data directly from government databases; useful for finding personal identity numbers and company details.

[https://UC.se UC] – provides credit rating reports on Swedish businesses.

[https://ebr.bundesanzeiger-verlag.de/european-business-register/unternehmenssuche/ Bundesanzeiger Verlag] – European Business Register (EBR) interface for searching companies across Europe (including Sweden) by country and company name; registration and payment required for detailed information.

---

[https://www.bolagsverket.se/ Bolagsverket]

The official corporate registry. The Swedish-language version of the website offers more options than the English one. The Bolagsverket, business register, provides information on companies, but only company name and ID number are available without registration. Registration costs €50, and gives the user access to corporate filings, which may be downloaded for a fee.
  
Company filings 
  
To purchase the filings: 

On Bolagsverket's website, click "Köpa registreringsbevis" 

Input the company's name or registration number  

You'll have the option to purchase some of the documents in English: 

"Certificate of registration" - standard company registry extract which includes basic registration information, address, directors, signatories, capital and name history (but not shareholders). 

"Current assignments" - lists roles the company has in other companies and organisations. 

"Uppgifter ur registret över verkliga huvudmän" - lists the UBOs of a company who hold a 25%+ stake. 

"Bolagsordning" - articles of association/statutes. 

"Protokoll" - meeting minutes (e.g. AGM, extraordinary meetings, board meetings, etc) 

"Årsredovisning" - annual (financial) reports. 

Tick off your choices and click "Lägg i kundvagn"

Click "Till kassan". Fill in your contact details.

Pay using a credit/debit card.

You'll receive an email with download links. 

You will find the shareholding information in the annual report, not in the company registry extract. 

A company's historical boards of directors are only accessible to Bolagsverket's registered clients with Swedish ID numbers. Get in touch with Eugen or any Sweden-based contrib for help. 

  
Directorship checks 

Swedish residents 

Every long-term Swedish resident has a personal 10-digit ID number (personnummer) which consists of its DOB (YYYYMMDD)+four digits, e.g. 851125-5477. You will need this number to run directorship checks in the official registry. 

To find out a person's ID, you can register for free e.g. with www.ratsit.se (a third party aggregator which sources its data directly from government databases) and search by person's name and DOB there. You will still need to have an idea of the person's age and/or location to eliminate namesakes. You can also call the tax authority (see Skatteverket).

[https://mrkoll.se Mrkoll] - This can be a quicker way of getting someone's ID number than the process outlined two rows above. It is a commercial aggregator of personal information. Will be best for the more rare names or if you already have the subject's address on file. Requires Swedish VPN.


UBO checks

It is mandatory for Swedish companies, trusts and other eligible organisations to report their UBOs (those who control at least 25% of votes or shares) to Bolagsverket. You will need a Swedish digital ID to login into and search the UBO register (get in touch with Eugen or any Sweden-based contrib). https://bolagsverket.se/sjalvservice/etjanster/verklighuvudman/sokverklighuvudman.3084.html
Short-term residents who stay in Sweden for less than 1 year or those who have moved abroad will not show up in the searches.

Corporate information

[https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?SWEDEN&member=1 European Commission E-Justice overview of the Swedish business registry]

[https://foretagsinfo.bolagsverket.se/sok-foretagsinformation-web/ Företagsinfo]

This Företagsfakta (company facts) database supports search by company name or registration number. Search returns company name, registration number, location, legal form and status. Additional data products, such as certificates of incorporation and annual reports, are available for €25 each.

[https://snr4.bolagsverket.se/snrgate/startIn.do Bolagsverket business register - basic company information and bankruptcy search]

Company information aggregators

[https://proff.se/foretag/ Proff]

Proff is an online aggregator that includes only active companies and directorships. Private, non-official alternative to the official CR website with information sourced from the CR. Provides key company details including name, ID, address, establishment year, management and ownership, basic financials.

Allabolag – similar to Proff and Ratsit.

[https://ratsit.se/ Ratsit]

[https://UC.se UC] provides credit rating reports on Swedish businesses.

[https://ebr.bundesanzeiger-verlag.de/european-business-register/unternehmenssuche/ Bundesazeiger Verlag]

Sweden corporate registry via the European Business Registry (EBR) on the website of the Bundesanzeiger Verlag. Supports search by country and company name. Can retrieve name and city of companies registered in Sweden. Registration and payment is required to access more information.

[https://poit.bolagsverket.se/poit/PublikPoitIn.do Swedish Gazette - official gazette for incorporation/company information]

litigation.wiki_content:
The Swedish judiciary comprises 48 district courts (tingsrätt), the Labour Court (Arbetsdomstolen), administrative courts (förvaltningsdomstolar), environmental courts (mark‑ och miljödomstolar), migration courts (migrationsdomstolar), the Patent and Market Court (patent‑ och marknadsdomstolar), the Svea Court of Appeal (Svea Hovrätt) and the Supreme Court (Högsta domstolen).

[https://www.lexbase.se/ Lexbase] – a commercial database to check litigation involving individuals or companies. You need the subject’s ID number (organisationsnummer or personnummer) or name and place of residence. Findings can be purchased for a fee. Lexbase may not have all court filings digitised; contact the relevant court directly if needed.

[https://rattsinfosok.domstol.se/lagrummet/ Sveriges Domstolar] – the Swedish Courts’ database where select judgments and precedents can be searched.

[https://www.domstol.se/hogsta-forvaltningsdomstolen/avgoranden/ Supreme Administrative Court] – official website of the Supreme Administrative Court; judgments and decisions from 2008, minutes from 2013 and notices from 2019 onwards.

[http://www.arbetsdomstolen.se/ Swedish Labour Court] – maintains records of labour‑related disputes.

[https://www.domstol.se/hogsta-domstolen/avgoranden/ Supreme Court] – official website of the Supreme Court; guiding judgments and decisions from 2003 and information on issues under consideration.

[https://www.domstol.se/domar-och-beslut/publicerade-domar-och-avgoranden/ Other courts] – portal where some other courts publish their decisions. Check for relevant cases if any apply.

Enquiring with courts directly – For many district and appeals courts you must phone or email to search cases; provide the organisation or personal ID number. Gather all relevant addresses and jurisdictions, call each court to ask how far back their records go (usually five years for civil, longer for criminal) and request summaries or filings. Courts will often send information for a small fee. The [https://www.aklagare.se/ Swedish Prosecution Authority] can also be consulted for ESG‑related matters.

---

The Swedish judiciary system consists of:			
			
48 district courts (tingsrätt),the Labour Court (Arbetsdomstolen, equivalent of the Labour Tribunal),administrative courts (förvaltningsdomstolar),environmental courts (mark- och miljödomstolar),migration courts (migrationsdomstolar),patent and market courts (patent- och marknadsdomstolar),the Svea Court of Appeal (Svea Hovrätt) andthe Supreme Court (Högsta domstolen). 


[https://www.lexbase.se/ Lexbase]
		
The quickest way to do litigation checks on individuals or companies in Sweden is via the commercial database www.lexbase.se/. You will need the subject's ID number (company reg. no. (organisationsnummer) or personal ID no, (personnummer)) or name and place of residence. Any findings can be purchased for a small fee.	
		
Note that Lexbase, while begin fairly comprehensive, may not always have all court filings digitised. If you know the case number and the parties, it is possible to get in touch with the relevant court directly to obtain case filings, anonymously if required. The filings are collected in person at the court location.	


[https://rattsinfosok.domstol.se/lagrummet/ Sveriges Domstolar]
		
Select judgements and precedents can be searched here.	


[https://www.domstol.se/hogsta-forvaltningsdomstolen/avgoranden/ Supreme Administrative Court]

Official website of the Supreme Administrative Court. Judgments and decisions from 2008 and minutes from 2013 and notices from 2019 are published on this website.

[http://www.arbetsdomstolen.se/ Swedish Labour Court]

Keeps records of labour-related disputes.

[https://www.domstol.se/hogsta-domstolen/avgoranden/ Supreme Court]

Official website of the Supreme Court. Guiding judgments and decisions (precedents) from 2003 are published here, as well as information on the issues that the Supreme Court intends to try (leave to appeal) and on ongoing cases where the Supreme Court has requested a preliminary ruling from the European Court of Justice.

Other courts

https://www.domstol.se/domar-och-beslut/publicerade-domar-och-avgoranden/

Some other courts publish their decisions in online databases. If there are any that could be relevant on a case, check them out.


Enquiring with courts directly

You need to call most courts, particularly District and Appeals Courts. No Swedish necessary except to read any filings.
 
Step 1: Gather all the relevant current and historical addresses for your subject. Include branch/regional offices. For a person, perhaps best to call Skatteverket to get the old addresses.
 
Step 2: Find the courts you need to search by searching by postcode of the offices/addresses of your subject. Search all former addresses as well. Make a note of the email/phone number of each relevant District and Appeals Court and make a list of subjects you want to enquire about. Note: You need to enquire by organisation number or ID number, rather than company/subject name.
 
Step 3: Call each court one by one. When contacting them, always ask how far back the resources go – tends to be about five years for civil, a bit longer for criminal.
 
Step 4: If any cases are found, ask them for a quick summary of the case. If the lawsuit relates to something more serious, then it would make sense to request the filings. In such instances, emailing is fine.
 
It is also OK to email courts when doing secondary research e.g. researching a company that is not the target company or an individual who is not a subject.
 
[https://www.aklagare.se/ Swedish Prosecution Authority]

Prosecution authority that seems to produce results particularly in ESG-related matters.

Search is available by the name or ID number of the company for all company types and it gives detailed and historical information. At AJPES, more information is available in Slovenian language compared to the English version. Options in the upper menu: eRTR - data on bank accounts of companies (open, closed) JOLP - annual reports of companies eOBJAVE - insolvency cases w/supporting documentation.

* [http://www-en.kdd.si/ Central Securities Clearing Corporation] (''pub'') - The list of issuers and securities available. Available in English.

* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?SLOVENIA&member=1 European Commission E-Justice] (''pub'') - European Commission overview of the Slovenian business registry, including links to the registry, description of how to search and what can be found as well as legislation behind it.

* [http://www.gvin.com/ Gvin (Commercial business registry of Bisnode)] (''paid'', ''reg'') - Search by names of directors/shareholders. Offers all the financial data from annual reports (incl. for years before 2008/2009, which are usually the earliest years you get annual reports for at Ajpes). Info on tax payments, ongoing lawsuits and credit ratings (the latter is a payable service of Ajpes). If a company changed its name, Ajpes would return no results, while Gvin would detect it and put you through to the "new" company. Offers all available documents in one place (except those you can find only at the court register - memorandum/articles of association, insolvency reports, statute). You can click on the address of a company and see what other companies are registered there. Registration and payment required.

* [http://www.oam.si/default_en.aspx?doc=ISSUERS Info Storage] (''pub'') - Contains the list of issuers and the list of securities with company contact information.
