corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://www.orsr.sk/search_subjekt.asp?lan=sk Business Register (entity)] / [https://www.orsr.sk/search_osoba.asp?lan=sk (individual)] (''pub'') The Business Register is Slovakia's official portal providing details of all entrepreneurs, companies and other legal entities. The Register is administered by the Ministry of Justice and is kept by the district courts. Search by trade name [obchodné meno] or identification number [identifikačné číslo; IČO], registered office [sídlo], reference number [spisová značka] or a person's surname/first name [priezvisko a meno osoby]. The Register provides dates of registered addresses of all officers. * [https://rpvs.gov.sk/rpvs CR] - Beneficial owners register. Administered by Ministry of Justice. Searchable by surname, business name, ID number. The collection of data is not comprehensive - missing wherever companies have not yet declared and submitted beneficial ownership structure. * [http://orsr.sk Business Register of Slovak Republic - Person search] - Official governmental online Slovakian Business Register. The Register falls under the responsibility of the Ministry of Justice of the Slovak Republic. Supports search by the name of an Individual. Includes lots of information about companies registered in Slovakia including company's name, address, legal form, ID number, owner, partners, amount of capital etc. * [http://orsr.sk Business Register of the Slovak Republic] - Official governmental online Slovakian Business Register. The Register falls under the responsibility of the Ministry of Justice of the Slovak Republic. Supports search by Business Name, Identification Number, Address, Registration Number, Name of an Individual. Includes lots of information about companies registered in Slovakia including company's name, address, legal form, ID number, owner, partners, amount of capital etc. * [http://www.orsr.sk/default.asp?lan=en Business Register of the Slovak Republic (English)] - English version of the official business register of the Slovak Republic. * [http://vorsr.sk/ Visual Business Register] - Alternative visual interface to the official business register with infographic representation of companies and their connections. * [https://www.zrsr.sk/StatusCode/404 Trade Register of Slovak Republic] - Official trade register of the Slovak Republic. Search for company name (must be longer than 2 characters) and retrieve full company name, an overview over traded items and address as well as a link to an organisation's entry on the official Companies Register. Click through for fuller information. Use the link below to find other information and search by other fields. * [http://www.bsse.sk Bratislava Stock Exchange] - Official website of the Slovakia's main stock exchange. Also available in English. * [http://www.bsse.sk/bcpben/MainPage/tabid/104/language/en-US/Default.aspx Bratislava Stock Exchange (English)] - English version of the official website of Slovakia's main stock exchange with list of issuers, basic company information and financial reports for some companies available for download. * [http://web.sopk.sk/ Slovak Chamber of Commerce and Industry] * FIREMNÝ REGISTER (Slovakia Business and Person Search) - This is an unofficial business and person searchable directory for Slovakia. The site returns information on both businesses and individuals and is searchable with either full or partial data but is only searchable in Slovak. * [http://www.sbagency.sk Slovak Business Agency] - This website enables direct B2B trading for SMEs in Slovakia and abroad. It includes a public directory of companies but some extra services are only available to registered users. * [https://telefonny.zoznam.sk Slovakia Phone Book] - Telefonny Zoznam (Telephone Book) is a phone directory for Slovakia the site is searchable by either first or last name and can also provide results by location. * [https://www.zlatestranky.sk Slovakia Yellow Pages] - The official Yellow Pages for Slovakia the site is searchable by first or last name and provides address and other basic information. * [http://foaf.sk/ FOAF.sk] - FOAF is a project based on corporate data from a number of official sources, including the Business Register of the Slovak Republic and the Slovak tax authorities. Its objective is to help identity connections between people and companies in Slovakia. The source can be searched by individual or company name as well as by company number. It provides information about companies an individual is affiliated to and includes details such as shareholdings and directorships. In the case of companies, it will return registration and capital information along with information about directors and shareholders. * zNasichDani.sk - ZNasichDani.sk uncovers who are influential persons (owners, managers, statutories) standing behind companies successful in securing contracts with the state. The service displays only total value of government contracts for companies. The resulting amount does not represent profit of specific individuals. Listed persons are not always owners of companies; they may be managers, members of the Supervisory Board or key employees. No data available for people who worked at a company before 2005. ZNasichDani.sk use the data and have access to the data of the section of judicial informatics and statistics and the Department of centralized information systems operations, the Ministry of justice and their Business Register of the Slovak republic. Enter the name or surname of a person and find full names, the name of the company the person is working for. By clicking through you can get information on the value of contracts for companies as well as documents related to the procurement process. * [https://www.cdcp.sk Central Securities Depository of the Slovak Republic] * [https://www.notar.sk/notarske-centralne-registre/ Chamber of Notaries of Slovak Republic] - Central notary register of deeds, liens, voluntary auctions of property. Searchable database of notaries with their contact details. * [http://datanest.fair-play.sk Datanest] - Created by Fair-Play Alliance, Slovakia's watchdog for transparency, this comprehensive database contains lists of persons and organizations grouped by the following categories: public procurement; organizations; politics and justice; donations, grants, funding; eurofunds; state institutions management; money in politics (including party sponsors); sale and privatization of state property; debts and tax liability. * [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?SLOVAKIA&member=1 European Commission e-Justice] - European Commission overview of the Slovak business registry, including links to the registry, description of how to search and what can be found, as well as legislation behind it. * [http://www.slovgram.sk/ Slovgram] - Slovgram is an independent company of performers and producers of audio and audio-visual recordings. The site contains a registry of licensed artist recording companies and other related organisations as well as scans of registration documents. ===Ownership=== *generally available :-reverse: in some cases only In Slovakia, not all companies are required to disclose their shareholders – for joint stock companies with more than one shareholder, the shareholders are not disclosed in the commercial register (though they may of course be the founding shareholders, which must be disclosed in filings). In these cases, information on the shareholders can only be accessed through the central securities depository by certain authorized persons, such as law enforcement, tax administration, public bodies. Sole shareholders are disclosed. [https://esm.justice.cz/ias/issm/rejstrik-$sm UBO Register] Information on who meets the criteria of a beneficial owner: {- https://esm.justice.cz/ias/issm/napoveda#zmenyNew ]
Research Guide
'''Ultimate Beneficial Ownership''' Ultimate beneificial ownership may be found through the '''Register of Public Sector Partners (RPVS).''' RPVS is a legally established list of data on '''public sector partners, and these partners are obliged to provide information on all direct and indirect shareholders.''' A public sector partner is a natural person, a natural person-entrepreneur and a legal entity that receives from the state, local government and other entities of the public sector monetary payment or property above the limit specified by law. In addition, persons who enter into a contract, framework agreement or concession agreement according to the regulations on public procurement, health care providers, a person to whom a claim against the state or public sector entities is assigned or otherwise transferred, must also be entered in the register - taking into account financial limits. as well as subcontractors. Health insurance companies are also partners of the public sector. Natural persons, natural persons-entrepreneurs and legal entities that are not partners of the public sector can also voluntarily enroll in the RPVS. The platform for disclosure of end-users of benefits in the register of public sector partners can also be used by entities other than public sector partners, for example business partners for their B2B business relationships. The public sector partner does not register himself in the RPVS. For this purpose, he must secure an authorized person (according to the law, this is a lawyer, notary, bank, branch of a foreign bank, auditor or tax advisor with a registered office or place of business in the territory of the Slovak Republic), with whom he must conclude an agreement on the fulfillment of the duties of the authorized person for the partner public sector. Subsequently, this authorized person performs all actions related to the RPVS on behalf of the public sector partner (that is, not only the initial entry, but also the change or deletion of entered data). According to § 11 par. 2 letters c) Act no. 315/2016 Coll. on the register of public sector partners and on the amendment of certain laws as amended by Act no. 38/2017 Coll. (hereinafter referred to as ZRPVS), '''the authorized person is obliged to verify the identification of the final user of the benefits of the public sector partner''' as of 31.12 . The authorized person can fulfill the mentioned obligation no earlier than 31.12 . He cannot send verification before this day; the purpose of the provisions of § 11 par. 2 letters c) ZRPVS is to declare the status as of 31.12. of the relevant calendar year and not earlier . ZRPVS does not specify the longest possible period when a notice of court verification can be sent after this date. At the same time, however, in accordance with § 11 par. 6 ZRPVS, this notification can be sent "immediately" after the authorized person succeeds in finding out the result - that the final user of the benefits has not changed. This means that it is possible to send a notification about the verification of the identification of the end user of the benefits even after 31.12. However, it is necessary to be aware that failure to fulfill the obligation to verify identification may mean suspension of performance by the public sector for the public sector partner until the said obligation is fulfilled , i.e. until the moment when the date of the notification on the verification of the end users of the benefits appears in register of public sector partners.
===Directorship=== * available :- reverse: yes ===Company Types===
''Details''
'''Limited Liability Company (s.r.o.)''' One of the most common types of companies in the Czech Republic is the limited liability company. Such types of Czech companies must be formed with a minimum investment of CZK 1. A minimum of one stockholder and one director are essential for forming a limited liability company in the Czech Republic. The stockholders may be either natural persons or corporations. An SRO's stockholders assume limited responsibility for the organization, meaning they are not personally liable for the various monetary loans or liabilities of the corporation. '''Limited Partnership (k.s.)''' In a limited partnership, the general partners are fully responsible for the monetary debts and responsibilities associated with the firm. The general partner is in charge of running the business in such types of companies in the Czech Republic. Limited partners have restricted liability and as such, they are only responsible for the value of funds they have contributed to the partnership, as specified in the articles of association of the firm. '''General Partnership (v.o.s.)''' A General Partnership is one of the types of business in the Czech Republic where two or more individuals jointly control and run the business that is operating under a single trade name. Partners in such businesses split their earnings and expenses equally. Every member is entirely accountable for the financial commitments and responsibilities of the partnership company. As such, each of the members in such types of Czech companies is equally and jointly liable for the monetary obligations and responsibilities of the firm. There isn't any basic investment requirement for forming such types of companies in the Czech Republic. '''Joint Stock Company (a.s.)''' A JSC's stockholders have restricted responsibility, which implies that if the business accrues difficulties or obligations, their finances are not in danger. As such, the stockholders of an AS are only financially responsible for their investment's value. Such types of companies in the Czech Republic must have CZK 2,000,000 as the required capital in order to be formed. This sort of corporation may be established by at least one stakeholder. The statutory authority for corporations with multiple shareholders is the board of directors, which must have at least 3 persons. A supervisory board of a minimum of 3 people is also required to be established by the joint stock corporation. The three people on the supervisory boards cannot also serve as directors of the corporation in the case of an AS firm. '''Cooperative (Družstvo)''' A cooperative, known as a "družstvo," is a business that is held and operated by the individuals who consume its commodities and services. The cooperative's main commercial objective is the societal or economical well-being of its participants, who are not individually accountable for the debts as well as liabilities of the enterprise. There isn't any capital necessity for establishing a cooperative, however, it must possess adequate funds to operate. Such types of companies in the Czech Republic must consist of three individuals as a minimum before they may be founded. '''Sole Proprietorship''' Such types of business in the Czech Republic are controlled and managed by a sole person and can be established quickly and easily. In this kind of company entity, a single person operates their own firm on a self-employed basis. According to the Trade License Act, an individual can officially begin their business as a sole proprietor after they turn 18 years old. There isn't any legal distinction between the company's financial resources and those of the proprietor in these types of Czech businesses. As such, the firm proprietor is entirely and solely accountable for all financial debts and responsibilities of the firms. '''Branch Office''' A branch office in the Czech Republic is an addition to an international business that conducts business in the nation. A branch office in the Czech Republic isn't regarded as a separate legal organization, thus, the parent firm must authorize all of its business-related decisions. Also, in such types of Czech companies, the parent firm is responsible for the duties and actions of its branch. The Czech legislation governs its formation and inclusion in the Czech commercial registry. International corporations who want to maintain a presence in the Czech Republic without establishing a distinct legal organization might consider opening a branch office there. It enables the parent business to keep oversight of the Branch office's activities. '''Representative Office''' A representative office can be established in the Czech Republic by international corporations. A representative office is only permitted to carry out market research or advertise the products and services of its holding organization. Such types of business in the Czech Republic are not permitted to go on trade or enter into agreements.

litigation.wiki_content:
===Disclaimer===

We have conducted searches of litigation records in South Africa, including the High Courts and the Supreme Court of Appeal.[1] We note that litigation records are not always publicly available and therefore these searches should not be considered comprehensive. We identified no litigation involving ***.

1. Including the following courts: Competition Appeal Court; Competition Tribunal; Companies Tribunal; Consumer Goods and Services Ombudsman; Constitutional Court; Court of the Commissioner of Patents; Commercial Crime Court; Electoral Court; Equality Court; High Courts - Northern Cape, Eastern Cape, Western Cape, Free State, Gauteng, Limpopo, Kwazulu Natal, North West; Land Claims Court; Law Reform Commission; National Consumer Tribunal; Rules of Superior Courts; Rules of Magistrates Courts; Supreme Court of Appeal; Tax Court; Water Tribunal; Labour Appeal Court; Labour Courts for Cape Town, Johannesburg, Port Elizabeth, Durban.

When using the Nexis Power Search ClarifiedBy extension, remember to account for the "maker's mark" that Diligencia inserts into the data it provides to Nexis. When reviewing Arabic writing in the results, please note that most, if not all, instances of the letter "ك" are replaced with the letter "ج". For example, the word "شركة" will appear as "شرجة". This also happens with names. Please modify computer assisted searches within documents, as well as copying and pasting practices, to this effect

litigation.wiki_content:
[https://juricaf.org/recherche/+/facet_pays%3AGabon Juricaf]	Limited litigation available on Juricaf. Database of case law in French providing the decisions of supreme courts across the French speaking world. Funded by the French Ministry of Justice and the International Organisation of La Francophonie. Is very limited in scope. 
			
[http://www.worldlii.org/catalog/2668.html WorldLII Gabon]	Conduct search in the search bar at the top of the page.

[https://juricaf.org/recherche_avancee French case law database] collecting Supreme Court judgements from French-speaking nations.
			
Additional Information on the Gabonese Court System			
			
Following constitutional reforms in 1991, the Gabonese judiciary system was substantially modified. The judiciary is now comprised of a number of specialized courts: the Judicial Supreme Court, the Administrative Supreme Court, the Accounting Supreme Court, the Constitutional Court, and the Court of State Security.			
			
Subordinate Courts			
			
At the lowest level, customary law courts, presided over by traditional chiefs, mediate local disputes. Courts of first instance (tribunaux de première instance) and regional high courts (tribunaux de grande instance) appeal cases to the Appeal Courts (Cours d'appel). From the Appeals Courts, cases can be further appealed to the Judicial Supreme Court (Cour de Cassation).			
			
Supreme Court			
			
Gabon's highest-level courts are the country's former Supreme Court chambers now broken into three separate supreme courts: a judicial court, an administrative court, and a court of accounts, each having absolute authority over its respective area of expertise. The Judicial Supreme Court (Cour de Cassation) oversees ordinary affairs, in other words, criminal, social, commercial, and civil matters. Further, the Administrative Supreme Court (Conseil d'Etat) rules on administrative litigations or judicial review of the activities of the executive branch and other public law bodies. It receives drafts of laws and regulations from the government for legal advice before sending them to Parliament or to the respective cabinet for signature. The Accounting Supreme Court (Cour des Comptes) is responsible for auditing accounts of government and other public and semi-public bodies. It also has the ability to rule on all conflicts arising as the auditing of such bodies and to sanction the relevant authorities, notwithstanding possible criminal investigations and prosecutions.			
			
Constitutional Court			
			
The Constitutional Court is the highest level court in Gabon with regard to constitutional matters. It has control of the constitutionality of laws before promulgation upon referral by the head of state, or the president of one or the other chamber of Parliament. Every seven years, its judges are appointed as follows: three by the national president, three by the president of the Senate, and three by the president of the National Assembly. These judges serve seven-year terms that can be renewed only once.			
			
Court of State Security			
			
The Court of State Security tries the president and other senior government official for acts of high treason. This court also has the power to impeach the president or try them for violations of their presidential oath.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://egov.gov.gd/RegistrarGeneral Grenada Registrar General's Department] (''pub'') The Grenada Registrar General's Department is responsible for the registration of companies in Grenada. The department operates under the Ministry of Legal Affairs and ensures compliance with the Companies Act. Companies must file specific details as required by legislation. Use the search bar on the Grenada Registrar General's website to search by company name, number, or officer name. The search results will be organized by tab. To refine your results to companies, click the relevant tab. For disqualified directors, search for their name and click the 'Disqualifications' tab. Once you click on a company name, you will be brought to its Overview page. Click on the relevant tab to access filings (Filing History), info on officers and shareholders (People), and current and former charges (Charges). Company records are retained by the Grenada Registrar General's Department for 10 years after a company is dissolved. The department includes registrations, annual reports, and other corporate filings, directors, and significant shareholders (25% or more). Companies are required to register incorporation details (including previous names), charges/mortgages, and insolvency information, and file annual reports and annual returns. For full date of birth, including the day, look for documents submitted before 2019. For '''archived company details and reports''', use [https://data.occrp.org/ OCCRP Aleph] (''civ'') and/or one of the following services: * [https://companycheck.co.uk Company Check] (''priv'') * [https://www.duedil.com DueDil] (''priv'') * [https://www.endole.co.uk Endole] (''priv'') [https://register-of-charities.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-search Charity Register] (''pub'') You can find out what a charity does, where it operates, its trustees, and info on income and assets. Additionally, OpenCorporates has a comprehensive charity register for Grenada that includes registered charities. ===Ownership=== * generally available :-reverse: in random cases only, on [https://data.occrp.org/ OCCRP Aleph] (''civ'') Information on [https://www.gov.uk/guidance/people-with-significant-control-pscs People with significant control]
Research Guide
'''Ultimate Beneficial Ownership''' Beneficial ownership can be found on the Grenada Registrar General's website by following the chain of ownership or simply looking at the Persons with Significant Control (PSC). PSCs meet one of the following guidelines: the individual directly or indirectly owns over 25 percent of the company's shares or voting rights, or has the right to appoint or remove the majority of the board of directors. '''Publicly Traded''' You can find ownership information and corporate filings on the Eastern Caribbean Securities Exchange (ECSE) and the Grenada Registrar General's websites for publicly traded companies. Public companies must have at least two directors and one secretary registered with the Registrar General. '''Privately Held''' The Grenada Registrar General's Department will often have shareholder information. Ownership/subsidiaries can also sometimes be found in accounts. In the Filing History section, you will find a list of documents. If there are numerous documents, you can narrow your search by keywords such as Capital, Shares, Annual Return, Confirmation Statement, and Incorporation. If there are only a few documents, please search all of them. If a company has numerous shareholders and you are unsure how to report this, contact your CM to notify him/her that the company's ownership structure is complicated. '''Nonprofit''' The Charity Commission in Grenada keeps records of charities. This website will have corporate filings that sometimes include trustee information.
===Directorship=== * available :- reverse: yes ===Company Types===
''Details''
'''Private Company Limited by Shares''' This is the most common company type. They usually have 'Limited' or 'Ltd' at the end of the company name. The amount for which shareholders are liable in the event that the company is wound up is limited to the face value of their share in the business. The company cannot sell shares to the general public (like a PLC can). '''Public Limited Company (PLC)''' This type can sell shares to the general public. It must have share capital of GHS 50,000 or more, of which at least 25% must have been paid up before the company can begin trading. Not all PLCs are listed on a stock exchange. The liability of the company is limited to the value of its reserves. '''Private Company Limited by Guarantee''' This type limits the liability of its guarantors to a pre-agreed amount that they have to pay if the company is wound up. Non-profits are often set up like this. There is no share capital or shareholders in this company. Its members/owners are the guarantors. '''Private Unlimited Company''' There is no cap to the amount that its members are required to pay if the company is wound up, so they tend to be used for companies where insolvency is a very low risk. They are not required by law to submit annual accounts to the Registrar General. This makes unlimited companies attractive to businesses that wish to maintain a level of secrecy about their financial status. '''Limited Liability Partnership (LLP)''' An LLP is owned by its members who have certain responsibilities, including acting in accordance with the partnership agreement. Its members (partners) are only liable for the amount of money they invest, plus any personal guarantees. There's no restriction on the maximum number of partners allowed but there must be at least two members on incorporation, either individuals or limited companies. They are solely for profit-making businesses. '''Limited Partnership (LP)''' This is a business association of one or more 'general partners' alongside one or more 'limited partners'. It is the general partner who is personally liable for the partnership's debts and other obligations. Where there is more than one general partner, they are jointly liable for the partnership's debts. Liability is potentially unlimited, so they may face losing personal assets. Each limited partner's personal liability is capped to the amount of their investment (and any personal guarantees they have given). While their original investment may be lost in paying off partnership debts, the limited partner's personal assets cannot be accessed by creditors. '''Societas Europaea, or SE companies''' These can be established in all European Economic Area. When established in Grenada, SEs are a type of public limited company which can be formed as a subsidiary of another company or as a holding company. SE companies can also be created by mergers or from an existing PLC.

litigation.wiki_content:
''Context''
Grenada has a common law legal system. Judges look to past, relevant precedential decisions and apply their principles to the legal questions before them. If a similar dispute has been resolved in the past, the court is usually bound to follow the reasoning used in the prior decision. Written opinions for precedent-setting decisions are published online as they are of significance and interest to the general public and legal practitioners alike. Case briefs mainly serve to show how a legal decision was arrived at, which requires, to some extent, recounting the circumstances of the underlying dispute. Personal data may be published in judgments. Court records for cases that are neither precedent-setting nor of public importance are not publicly available. The most comprehensive, online Grenada case law databases are maintained by the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court website and the Eastern Caribbean Legal Information Institute. These databases include decisions from all Grenadian courts and specialty tribunals. The databases search allows for all courts to be searched at once, making knowledge of the subject's address history unessential.
* [https://www.eccourts.org/ The Supreme Court covering the] Eastern Caribbean countries including Grenada with searchable judgements by year, country, and month (''pub'') '''[https://www.eccourts.org/ Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court]''' (''civ'') A searchable database of case law and legislation from the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court, which includes Grenada.
''Sources''
* Grenada Administration Orders; * Grenada Child Support Agency Liability Orders; * Grenada County Court Judgments ('CCJs'); * Grenada Fine Defaults; * Grenada High Court Judgments; * Grenada Tribunal Awards; * Isle of Man Judgments; * Jersey Judgments; * Northern Ireland High Court Judgments; * Northern Ireland Judgments; * Republic of Ireland Registered Court Judgments; * Scotland Ordinary Causes; * Scotland Small Claims Summary Cause & Simple Procedure Decrees
'''[https://www.thelawpages.com/court-cases/index.php?res=1 The Law Pages]''' (''civ'') '''[https://www.scotcourts.gov.uk Scottish Courts and Tribunals]''' (''pub'') Required for subjects with an address history in Scotland.
''Search Tips''
:-Use the site's "Search" bar
'''[http://www.courtsni.gov.uk Northern Ireland Courts]''' (''pub'')
''Search Tips''
:-Search for court cases by all of these words from

Written opinions for precedent-setting decisions are published online as they are of significance and interest to the general public and legal practitioners alike. The CCIC is a Public Law entity. This website gives you the option to search for company information with registration number (use empresasabiertas.com to identify subject company's 10-digit registration number and region of registration for the CCIC search). The website provides its users with the option to view documents electronically, in the Mercantile Registry section, where both companies and citizens and administrations the public have sufficient proven information on the companies.	
				
[http://www.dei.gob.hn Revenue Directorate, Honduras]	

Company search only possible with a passport or ID number.		
		
[http://alvm.prefecturanaval.gob.ar Acuerdo Viña del Mar]

The Latin American Agreement on Port State Control of vessels is called Viña del Mar. Member states are Argentina, Brazil, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, Ecuador, Honduras, Mexico, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela. Search by ship name, flag, IMO or port of inspection to find out whether the ship in question passed its inspection, and why it didn't. This information is available on click through.

Company search only possibly with a login.

litigation.wiki_content:
Context
The legal system in Hong Kong is based on common law, with judges looking to past precedents to resolve legal questions. Significant legal decisions are published online. The Judiciary website maintains a comprehensive database of case law from all courts and specialty tribunals. === Key Resources === - [Bailii](http://www.bailii.org/) (''civ'') - [The Law Pages](https://www.thelawpages.com/court-cases/index.php?res=1) (''civ'') - [Hong Kong Judiciary](https://www.judiciary.hk/en/index/index.html) (''pub'')
=== Directorship Search ===
Steps
1. Go to: [ICRIS](https://www.icris.cr.gov.hk/csci/) 2. Choose unregistered user 3. Fill in personal information 4. Click Search and choose “Directors Index” from the dropdown list 5. Click “Directors Index Search (Director-based)” 6. Enter the surname and other names of the person you want to search 7. Click “Online Review” to proceed to the payment session and wait for results 8. Repeat the search using the Chinese name if necessary

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
=== Companies Registry === [Companies Registry](https://www.icris.cr.gov.hk/csci/) (''pub'') The Companies Registry in Hong Kong is responsible for the incorporation and registration of companies. It operates under the Companies Ordinance and maintains a comprehensive register of all forms of companies, including public and private companies. Use the search bar on the ICRIS portal to search by company name, number, or director's name. For detailed information, follow these steps: 1. Go to the Companies Registry website. 2. Choose "Unregistered User." 3. Fill in the required personal information (e.g., name and a UK passport number). 4. Click "Search" and choose “Directors Index” from the dropdown list. 5. Click “Directors Index Search (Director-based)” and enter the surname and other names of the person you want to search. 6. Click “Online Review” to proceed to the payment session (Visa/Mastercard) and wait for the search results. 7. Repeat the search using the Chinese name if necessary. === Bankruptcy Records === [Bankruptcy Records](https://www.gov.hk/en/residents/taxes/empayment/services/empayment.htm) (''pub'') You can search for records of bankruptcy using the Hong Kong government services portal. This includes accessing information about individuals and companies that have filed for bankruptcy. === Charity Register === [Charity Register](https://www.icris.cr.gov.hk/csci/) (''pub'') The Charity Register provides information about registered charities in Hong Kong, including details about their activities, financial status, and governance. === Ownership === * generally available * reverse: in random cases only, on [OCCRP Aleph](https://data.occrp.org) (''civ'') Information on [People with significant control](https://www.gov.hk/en/residents/taxes/empayment/services/empayment.htm)
Research Guide
==== Ultimate Beneficial Ownership ==== Beneficial ownership can be found on the Companies Registry by following the chain of ownership or by searching the Directors Index. Persons with Significant Control (PSC) guidelines include individuals who directly or indirectly own over 25 percent of the company’s shares or voting rights or have the right to appoint or remove the majority of the board of directors. ==== Publicly Traded ==== Ownership information and corporate filings for publicly traded companies can be found on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) and the Companies Registry websites. Public companies must have at least two directors and one secretary registered. ==== Privately Held ==== The Companies Registry often contains shareholder information for privately held companies. Ownership and subsidiary information can sometimes be found in the accounts section of the filings. In the Filing History section, documents can be searched using keywords such as Capital, Shares, Annual Return, Confirmation Statement, and Incorporation. ==== Nonprofit ==== The Social Welfare Department in Hong Kong maintains records of registered charities, which include corporate filings and trustee information.
=== Directorship === * available * reverse: yes === Company Types ===
Details
==== Private Company Limited by Shares ==== This is the most common company type in Hong Kong. They usually have ‘Limited’ or ‘Ltd’ at the end of the company name. The liability of shareholders is limited to the face value of their share in the business. These companies cannot sell shares to the general public. ==== Public Limited Company (PLC) ==== This type can sell shares to the general public. It must have a minimum share capital and comply with listing requirements if listed on the stock exchange. The liability is limited to the value of its reserves. ==== Private Company Limited by Guarantee ==== This type limits the liability of its guarantors to a pre-agreed amount that they must pay if the company is wound up. Non-profits are often set up like this. There is no share capital, and its members are the guarantors. ==== Private Unlimited Company ==== There is no cap to the amount that its members are required to pay if the company is wound up. These companies are not required by law to submit annual accounts, making them attractive for maintaining financial secrecy. ==== Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) ==== An LLP is owned by its members, who are liable for the amount of money they invest plus any personal guarantees. There is no restriction on the number of partners, but there must be at least two on incorporation. They are solely for profit-making businesses. ==== Limited Partnership (LP) ==== This business association includes general and limited partners. General partners are personally liable for the partnership’s debts, while limited partners' liability is capped to the amount of their investment. ==== Societas Europaea, or SE companies ==== SE companies can be established in all European Economic Areas. In Hong Kong, they operate similarly to public limited companies and can be formed through mergers or as subsidiaries or holding companies.

litigation.wiki_content:
=== Court System in Iceland ===
Iceland has a structured court system with various levels including District Courts and the Supreme Court. The District Courts handle both civil and criminal cases at the first instance, while the Supreme Court handles appeals.

[District Courts](https://www.heradsdomstolar.is/heradsdomstolar/)  
The Icelandic justice portal enables search for legal decisions and case information from the district courts. It provides access to court decisions, procedural history, and other relevant case details. This covers the seven district courts. (pub)

[Supreme Court](https://www.haestirettur.is/)  
The Supreme Court is responsible for appeals from the district courts. It provides access to final decisions on significant cases and maintains a searchable database of its rulings. The Supreme Court offers a search service for case law since 1999 on its website. However, parties to cases are anonymised. (pub)

Icelandic companies are registered and maintained by the Ríkisskattstjóri (Directorate of Internal Revenue).

[Iceland Corporate Register](https://www.rsk.is/fyrirtaekjaskra)  
The Iceland companies register is run by the Ríkisskattstjóri (Directorate of Internal Revenue). It provides comprehensive information about companies registered in Iceland. The registry supports searches by company name and provides details such as company status, registration number, and more. Search by company name to get basic company information with information on postal address, municipality, legal form, type of business. Annual accounts are available for free download by email. (pub)

[Legal Gazette Iceland Lögbirtingablað](http://www.logbirtingablad.is/) (pub)

=== Ownership ===
Ownership information is available for companies listed in the registry. Reverse ownership searches are generally not available.

=== Directorship ===
Directorship information can be obtained through the Iceland Corporate Register. This includes details about the directors and their roles within the company.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
=== Companies in Japan ===
Japanese companies are categorized under various types including Kabushiki Kaisha (KK) and Godo Kaisha (GK).

Kabushiki Kaisha (KK) is a type of corporation similar to a public company in the Western context, where shares can be offered to the public. Godo Kaisha (GK) is similar to a limited liability company, typically used for smaller businesses.

See the detailed regulations for each type of company in Japan Regulatory.pdf

=== Japanese Corporate Register ===
[Japanese Corporate Register](http://www1.touki.or.jp/gateway.html)
The Japanese Corporate Register is maintained by the Ministry of Justice and provides comprehensive information about companies registered in Japan. Access to the database requires a login.

=== Japanese Corporate Register - Information ===
[Japanese Corporate Register - Information](http://www1.touki.or.jp)
This site run by the Ministry of Justice allows searching for companies, directors, and ownership information. Details available include company name, registration number, and directors' information.

=== Japanese Corporate Register - Business Names ===
[Japanese Corporate Register - Business Names](http://www1.touki.or.jp)
You can search the business names register by the family and given name of a person holding business names. The information retrieved includes current person name details, roles held, and current business name details.

=== Japanese Corporate Register - Public View ===
[Japanese Corporate Register - Public View](http://www1.touki.or.jp)
Provides access to publicly available information supplied by businesses when they register. Supports search by company's name and registration number.

=== Ownership ===
Ownership details are generally unclear and require specific searches through the corporate register. Reverse searches are not commonly available.

=== Directorship ===
Directorship information can be obtained through the Japanese Corporate Register. Details include the directors' names and roles within the company.

=== Additional Resources ===
* [Japan Exchange Group](https://www.jpx.co.jp/english/) - includes listed company search with incorporation date, office address, shareholders, representatives and total shares (pub)

* [Ministry of Justice Registry](http://www1.touki.or.jp/gateway.html) - company and real estate registries (only in Japanese) (pub, reg)

* [Japanese Corporate Register](http://www1.touki.or.jp) - maintained by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (pub, paid, reg)

* [American Chamber of Commerce in Japan](http://www.accj.or.jp/commercial-me...) membership directory

=== Court System in Japan ===
Japan has a well-structured court system divided into several levels including the Supreme Court, High Courts, District Courts, Family Courts, and Summary Courts. Each level of court handles different types of cases ranging from criminal, civil, to family matters.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
[https://www.orcjamaica.com/CompanySearch.aspx ORC Jamaica] (''pub'') The Jamaican company search allows you to search by company name, registration number, or officer name. The search results will provide a list of companies that match your criteria, and clicking on a company name will provide detailed information about that company. Use the search bar to search by company name, registration number, or officer name. The search results will be organized by tabs. To refine your results to companies, click the relevant tab. If searching for disqualified directors, search for their name and then click the 'Disqualifications' tab. Once you click on a company name, you will be brought through to its Overview page. Again, click on the relevant tab to access filings (Filing History), info on officers and PSCs (People), and current and former charges (Charges). In the Filing History tab, you can refine the filings by category by clicking on the relevant box at the top – for example, you can view Accounts, filings relating to officers, etc. NOTE: it's always a good idea to review the filing history in full as well because sometimes the filtered version does not pick up on relevant documents (e.g., filings that were resubmitted due to an error in the original). Company records are retained by the Jamaica Office of the Registrar of Companies for 20 years after a company is dissolved and struck off. Companies are also required to register incorporation details (including previous names), charges/mortgages, and insolvency information, and file annual reports (full accounts) and annual confirmation statements. For full date of birth, including the day, look for documents submitted before 2016. For '''archived company details and reports''', use [OCCRP Aleph](https://data.occrp.org/) (''civ'') and/or one of the following services: * [Company Check](https://companycheck.co.uk) (''priv'') * [DueDil](https://www.duedil.com) (''priv'') * [Endole](https://www.endole.co.uk) (''priv'') * [https://www.orcjamaica.com/CompanySearch.aspx?cId1=ab498fb6-5ae9-46fd-ab4f-09c778c557f0 Companies Office of Jamaica -] Search by name or number for company address, incorporation date, and status (''pub'', ''paid'') ===Ownership=== *generally available :-reverse: in random cases only, on [OCCRP Aleph](https://data.occrp.org/) (''civ'') ===Directorship=== * available :- reverse: yes ===Company Types===
''Details''
'''Private Company Limited by Shares''' This is the most common company type. The amount for which shareholders are liable in the event that the company is wound up is limited to the face value of their share in the business. The company cannot sell shares to the general public. '''Public Limited Company (PLC)''' This type can sell shares to the general public. It must have share capital of a specified amount, and the liability of the company is limited to the value of its reserves. '''Private Company Limited by Guarantee''' This type limits the liability of its guarantors to a pre-agreed amount that they have to pay if the company is wound up. Non-profits are often set up like this. There is no share capital or shareholders in this company. Its members/owners are the guarantors. '''Private Unlimited Company''' There is no cap to the amount that its members are required to pay if the company is wound up, so they tend to be used for companies where insolvency is a very low risk. They are not required by law to submit annual accounts to the Registrar. This makes unlimited companies attractive to businesses that wish to maintain a level of secrecy about their financial status. '''Limited Liability Partnership (LLP)''' An LLP is owned by its members who have certain responsibilities, including acting in accordance with the partnership agreement. Its members (partners) are only liable for the amount of money they invest, plus any personal guarantees. There's no restriction on the maximum number of partners allowed but there must be at least two members on incorporation, either individuals or limited companies. They are solely for profit-making businesses. '''Limited Partnership (LP)''' This is a business association of one or more 'general partners' alongside one or more 'limited partners'. It is the general partner who is personally liable for the partnership's debts and other obligations. Where there is more than one general partner, they are jointly liable for the partnership's debts. Liability is potentially unlimited, so they may face losing personal assets. Each limited partner's personal liability is capped to the amount of their investment (and any personal guarantees they have given). While their original investment may be lost in paying off partnership debts, the limited partner's personal assets cannot be accessed by creditors. '''Societas Europaea (SE companies)''' These can be established in all European Economic Area countries. When established in Jamaica, SEs are a type of public limited company which can be formed as a subsidiary of another company or as a holding company. SE companies can also be created by mergers or from an existing PLC.

litigation.wiki_content:
''Context''
Jamaica has a common law legal system. Judges look to past, relevant precedential decisions and apply their principles to the legal questions before them. If a similar dispute has been resolved in the past, the court is usually bound to follow the reasoning used in the prior decision. Written opinions for precedent-setting decisions are published online as they are of significance and interest to the general public and legal practitioners alike. Case briefs mainly serve to show how a legal decision was arrived at, which requires, to some extent, recounting the circumstances of the underlying dispute. Personal data may be published in judgments, the GDPR notwithstanding. Court records for cases that are neither precedent-setting nor of public importance are not publicly available. The most comprehensive, online Jamaican case law databases are maintained by the Supreme Court website and the Caribbean Court of Justice website. These databases allow for all courts to be searched at once, making knowledge of the subject's address history unessential.
===Sources=== * [Supreme Court Jamaica](http://www.supremecourt.gov.jm/) (''pub'') * [Caribbean Court of Justice](http://www.caribbeancourtofjustice.org/judgments-proceedings) (''civ'') * [http://www.caribbeancourtofjustice.org/judgments-proceedings/appellate-jurisdiction-judgments/ Caribbean Court of Justice -] Appellate jurisdiction and original jurisdiction judgements available as searchable PDFs (''pub'') * [http://www.supremecourt.gov.jm/ Jamaican Supreme Court - Contains] full text judgments (''pub'')
''Details''
The Caribbean Court of Justice is the judicial body for the Caribbean Community (CARICOM). It handles cases of regional importance, including disputes between CARICOM member states, and interprets the Revised Treaty of Chaguaramas which governs CARICOM. The Supreme Court of Jamaica provides information on its website about judgments, rules, and practice directions, which can be accessed by searching the site's database.
===Search Tips=== * Use the "Search" bar on the website to search for judgments and decisions. * Use a Google site search on the relevant website to find specific case information. ===Criminal=== Official criminal record checks in Jamaica can only be obtained by the subject of the request. A basic police record can be applied for through the Jamaica Constabulary Force (JCF) website. ===Insolvency & Debt=== Records of insolvencies and bankruptcies are maintained by the Jamaican Registrar of Companies and can be searched through the ORC website.

litigation.wiki_content:
Litigation records are available through various sources in Morocco.

===Federal Judiciary===

The courts in Morocco are divided into several levels:

1. '''Supreme Court of Morocco''' - The highest court, composed of justices.
2. '''Appeals Courts''' - Spread across various geographic areas.
3. '''District Courts''' - Handle federal cases including civil, criminal, and administrative matters.

===Key Resources for Litigation Searches===

* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Paid service providing limited case docket information.
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Google site search required for all subjects.
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Use the site's internal search bar.
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Subscription required for internal searches.
* [http://www.coursupreme.ma/en/default.asp Supreme Court of Morocco with] searchable court decisions (primarily in Arabic) (''pub'')
* [http://www.mahakim.ma/Ar/Annonces/RechercherAnnonces/?Page=AnnoncesJudiciaires Justice portal displaying case law] with search by date for cases of courts of first instance and commercial courts (''pub'')
* [http://www.jurisprudence.ma/ Private subscription based service offering] access to judgements from various courts (''paid'', ''reg'')
* [http://www.juricaf.org/recherche_av Juricaf database of case law] in French providing decisions of supreme courts across the French speaking world (''pub'')
* [http://www.jurisprudence.ma/recherc Moroccan Jurisprudence Portal with case] search and keyword search providing full records on click through (''pub'')

===State-Specific Judiciary Searches===

Each state in Morocco has its own judiciary system. The judiciary websites for each state provide search functionalities for local cases. Examples include:

* '''Judiciary of Casablanca'''
* '''Judiciary of Rabat'''
* '''Judiciary of Marrakech'''
* '''Judiciary of Fes'''

(Refer to each state's judiciary website for specific search instructions).

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
Various sources of corporate records are available in Morocco.

===National Enterprise Register===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

Morocco's National Enterprise Register is managed at the national level by the relevant government body. The search engine supports searches by company name, number, and other characteristics. Company pages on the Enterprise Register give basic information, including those listed below. Directors, other principals, and UBOs (where disclosed as required) are identified, with the DOBs of directors and UBOs given.

* Name
* Corporate ID
* Activity
* Entity type
* Share capital
* Wholly-owned (Y/N)
* Branch registrations
* Date of registration with its current commercial court

Note: The company's date of ''registration'' may not be its date of ''incorporation''. Look for a date of activity commencement or historical filings to check.

===Commercial Court Registry Database===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

The older corporate database, maintained by the Commercial Court Registries. Compared to the National Enterprise Register, this database may only offer corporate filings for a fee. However, it does offer various company details for free, including those listed below. Directors and other principals are listed.

* Address
* Trade name
* Legal form
* Last year's turnover (where declared)
* Activity
* Branch registrations
* Date of registration at the current Commercial Court

Further detailed documents may be obtained for a fee. The most useful of these are individual filings and annual accounts.

===Commercial Gazette Records===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

The Official Bulletin of Announcements regularly publishes announcements that companies are required to make on changes made. It may be searched by company name or ID, and also by keyword, which can identify directors.

===Free Corporate Filings===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

This database provides basic identity data on companies and, if available, a table presenting details from their most recent accounts. Further down the company page, a list of the company's corporate announcements is given. Beyond the corporate announcements, the database lists the company's corporate filings and makes them available for free download.

===Associations and Foundations===

'''[Link to the relevant source]'''

The Official Journal publishes announcements by associations and foundations (charities).

===Note on Identifying Ownership===

Ownership identification can be complex in Morocco. Always check a public company's accounts first to save time.

Moroccan companies declare changes in ownership in individual filings to the corporate registries. These filings are available through the '''National Enterprise Register''', '''Commercial Court Registry Database''' (for a fee), and '''Free Corporate Filings''' (overall best option). Scrolling down the list of filings, look for ones described as a change to share capital. Typically, these will consist of notes on a company shareholder meeting detailing the change, and then updated company statutes.

===Directorships===

Directorship searches are available through all of the official corporate records sources listed above, namely:

* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - search by name, surname, and birthdate through the Advanced Search
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - search by name, surname through the Advanced Search
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - search director's "[surname, name]" as a keyword
* '''[Link to the relevant source]''' - Provides a surname/name search for directors and sole partnerships.

Note that while a register of disqualified directors exists in Morocco, it is not publicly accessible.

===Additional Corporate Registry Resources===

* [https://www.directinfo.ma/ Moroccan Office of Industrial and] Commercial Property database search function covering companies and trademarks with basic company data available for free (''pub'', ''paid'')

* [http://www.ammc.ma/en Moroccan Authority of Capital Markets] with issuer information, management details, incorporation data, shareholder and financial information (''pub'')

* [http://www.directinfo.ma/ Database of companies searchable by] company name, patent, design and other keywords (''pub'', ''paid'')

* [http://www.mahakim.ma/Ar/Services/RC/?Page=RC Moroccan e-justice portal offering limited] corporate data with searches requiring selection of the correct commercial court (''pub'')

* [https://servicesenligne.justice.gov.ma/Home/Index Ministry of Justice corporate extracts] providing basic corporate data including personal details of directors (''pub'', ''paid'')

* [http://www.casablanca-bourse.com Casablanca Stock Exchange]  (''pub'')

=== Court System in Malawi ===
Malawi has a hierarchical court system that includes courts of first instance, appellate courts, and the Supreme Court. Information on litigation cases can be found through the official court records.

Conduct the internal Supreme Court Search and a Google Site search in both Chichewa and English. Note that the internal search requires a case number.

=== African Court on Human and Peoples' Rights ===
Conduct a site search in addition to running a page find search of the following tabs:
- Latest Decisions
- Finalized Decisions
- Pending Decisions

=== WorldLII ===
Conduct internal and Google site searches in both Chichewa and English.

Search is available by the name or ID number of the company for all company types and it gives detailed and historical information. At AJPES, more information is available in Slovenian language compared to the English version. Options in the upper menu: eRTR - data on bank accounts of companies (open, closed) JOLP - annual reports of companies eOBJAVE - insolvency cases w/supporting documentation.

* [http://www.gvin.com/ Gvin (Commercial business registry of Bisnode)] (''paid'', ''reg'') - Search by names of directors/shareholders. Offers all the financial data from annual reports (incl. for years before 2008/2009, which are usually the earliest years you get annual reports for at Ajpes). Info on tax payments, ongoing lawsuits and credit ratings (the latter is a payable service of Ajpes). If a company changed its name, Ajpes would return no results, while Gvin would detect it and put you through to the "new" company. Offers all available documents in one place (except those you can find only at the court register - memorandum/articles of association, insolvency reports, statute). You can click on the address of a company and see what other companies are registered there. Registration and payment required.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
* [http://www.einforma.com/ Third-party (D&B-affiliated) database of Spanish companies]  (''paid'')

As of July 2025, this website offered 5 free basic company reports in return for a free sign-up. Even if paid for, the basic report was EUR 6, compared to EUR 9 with the official registry (which is harder to sign up for, see below). Einforma's reports offer all background information on a company (including directors and owners, with a reverse search available but also paid for), alongside basic financial overviews (full annual reports are available for EUR 11.50) and filings (summary free, full version EUR 4). Overall, this seems like the best option at present.

This makes the official source the [https://sede.registradores.org/sede/sede-corpme-web/home?lang=en ''Registradores de Espana''] site listed above. While the official source in Spain, this website requires sign-up either through a Spanish e-gov profile, or via application including provision of an ID document scan. Pascal completed this in July 2025, but found that the next step in signing up is an up-front payment for site credit of EUR 150. litigation.wiki_content:
Searches of litigation records from the Spanish Supreme Court (Tribunal Supremo de Justicia), the Audiencia Nacional (a special criminal/administrative law court based in Madrid) and manual searches of the regional supreme courts of Spain's autonomous regions and cities[1] (Tribunales Superiores de Justicia y Unipersonales) identified no references to ***.
 
These are: Andalucía; Aragón; Principado de Asturias; Baleares; Canarias; Cantabria; Castilla-La Mancha; Castilla y León; Cataluña; Extremadura; Galicia; La Rioja; Comunidad de Madrid; Región de Murcia, Comunidad Foral de Navarra; País Vasco; Comunidad Valenciana; Ceuta and Melilla.

Spain follows a civil law legal system, derived from Roman law, which relies on comprehensive legal codes rather than case law. Unlike common law systems, judicial decisions do not have a binding precedent, but they may still influence future rulings. Legal outcomes and the interpretation of codes rely heavily on strict adherence to statutory law and legal scholarship. Searchable legal databases in Spain include multiple resources that encompass various levels of courts and tribunals. These databases provide access to judicial decisions, although the focus is primarily on statutory law.

'''[http://www.poderjudicial.es Consejo General del Poder Judicial]''' This body supervises the judiciary and maintains records of judicial decisions made across Spain. It plays a crucial role in the judiciary's administration and provides significant transparency in judicial proceedings. Search Tip: Use the site's internal search bar to find judgments and related records. Searchable by keyword (company name), but the only other search tools relate to court data. Searchable by keyword only. Searchable by keyword only.

'''[https://www.cnmc.es Comisión Nacional de los Mercados y la Competencia]''' This commission deals with cases related to market regulation and competition law in Spain. Their database includes rulings and sanctions related to competitive practices. Search Tip: For litigation related to market competition, utilize the search functionality within the website.

'''[https://www.boe.es BOE (Boletín Oficial del Estado)]''' The official state gazette publishes all legislative, regulatory, and legal announcements, including court judgments. It serves as an essential resource for understanding statutory law and regulatory updates. Search Tip: Use keyword searches relevant to the case or statutes you are interested in.

* [http://www.poderjudicial.es/search/indexAN.jsp Portal for judicial information in] Spain (''pub'')

* [https://www.poderjudicial.es/search/indexAN.jsp National high courts and provincial] courts case law database (''pub'')

Search for tax status but requires identification number.

Corporate Websites and Open Web Searches

Locate, when possible, the company's corporate website.
Run site searches of the Salvadoran government portal site:.gob.sv and site:.sv as a good starting point to figure out what kind of identifying information and regulatory footprint your subject has. As you run these searches, keep an eye out for the company's National Tax Identification ("NIT") number (the NIT is not always possible to find). 
Salvadoran companies will sometimes list their full legal names and trade names on their websites. A good way to try to determine the corporate suffix/legal name of a company is to go to the company's website and check the privacy policy or terms of use section.

[https://sayari.auth0.com/u/login/identifier?state=hKFo2SBBaFZrbDJNNWV0Q3pMUFJ1aldLV2R5OFlJVW5kUWxwNKFur3VuaXZlcnNhbC1sb2dpbqN0aWTZIGt0MjlNZXdZRnowTmJpYnp0TGdqVXRHWm9zdGZWZ3Jvo2NpZNkgcFcwUHF4bENyMTA4WGYxajU1WlZNS3lTQ2dJaFBUdVA Sayari Graph]

Search Sayari Graph. See the Sayari Guidance Wiki for information about how to conduct Sayari Graph searches.
Sayari Graph scrapes from the El Salvador Commercial Registry and can provide us with access to whatever corporate registry documents have been digitized locally. These documents sometimes contain the company's NIT number which can be decoded (see instructions below) to determine the company's date of establishment.

National Tax Identification ("NIT")

If you have not found the NIT in Sayari Graph or elsewhere, google: "Subject Name" AND (NIT OR ""Número de Identificación Tributaria"")
Though not always possible, once you have found the NIT, please decode it.
The set of numbers after the first - is the date in which the company was created or the person was born. The first two numbers are the day, the second two are the month, and the last two are year.
Ex. 010101 - January 1, 2001.
For more information, refer to the link.

The NIT is a national tax payer identification number issued to tax-paying individuals and entities in El Salvador. The NIT is not always possible to find.

[www.cnr.gob.sv National Records Center]

Internal search and site search. Also note that you can search by name (kind of like NUANS in Canada), which can show you whether the company exists. Minimal information though. Official company registry: Dates back to July 2005. Can find data on companies that were dissolved, formed, transferred; however it is not a database. There are individual documents for specific periods of time which contain business data, such as directors, registered capital, addresses, full legal entity names, etc.

[www.comprasal.gob.sv National Records Center]  

The National Records Center also has links to various registries, including intellectual property (patents, trademarks) and real estate. However, accessing information on the registries requires an identification number of the person requesting the information, or a transaction number associated with the property which is the subject of the inquiry. Official government contractor registry. Provides address, telephone number, and website for government contractors; categorizes the company by size; no ID numbers provided.

[www.amchamsal.com American Chamber of Commerce of El Salvador]

Search AmCham members for your subject company for basic contact information, such as addresses.

[www.anep.org.sv National Association of Private Enterprise]	

According to ANEP's website: ANEP brings together 50 trade entities belonging to 55 economic subsectors and more than 15 thousand companies, 93% of them are small, 4% medium and 3% large companies.

You may not find much information on your subject company.

[https://app.vlex.com/#account/login vLex]

Run vLex only after having run all of the above searches and only if the the above searches yield absolutely no information.
If you do not find any information with the above searches, do the following:
Log in to vLex. Click on Advanced Search on the left. Click on Search All Countries & International. Then click on Select Jurisdiction. Select El Salvador only. In the search bar at the top of the page, type in the name of the subject. The preselected option will be to search All content. Hit search. Search through the content to determine if there is any corporation registration information.

Individual Identification		

Open Web and Salvadoran Domain Searches: Do all of the following as a key starting point for Salvadoran individuals:
- Search Subject's Name in Google Noticias
- General Google Open Web searches
- Open Corporates (in case of any affiliations with Panama companies)
- Site search of Salvadoran government portal -> site.:gob.sv
- Site search of Salvadoran domain -> site:.sv

Things to keep any eye out for are name variations, employment history, university education, NIT or Documento Unico de Identidad ("DUI") numbers, and/or any other bits of identifying information for the subject. The DUI is a national identification card issued to all Salvadoran nationals which serves as primary form of identification in the country and is required for activities such as voting in elections.

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
===Moneyhouse===

Moneyhouse.ch is a private third-party corporate record aggregator, and it's usually the most convenient place to start looking at corporate records. We have an account, and when logged in some extra information should be visible, so it's best to do that. 

This website has a simple search function where you can enter the name of a company or an individual, and it'll search all Swiss cantons plus Liechtenstein. If you enter an individual's name, it'll show you directorships but not ownership. 

The page for a company shows a decent amount of information, though not arranged in the most user-friendly way. 

* In the first section ("Übersicht" in German), you can see its share capital, number of employees, address, sector of business, directors' names, incorporation date and purpose (often quite a detailed and specific description), then there's the most recent corporate filing that names them (from the Swiss Official Gazette of Commerce, "SHAB").
* The second section ("Auskünfte") allows you to buy various types of financial report.
* The third section ("Management") shows you current and past directors, and their dates.
* The fourth section ("Netzwerk") visually displays directorships and doesn't seem very useful.
* The fifth section ("Timeline") shows major events on a timeline.
* The sixth section ("Kennzahlen") shows some basic information already included in the first section.
* The seventh section ("Besitzverhältnisse") should in theory list the company's shareholders and shareholdings/subsidiaries, but in practice it's very often empty/incomplete.
* The eighth section ("Meldungen") lists SHAB filings.
* The ninth section ("Marken") lists brands registered with the company.

The page for an individual shows more limited information: 
* The first section ("Übersicht") only really shows their citizenship (or for Swiss citizens, canton of origin) and place of residence (town if in Switzerland, town and country if abroad) and then provides the most recent corporate filing that mentions them.
* The second tab ("Auskünfte") allows you to download a PDF containing the information from the first, third and fifth tabs.
* The third tab ("Mandate") shows a list of past and present directorships and their dates.
* The fourth tab ("Netzwerk") visualizes their connections and doesn't seem particularly useful.
* The fifth tab ("Beteiligungen") should in theory show companies in which they own shares, but in practice it's usually empty.
* The sixth tab ("Meldungen") provides a list of corporate filings that mention them.

As Moneyhouse is a third-party website, we don't usually cite it directly in our reports. To cite, we can either provide a link to an official website (see below) or just write something like "Swiss corporate records".

* [http://www.moneyhouse.ch/ Online company database with director] names, shareholders, gazette notifications and registered company activity (''pub'', ''paid'')

===Swiss Official Gazette of Commerce (SHAB)===

The Swiss Official Gazette of Commerce, generally known by its German acronym SHAB, has an official website at shab.ch. Its local names are Schweizerisches Handelsamtsblatt (German), Feuille officielle suisse du commerce (French) and Foglio ufficiale svizzero di commercio (Italian).

The SHAB contains entries for certain types of changes to corporate records, such as the establishment or dissolution of a company, the addition or removal of directors, and changes of company names. There are two search fields on the website's homepage, one for all entries since 2 September 2018 and one for all entries before that, back until 1999. 

It's worth searching this website if the information on Moneyhouse seems questionable or incomplete, which may especially be the case when a company has changed name or address. 

* [https://www.shab.ch/shabforms/COMMON/application/applicationGrid.jsp?newLanguage=EN Swiss Official Gazette of Commerce] - Information about company changes and gazette notifications (''pub'')

===Official cantonal corporate registries===

Each Swiss canton has its own corporate registry, and although Moneyhouse generally does a good job of aggregating data from all of them, it's often a good idea to check the relevant official registry too, to be certain of up-to-date information. In some cases, the official registry may contain information that Moneyhouse lacks. As these registries are official, if they let you link directly to companies' pages, you can use these links as citations in your reports.

Here are the cantonal registries:
* Aargau https://ag.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Appenzell Inner-Rhodes https://ai.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Appenzell Outer-Rhodes https://ar.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Basel City https://bs.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Basel-Landschaft https://bl.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml 
* Bern https://be.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Fribourg https://adm.appls.fr.ch/hrcmatic/
* Geneva https://app2.ge.ch/ecohrcinternet/ 
* Glarus https://gl.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Grisons https://gr.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Jura https://ju.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Lucerne https://lu.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Neuchâtel https://www.ne.ch/autorites/DESC/NECO/rcne/Pages/Recherche-d'entreprises.aspx
* Nidwalden https://nw.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Obwalden https://ow.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml
* Schaffhausen https://sh.chregister.ch/cr-portal/suche/suche.xhtml

litigation.wiki_content:
===Federal===

You can search for records on the following court websites:

* Federal Court (Bundesgericht): https://www.bger.ch/ext/eurospider/live/fr/php/clir/http/index.php (Switzerland's supreme court; cases since 1954)
* Federal Administrative Court (Bundesverwaltungsgericht): https://bvger.weblaw.ch/dashboard (cases since 2007)
* Federal Criminal Court (Bundesstrafgericht): https://bstger.weblaw.ch/dashboard (cases since 2004; largely anonymised)
* Federal Patent Court (Bundespatentgericht): https://www.bundespatentgericht.ch/rechtsprechung/einfache-suche

* [http://www.bger.ch/ Bundesgericht - The Supreme Court] of Switzerland (''pub'')

* [https://bstger.weblaw.ch/index.php?= Bundesstrafgericht - The Federal Criminal] Court database of cases (''pub'')

* [https://www.bger.ch/it/index.htm Supreme Court records - Requires] journalist accreditation for detailed information (''pub'', ''reg'')

* [http://bstger.weblaw.ch/index.php?method=search The Swiss Tribunal penal federal] - Searchable database of decisions (''pub'')

* [https://www.bstger.ch/en/il-tribunale/il-tribunale-penale-federale-in-breve.html Federal Supreme Court - Landmark] rulings since 1954 (''pub'')

* [http://relevancy.bger.ch/ Federal Supreme Court - Further] rulings since 2000 (''pub'')

* [https://www.bundespatentgericht.ch Federal Patent Court - Database] of patent cases (''pub'')

* [https://jurispub.admin.ch/publiws/ Federal Administrative Court decisions and] judgments (''pub'')

* [https://www.bvger.ch Federal Administrative Court website]  (''pub'')

* [https://www.bvger.ch/bvger/en/home/judgments/entscheiddatenbank-bvger.html Federal Administrative Court judgment database]  (''pub'')

===Cantonal===

You can search for records on the following court websites (this list is currently non-exhaustive):

* Bern: https://www.zsg-entscheide.apps.be.ch/tribunapublikation/ (civil and criminal)
* Valais: https://jurisprudence.vs.ch/ (database of selected decisions from the Cantonal Court of Valais; cases since 2009; completely anonymised)
* Zug: https://verwaltungsgericht.zg.ch/ (Administrative Court)
* Zug: https://obergericht.zg.ch/ (High Court)
* Zurich: https://www.gerichte-zh.ch/entscheide/entscheide-suchen.html (unified database for decisions from the High Court of the Canton of Zurich, the Court of Cassation of the Canton of Zurich, the Commercial Court of the Canton of Zurich, and the canton's 12 district courts)

corporate_registry.wiki_content:
* '''İstanbul Chamber of Commerce – Bilgi Bankası''' – [https://bilgibankasi.ito.org.tr/tr/bilgi-bankasi/firma-bilgileri Company information search].  The Istanbul Chamber of Commerce operates an online information bank where users can search for company information using a trade registry number, chamber registry number or company name.  The search page lists options such as “Firma Bilgileri Arama,” “Ticaret Sicil No,” “Oda Sicil No,” “Ticaret Unvanına Göre,” and filters by NACE code.  The site notes that registration and announcement details are available through MERSİS or the Turkish Trade Registry Gazette.

* '''MERSİS – Central Trade Registry System''' – [https://mersis.gtb.gov.tr/Portal/Home/Index Central trade registry system].  MERSİS is a national database that digitises commercial registry processes and stores data electronically.  It contains company titles, addresses, contact information, capital details, partners, joint capital information, business fields and executive bodies.  Access is available to registered users or via e-signature; some information is public, while filings and changes require authentication.

* '''Turkish Trade Registry Gazette''' – [https://www.ticaretsicil.gov.tr Turkish Trade Registry Gazette].  This official gazette publishes trade registry amendments, official announcements, court decisions and bankruptcy notices.  Under Article 37 of the Turkish Commercial Code all changes to the trade register must be published here.  It is issued daily (around 850 pages) and has been available online free of charge since 1 October 2003.  Users can search by company name, registry number or gazette number.

* '''Adana Chamber of Commerce''' – [https://www.adana-to.org.tr Adana Chamber – member directory].  Provides an online directory of members of the Adana Chamber of Commerce.  Searches by company name or registry number return basic data such as trade registry number, contact details, capital and shareholders.  Full access may require membership or registration (Turkish only).

* '''İstanbul Chamber of Commerce – business name search''' – [http://www.ito.org.tr/wps/portal/bi Business name search].  Allows users to look up a company name and verify its existence in the trade register.  Results include the trade name and registration number; detailed filings link back to the trade registry gazette.

* '''Mersin Chamber of Commerce''' – [http://oda.mtso.org.tr/mtso/BorcDet Debt inquiry (members only)].  This portal enables members of the Mersin Chamber of Commerce to check outstanding membership dues by entering their membership number.  Access is restricted to registered members.

* '''Turkish Standards Institute (TSE)''' – [https://belge.tse.org.tr/Genel/Firm Certified company search].  TSE maintains an online database of companies holding TSE quality certificates.  Users can search by company name, certificate number or product category to verify certification status.  Registration may be required for some certificate types.
